We are gravely concerned at the Government's proposal to reduce significantly the pension and access to fringe benefits of persons who in good faith bought market linked insurance bonds, friendly society bonds, approved deposit funds, deferred annuities and unit trusts to protect their savings.

The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

We urge the government to declare a moratorium on uranium mining and treatment in Australia;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The proposed amendments will make possible a more flexible approach to Commonwealth overseas debt raising and management activities in the interests of more cost effective management of the Commonwealth's external debt portfolio. In particular, the Bill enables the Commonwealth to use a wider range of modern borrowing instruments and would assist in the management of foreign currency exposure with currency and interest rate swaps and other hedging techniques. This is essential if the Commonwealth is to minimise the cost of its external debt portfolio.

The proposed amendments to the Act do not provide the Government with additional powers to borrow money overseas. However, under present arrangements, the Government can only issue securities, such as medium term notes or short term commercial paper, with the Governor-General's approval for each issue. This is because under the present legislation each issue or short term rollover is considered to be a new borrowing. In practice, it is very cumbersome to submit each issue of notes under a medium term note program, or frequent rollovers of short term debt, for approval. Under the proposed amendments to sections 3 and 5a, the Governor-General could approve a program of borrowings up to a certain limit. This would be consistent with the arrangements applying to the Commonwealth's domestic borrowings and powers held by other OECD sovereign borrowers.

The new subsection 5b (1) is designed to provide the Treasurer with specific power to enter swaps or other financial agreements for debt management purposes. Swaps, which are essentially agreements between two parties to exchange financial obligations, are used extensively by a large range of international borrowers as a hedging technique. Section 5b (1) would also enable the use of other debt management techniques, such as interest rate caps which are designed to limit exposure to floating interest rates.

While the Government already has the authority to enter swap arrangements under the Consititution (and has undertaken a number of swap transactions during 1987-88), subsection 5b (1) would provide specific authority to this effect.

The proposed legislative amendments to subsection 5b (2) provide for standing appropriation for swaps. Swaps contracts are presently being met from annual appropriations but, given their unpredictable nature, it would be more appropriate if they were funded by way of standing appropriation. Such an amendment would bring more certainty to the future commitment of funds to honour swap contracts and would put swap funding on the same basis as overseas borrowings which are covered by standing appropriation. It is in line with the Government's view that unpredictable outlays be authorised by standing appropriations.

In seeking Executive Council authority for the Government to undertake overseas loans and swap arrangements, it has been customary for the Governor-General, in the documentation for each loan, to give the Treasurer the power to submit the Commonwealth to foreign legal jurisdiction and to waive legal immunity for the Commonwealth in respect of itself or its property (except for property used or intended to be used for diplomatic, consular or military purposes). Accordingly, the new section 5c encompasses the existing arrangements formally into the legislation.

Finally the proposed legislation (section 5d) expands existing arrangements for the Treasurer to delegate his powers regarding borrowings, swaps and other financial agreements or arrangements to a specified departmental officer or, in overseas countries, to a specified member of the Australian diplomatic mission. This would allow Treasury officials to set prices in line with market conditions subject to least favourable terms set by the Treasurer. Under a medium term note issue, securities are offered to investors continuously at market related rates and it would not be practical for the Treasurer to determine individual bond prices on a continuous basis (possibly several times a week).
FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT

The proposed amendments provide the Government with the flexibility to undertake a wide range of overseas borrowings and make more timely use of favourable interest rate or exchange rate movements to manage its debt portfolio more efficiently and reduce the overall cost of the portfolio.

During 1987-88 expenditure on net swap payments was $11 million and the Government has appropriated $30 million for these purposes in 1988-89. The transactions undertaken in 1987-88 were essentially aimed at changing the composition of the Commonwealth's external debt liabilities to better hedge the debt portfolio against possible exchange rate risk. The proposed amendments will ensure that swap commitments are provided for under standing appropriation.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANIZATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have a second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the employment provisions of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act. Sections 85 and 86 of the Act provide for the determination of salaries and terms and conditions of employment of ASIO staff by the Director-General of Security, the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department and the Chairman of the Public Service Board.

Sections 34 and 35 of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Amendment Act 1986 substitute the ``Public Service Board'' for the Chairman of the Board and the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department. There is now no longer a Public Service Board or a Chairman. An amendment is therefore required to remove these outmoded references and to ensure that staff of the Organization receive the benefit of wage increases awarded to the community.
In future, salaries and terms and conditions will be determined by the Director-General, who will be subject to any guidelines that the Attorney-General may give him pursuant to section 8a.

The amendment to section 8a makes it clear that guidelines under the section can be given in relation to these matters. These amendments thus provide a mechanism for ensuring that public sector policy on pay and conditions is taken into account by the Director-General as well as recognising the special circumstances associated with employment in the Organization.

The references in sections 85 and 86 to the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department are also being removed, since it is no longer appropriate for this officer to be involved in the determination of pay and conditions.
Financial Impact Statement
The Bill has no financial impact.
I commend the Bill to the Senate

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

When the Minister for Social Security introduced the Bill for the Child Support Act in the Parliament late last year the Minister indicated that maintenance would be able to be collected for all children of a marriage or for those ex-nuptial children where a State had referred its powers. Four States, New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania, agreed to refer their powers relating to ex-nuptial children to the Commonwealth.

The Minister also indicated that special provision was being made to provide for the collection of maintenance of ex-nuptial children of Queensland and Western Australia should either State, in the future, refer their powers to the Commonwealth, pass corresponding legislation or adopt the Child Support Act.

In the event, both Queensland and Western Australia have now indicated that they intend to adopt the Child Support Act as a means of including ex-nuptial children in their States in the Government's new child support scheme.

So as to enable the adoption of the Child Support Act by Queensland and Western Australia to be effective, the Attorney-General has advised that some minor technical amendments are required to be made so that the Child Support Act will also apply where maintenance orders or agreements in respect of ex-nuptial children are made under the law of a State.
This Bill simply makes those technical amendments.
Mr President, I would like to take this opportunity to briefly mention the present position in relation to the possible use of the Child Support Agency for collection of maintenance for state wards.

Discussions are proceeding with each of the States through the income security sub-committee of social welfare administrators. While the government is pleased with the progress of those discussions the Government does not expect that any state would seek to use the Child Support Agency for collecting maintenance for state wards until those discussions are concluded.

Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, the Treasurer announced in the 1988-89 Budget that the Government has decided that an annual supervisory fee is to be levied, commencing in 1988-89, on life and general insurance companies. The purpose of this fee is to recover the ongoing costs of supervision of such insurers under the Life Insurance Act 1945 and the Insurance Act 1973 respectively by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.
The Bill before the Senate, namely the Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, gives effect to this announcement.

The opportunity has also been taken to make a number of other amendments to insurance industry supervisory legislation. The Bill incorporates measures to provide for the registration under the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 of insurance intermediaries dealing with unauthorised foreign insurers. It will also effect a number of amendments to the Life Insurance Act 1945 to strengthen and improve the effectiveness of the existing supervisory arrangements, all of which will increase the level of protection available to the insuring public.
The Bill is structured into five parts.

Part I includes the commencement provisions and provides for specified provisions to come into operation on the 28th day after the day on which the Bill receives the Royal Assent, and for all other provisions to come into operation on day or days to be fixed by Proclamation.

Part II amends the Insurance Act 1973 to include the new provisions relating to the levying of the annual supervisory fee on general insurers. It also repeals section 113, which deals with unauthorised foreign insurers, in order to remove legislative overlaps with section 34 of the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984.

Part III amends the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 to include new provisions requiring the registration of all insurance intermediaries dealing with unauthorised foreign insurers, and the collection of statistics regarding premiums remitted overseas.
Part IV amends the Life Insurance Amendment Act 1977 to repeal two redundant unproclaimed sections.
Part V amends the Life Insurance Act 1945 in five ways:
(1) to include the new provisions relating to the levying of the annual supervisory fee on life insurers;
(2) to introduce the concept of `appointed actuary' for the purpose of performing certain functions required under the Act;
(3) to repeal certain redundant provisions;

(4) to change the period for furnishing to Parliament the annual report on the workings of the Act. The proposed period is to be within 3 months of the year ending on 30 June which corresponds to the reporting period provided in the other Acts administered by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner; and
(5) to effect a number of other changes intended to clarify and enhance the existing supervisory arrangements.
I would now like to address the more significant provisions of the Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill 1988.
First, the annual supervisory fee in respect of life and general insurers. At present, the cost of supervising the life and general insurance industries is borne by taxpayers in general.
The proposed annual supervisory fee on life and general insurance companies is based on the application of the ``user pays'' principle.
This approach is not a new one; it already applies in a number of areas of government activity. For instance, registration fees are imposed by the Commonwealth in respect of insurance brokers.

There is also a supervisory fee applicable to occupational superannuation funds and approved deposit funds that wish to take advantage of relevant concessions available under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

The proposed fee reflects the Government's view that, generally, where a service is designed to benefit a particular group, the cost should be borne by that immediate group of beneficiaries of the service rather than by taxpayers in general.

The supervisory fee will be payable into Consolidated Revenue. Its imposition will not affect the existing arrangements under which the financial resources made available to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission are subject to the same scrutiny processes as are applicable to Commonwealth departments generally.

As announced in the Budget, the proposed annual fee will be a flat fee and will be $19,000 for each registered life insurance company and $11,000 for each authorised general insurance company. Appropriate regulations to give effect to these fees will be sought later this year following passage of the Bill. The proposed supervisory fee has been estimated to raise $2.9 million in a full year.

The proposed fee will be payable in respect of financial years ending on or after 1 July 1988. It is intended that the fee be paid at the same time as an insurer's annual returns are normally lodged with the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The first fees will be payable by insurers in 1988-89 and will be applied to offset the Commonwealth's costs of supervising the industries in 1988-89.

I turn now to the proposed changes covered in Parts III and V of the Bill. These proposed amendments-to the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 and the Life Insurance Act 1945-have been the subject of consultations with representatives of industry bodies including, where relevant, the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, the Insurance Council of Australia, the Institute of Actuaries of Australia and the National Insurance Brokers Association of Australia. In addition, some of the other amendments provided for in the Bill have emerged as a result of suggestions put forward by the industry.

Presently, the Insurance Act 1973 and the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 do not provide as much protection to consumers dealing with agents of unauthorised foreign insurers as to those dealing with either agents of authorised insurers or brokers.

In the case of agents of authorised insurers there is more scope to enforce the statutory requirement that an insurer must accept liability for the conduct of his agent. Brokers must in general hold professional indemnity insurance.
The Government is of the view that those insured should be allowed access to overseas insurance markets where they wish to seek it.

At the same time the Government believes that insurance consumers should be reminded of the importance of considering the possible implications of entering into insurance contracts with offshore insurers who are not supervised under Australian insurance law.
Against this background the Bill will provide increased protection for those insured by including certain additional provisions in the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984.

A key additional requirement will be that all insurance intermediaries who arrange insurance contracts with unauthorised foreign insurers will be required to be registered under the Act, unless they are already registered as an insurance broker.
In addition, these intermediaries, as well as registered insurance brokers who arrange insurance contracts with unauthorised foreign insurers, will be required to:
(1) provide to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission a copy of any agency agreements they have with an unauthorised foreign insurer (the agreements to be available for public inspection);
(2) obtain written acknowledgement from the insured that cover may be provided in whole or in part by an unauthorised foreign insurer; and

(3) provide an Annual Return to the Commission on their activities in this area. This Annual Return will enable the Commission to monitor the volume of business placed with unauthorised foreign insurers through insurance intermediaries.

There will also be scope to make regulations to impose a requirement on intermediaries operating under these provisions to take out professional indemnity insurance cover in respect of their operations in this area.

I now turn to the proposed amendments concerning the Life Insurance Act 1945. These amendments are considered necessary to enhance the effectiveness of the Act, particularly in relation to the functions required to be performed by actuaries, and to clarify a number of the existing supervisory arrangements.
The most important of these amendments will introduce a new provision to require each life insurance company to identify an actuary as the `appointed actuary' to the company.

In the last decade or so, there has been a substantial increase in the variety of life insurance products marketed by life insurance companies. Consequently, life insurance business has become much more complicated than ever before.

Against this background, it has become increasingly important that actuaries of companies performing certain statutory functions under the Life Insurance Act carry out those functions in an objective and professional manner notwithstanding the fact that they may be receiving remuneration from the companies concerned. Creating the position of an `appointed actuary' will assist in achieving this objective.

Provisions in the Bill will require each life insurance company to appoint an actuary as the `appointed actuary', within a certain period of time, for the purpose of performing the actuarial functions specified under a number of provisions of the Act.
Small life insurance companies will not be precluded from appointing a consulting actuary as `appointed actuary'.

The position of `appointed actuary' will assist the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner in identifying the particular actuary for each company who is responsible for discharging the key actuarial functions required by the Life Insurance Act.

As a minimum level of experience, an appointed actuary must be a Fellow of the Institute of Actuaries of Australia of not less than 5 years standing. This qualification is regarded as necessary in view of the importance of the functions to be performed by the appointed actuary.
The requirement for an appointed actuary is supported by the Institute of Actuaries of Australia and the Life Insurance Federation of Australia.

The Bill also includes provisions to increase the threshold for publication in the Gazette of life insurance unclaimed moneys from $20 to $200. Publication annually of all unclaimed moneys of not less than $20 is a time-consuming and costly procedure.

This proposed change will apply to statements of unclaimed moneys as at 31 December 1988 and later, and should result in significant administrative savings as it has been estimated that in excess of 50 per cent of all unclaimed moneys are below $200.
The proposal will not affect a person's right to make a claim in respect of unclaimed moneys, including amounts less than $200, where satisfactory proof of claim can be made.

To increase public awareness of unclaimed moneys, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission will be making available the statements of all new unclaimed moneys from 31 December 1988. These lists will be available for public inspection in the Commission's Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra offices.

The unclaimed moneys provision in the Life Insurance Act is also being amended to give to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner power to authorise payment of unclaimed moneys. This is appropriate given the arrangements put in place last year with the passage of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Act 1987.

Among other changes proposed in this Bill is an amendment to alter the timing for the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to submit a report to the Treasurer on the workings of the Act. This time will be changed from five months after 31 December to three months after 30 June each year.

The Office of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner has overall responsibility for preparation of annual reports not only in respect of the Life Insurance Act 1945, but also the Insurance Act 1973, the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 and the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984. This proposal will allow the Commissioner to more effectively carry out his responsibilities under those Acts by producing a single consolidated annual report within 3 months of 30 June each year.

A further proposed amendment involves repeal of section 13 which permits the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to arbitrate in a dispute between a life insurance company and a policy owner in relation to a policy.
This provision has been used only once in more than 40 years of operation of the Act.

It is considered that the Office of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner is not equipped to provide arbitration services and it is therefore more appropriate that such disputes be settled by recourse to commercial, legal or other channels. At the same time, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission is examining in conjunction with other Government agencies and industry bodies possible additional arrangements for resolving disputes between insurers and policyowners.
Other proposed amendments include:

(1) repeal of two redundant unproclaimed sections of the Life Insurance Amendment Act 1977 relating to the conduct of non-insurance business by registered life insurers without the approval in writing of the Commissioner, and the registration of companies;
(2) improvements to certain definitions within the Life Insurance Act 1945;
(3) enhanced requirements for the provision of information in applications for registration under the Act;
(4) clarification of a number of existing provisions to remedy uncertainties in their administration;
(5) a reduction in the period of notice required to be given by life insurers before issuing a special policy to replace a policy that has been lost or destroyed; and
(6) enhancements to the review provisions in the Act to take account of introduction of the appointed actuary.

In conclusion, the various measures which I have outlined will enable the Government to recover the costs of supervision of the general and life insurance industries. The measures will also provide worthwhile increased protection for the insuring public and, consistent with the Government's broad approach to regulation, will not impose undue burdens on the industries involved.
I commend the Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:

Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ELECTORATE: (Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
TRITICALE LEVY BILL 1988

This Bill and the Associated Levy Collection Bill will provide the basis for the establishment of triticale research funding arrangements. The triticale industry will join other small emerging industries unable to support their own independent administrative arrangements in developing a research capacity under the auspices of the Australian Special Rural Research Fund.

The Bill is to provide for the imposition of a levy on triticale produced in Australia for the purpose of funding triticale industry research. The Associated Triticale Levy Collection Bill 1988 will provide the machinery for collecting the levy. Expenditure of moneys raised through the levy will be matched dollar for dollar by the Commonwealth.
Administrative and organisational arrangements for the research scheme will be provided by the Australian Special Rural Research Council pursuant to the Rural Industries Research Act 1985.
The triticale industry is a relatively small industry but has the capacity to expand its domestic markets and possibly to develop significant export markets.

Industry research to date has been funded by a voluntary levy on the industry with some Commonwealth funds from the Australian Special Rural Research Fund. The industry has established research programs in several States but those programs have rested on a precarious funding base, with no capacity to expand to meet the needs of an emerging industry. Recently these programs and funding have proven inadequate to cover the range of issues the industry needs to address to develop as an efficient and competitive industry on the domestic market and in a hostile world market. The Commonwealth supported program is intended to provide secure arrangements for an expanded research effort into production and beyond that into areas such as economic and marketing research.

The legislation provides for an initial levy rate of one dollar per tonne of triticale. Provision exists for the rate to be varied by regulation up to a maximum of two dollars per tonne. Provision is also made for any recommendations arising from consultation between the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Triticale Industry Organisation to be taken into account prior to any adjustment to the operative rate of the levy or leviable weight.

Amounts equal to the levy will be paid into a separate account established for the purpose in the special research fund. This will be accommodated by a provision in the accompanying amendments to the Rural Industries Research Act 1985. The Commonwealth's matching contribution will be up to a maximum level equal to 0.5% of the average gross value of triticale production. It is expected that initially the levy will raise about 160,000 dollars. The special research council will therefore have scope for an annual triticale research program approaching three hundred thousand dollars.
The commencement date of this legislation will be on a date to be proclaimed. It is intended that the levy be imposed on triticale produced in the 1988 harvest.

A full year research program under the scheme cannot begin until 1989/90. However the actual level of expenditure on research will be determined by the Special Research Council and it is possible some research could be funded in 1988/99.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.
TRITICALE LEVY COLLECTION
BILL 1988
The purpose of this bill is to provide the machinery necessary for collecting the levy imposed by the Triticale Levy Bill 1988.
This Bill should be read as one with the Triticale Levy Bill 1988, and is to come into operation on the same day that the Levy Bill becomes operative.
The Bill specifies the liability of purchasers and receivers under the scheme, outlines penalties for non-compliance and provides appropriate powers of enforcement.
There are no financial implications other than those covered in the Second Reading Speech for the Triticale Levy Bill 1988.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.
RURAL INDUSTRIES RESEARCH AMENDMENT BILL 1988
The purposes of this Bill are
(a) to provide for an improved organisational and administrative framework under the Rural Industries Research Act 1985 (Principal Act);
(b) to enable the expenses of collection and administration relating to relevant levies to be recovered from the Australian Special Rural Research Fund; and
(c) to remedy minor defects in regulations under the Principal Act.
The main organisational amendments will enable:
(a) new levies to be added to existing rural research schemes without having the effect of creating new Councils and new Trust Funds;
(b) matching Commonwealth contributions for any statutory levies paid into the Australian Special Rural Research Fund; and
(c) the amalgamation, re-organisation and winding up of Councils and Trust Funds.

The first two of those amendments will have imminent application under the Australian Special Rural Research Fund in relation to the triticale industry. Bills for triticale industry levy imposition and levy collection were introduced with the Rural Industries Research Amendment Bill 1988. Amounts equal to triticale levies received into Commonwealth revenue will be paid into the Australian Special Rural Research Fund to be used for the purposes of research and development relating to the triticale industry. The Government will provide funds on a matching basis up to a maximum contribution of 0.5% of the triticale industry's gross value of production, in the same way as it provides matching contributions to existing Rural Research Funds. Negotiations are well advanced for addition of other small industry research levies.

There is no immediate application contemplated of the new provisions enabling the amalgamation, reorganisation and winding up of Councils and Trust Funds. The new provisions would allow, for example, a smaller Fund to amalgamate with a larger Fund for economic purposes. The amendments would also provide, in that event, for the smaller Fund, and Council, to be wound up and the money in that Fund, relevant levies and research agreements to be transferred to the larger Fund.

Where such an amalgamation takes place, levies raised from each industry involved and the Government's matching contributions will continue to be for the purpose of funding research for that industry.

The amendments enabling new levies to be added to existing rural research schemes without having the effect of creating new Councils and new Trust Funds will not apply in relation to the Barley and Wheat Trust Funds and Councils. This exclusion from this Bill had regard to the need to consult with the State Research Committees for Barley and Wheat before including them in such an amendment and the current examination of the feasibility of a grains research and development corporation which could include both barley and wheat.

There are three main amendments to the administrative framework. First, there is a clarification of the form for the annual research and development program that Councils are required to submit to the Minister for approval. The new form will provide for essential information, without unnecessary detail, to be included in a council's annual program for the Minister's consideration. Approval of individual project expenditure will continue to be the responsibility of Councils.

Second, Councils will be able to replace a partly completed 5-year research and development plan with a varied plan to cover a new 5-year period. Under existing arrangements, a Council's plan, or varied plan, relates to a fixed 5-year period at the end of which a new plan is prepared for a further fixed 5-year period. The new arrangements will provide Councils and State Research Committees with more flexibility in their planning systems particularly in incorporating changing industry and market circumstances.

Third, the existing legislation requires the approval of Councils or State Research Committees for the bulk of expenditure under sections 9 and 36 of the Principal Act. However, some expenditure relating to a council, or State Research Committee, for example administrative expenses and investment management expenses, can be made currently without the approval of the Council or Committee. This is clearly undesirable. This legislation will require Council or State Research Committee approval for all such expenditure that relates to it.

The Australian Special Rural Research Fund (ASRRF) was established to support small and infant industries. It has been funded from appropriation sources. There has been no attached industry levy. The legislation provides for small industry levies to be credited to ASRRF. When the triticale levy imposition and levy collection Bills currently before the House become law, the triticale levies will be attached to the ASRRF. In line with Government policy, the Principal Act is being amended to enable the expenses of collection and administration of relevant levies to be recovered from the ASRRF.
A number of minor defects have been identified in the regulations under the Principal Act. These are being remedied by provisions in the Bill.

This Bill will contribute to effecting Government policy on rural research funding. The Bill facilitates matching Commonwealth funding of rural research under the Australian special Rural Research Fund, but of itself has no budgetary implications beyond those announced in the May 1988 Statement on Primary Industries and Resources.

As I have said on many occasions, rural research is a high priority of the Government. This is partly reflected in the Government's commitment to increase Commonwealth matching contributions to rural research to a maximum of 0.5% of the gross value of production for each of the industries concerned. Commonwealth matching funding for 1988/89 is budgeted at $65.4 million.
Honourable Senators, I commend the Bill to the Senate.
WHEAT MARKETING AMENDMENT
BILL 1988
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Wheat Marketing Act 1984 to reflect the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport.

The Royal Commission was established in October 1986 by the Commonwealth and Mainland States. Its charter was to identify the most efficient and cost-effective integrated system for the provision of grain storage, handling, transport and port terminal services and to make recommendations on changes necessary to put such a system into effect.

In its Final Report the Commission concluded that there were significant areas where the present system was not providing the best service to grain growers. It also found that significant savings of around 10 dollars per tonne could be achieved from a more flexible and competitive distribution system. This translates to total resource cost savings across Australia annually of around 100 million dollars.

To achieve these savings the Commission recommended that grain marketers and growers be given greater choice in selecting their least-cost grain distribution paths, and that greater competition be permitted in the provision of grain distribution services, including in all elements of the grain distribution system-marketing boards, storage and handling, land transport and ports and shipping.

The Royal Commission proposed that marketing boards take more responsibility for the efficiency of the grain distribution system, particularly the minimisation of storage, handling and transport costs, and the passing of actual costs of port services and sea transport back to growers to encourage competition between ports. It also recommended that marketing boards be given the capacity to exercise choice over licensed receivers.

Similarly in the storage and handling area, the thrust of the Commission's report is toward greater competition and grower choice, with the main recommendations involving the removal of sole receival rights, commercialisation of bulk handling authorities and bringing them under the Trade Practices Act.

In the land transport area, the recommendations are aimed to encourage greater competition between road and rail, and allow growers wider choice. They include removing restrictions on the use of road for grain transport, the removal of the 2 dollars and 50 cents surcharge charged by Australian National Railways in South Australia, greater commercialisation of rail services and bringing railway services under the Trade Practices Act.

In addition, the Commission recommended specific targeted funding for local roads in the short term and, in the longer term, the establishment of an efficient road-user charge and funding allocation system.
For ports and shipping there was support for the continuation of moves to commercialise port authorities, and support for more competition in the provision of port services.

The Government strongly endorses the Commission's recommendations and is moving to implement them as quickly as possible. It is continuing to build on reforms to improve the efficiency of the road transport industry. Agreement has been reached with State and Territory Governments on a single set of rules for the country's trucking industry. The Government has also introduced a new five-year road funding program which provides for specific assistance to national arterial roads. The Commission's recommendations in regard to rail services are also well in hand as they apply to Australian National Railways.

The amendments currently before the Parliament flow from the Commission's recommendations for the operation of marketing boards. In amending the Wheat Marketing Act in advance of the broader reforms being proposed for wheat marketing generally, the Government is clearly signalling its concern that the grains industry benefit as early as possible from the advantages of a system which offers greater flexibility and choice. Both the AWB and the Grains Council of Australia endorse this approach.

Improved efficiency and effectiveness in the grain distribution sector will of course have important flow-on effects for the competitive marketing of grain generally, both in Australia and overseas. The proposed amendments therefore represent an important step in achieving a framework within which the Australian wheat industry can effectively meet the challenges of the future.

Specifically the Bill provides for the AWB to enter into contracts for services relating to grain distribution and broadens the scope of the term authorised receiver to encompass all bodies corporate with whom the the AWB has a contract for wheat receival. This means that no longer will the AWB be constrained from dealing with bodies other than the sole receiver authorised in each State as at present. Rather, the Board will be able to contract with whomever will provide the best returns for growers.

On the subject of returns to growers, the Bill provides a clear statement that the principal object of the Board shall be to maximise net returns to growers from the marketing of wheat and that this should be the overriding principle in the performance of its other functions.

The Board will also be required to provide disaggregated charges for these services in its accounts to growers to the extent that this is possible and does not incur significant net additional costs. Growers will therefore be more aware of the costs associated with the individual services employed to receive, handle and transport their grain and will be in a better position to make choices as to their least-cost grain path.

This being said, I do not anticipate, and neither did the Royal Commission, that there will be dramatic changes in the short term. The current bulk handling authorities will remain the dominant providers of storage and handling services and road and rail transport will largely retain their existing tonnages. However, they will be exposed to competition and face pressure to contain their costs.

What is envisaged is a progressive redirection of grain flows through the most efficient storage and handling facilities, and a reallocation of the grain transportation task between road and rail so that each undertakes that part of the task for which it is best suited.

These and other changes announced by the Government are significant in opening the door to competitive pressures. Nevertheless I acknowledge that the bulk of the Commission's recommendations fall within the ambit of the States. I am therefore hopeful that the States will follow suit, as I have urged them to do.
In this respect I am encouraged by recent announcements that the New South Wales Government has adopted the Royal Commission's recommendations and will also be introducing changes to its system.

The passage of the Bill will involve no costs to the Commonwealth. On the contrary, it will facilitate the development of a more cost-effective grain distribution system with increased industry efficiencies and benefits to the community generally.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to the following Bills:
Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988
States Grants (General Revenue) Bill 1988

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate advising me of Senator Michael Baume's resignation from the House Committee and nominating Senator Crichton-Browne to be a member in his place.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray)-by leave-agreed to:
That Senator Michael Baume be discharged from further attendance on the House Committee and that Senator Crichton-Browne be appointed to that Committee.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (TAX FILE NUMBERS) BILL 1988PRIVACY BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 November, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bills be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Haines had moved by way of amendment:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate notes that-

(a) the Government's tax file number system is unacceptably intrusive in that the tax file number will be given to a range of private sector institutions which will not be adequately covered by the Government's privacy legislation;

(b) the Opposition parties' amendments to the tax file number legislation are meaningless to the ordinary taxpayer in that they only provide wealthy people with a real option not to supply the tax file number to private sector institutions; and

(c) the Government and Opposition parties are both to be condemned for their failure to support an alternative system which would have caught people who were cheating the tax system and protected the privacy of Australian taxpayers, and would not have laid the foundations of a national identification system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was adjourned last night, I was making a point about what the Australian Taxation Office had said about where the tax file number would not be required to be used. I mentioned loan accounts of all descriptions, including mortgages, credit cards and leases, and the fact that the tax file number would not be required for non-interest bearing cheque accounts or for existing-I emphasise the word `existing'-interest bearing accounts with banks, building societies and credit unions where the interest paid or credited each year remains below $120. I think I stated that about 70 per cent of accounts with building societies and credit unions fall below this level. I also said that the tax file number would not be required to be used with investments subject to quotation requirements where the person is prepared to accept deductions for tax at the maximum marginal rate at the time the income is paid, and also for a range of investments such as real estate and insurance bonds.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone, Senator Michael Baume, Senator Durack and Senator Hill have already spoken in this debate. Senator Panizza and Senator Crichton-Browne are still to speak in this debate. I think all the honourable senators who have spoken have made very worthwhile contributions. I will not go on much longer, except to say that the amendments to the tax file number proposal and the criteria set down by Mr Howard last year for the coalition are now met with the three criteria being agreed to, and effectively that deals with tax fraud, does not jeopardise civil liberties and is cost-effective. The Opposition has stalled the tax file number being surreptitiously turned into a de facto ID card through the back door. I think the work of the Hon. Neil Brown in the other place has been essential to making the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill a workable Bill. I am quite sure that the $300m that it effectively will raise out of the community will be wisely spent by this Government. Let us hope that it does spend it more wisely than it has spent many of the other extra taxes that have been garnished from the Australian people over the last few years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988, which has arrived after much delay. Honourable senators may remember that it was supposed to have been operative as from 1 November 1988. The only problem was that the Government did not do its homework and ascertain whether it was acceptable to the majority of the Senate, hence the delay. The biggest push to make sure that it was not another Australia Card, which was totally rejected by the Senate last year, came from Western Australia. As a result of the good work done by the hierarchy of our Party to make sure that this was not a pseudo-Australia Card, we now have legislation that should be acceptable to most Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Originally I considered it intrusive and offensive and it did not fulfil its supposed purpose. It was another Australia Card, with the same objectionable aims and hidden agenda. The agenda was to pry into the lives of Australians at large, while at the same time not attacking areas such as tax cheating and tax dodging where the Government should have been cracking down. Under this Bill, it will now not be compulsory for a taxpayer to supply a tax file number. It will need to be supplied to an employer only if the taxpayer wishes to be taxed at his marginal rate. If the employee chooses not to supply the number he will pay tax at the top rate, with the addition of the Medicare levy. At the end of the financial year, on filing a tax return the taxpayer will receive a refund, if there is one.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many people do you think will be able to afford to do that?

—Not too many. I agree that not too many will be able to afford it. In the case of interest bearing deposits in bank accounts, a depositor, if he chooses not to disclose his tax file number, once again will pay the withholding tax of 49c plus the Medicare levy, which works out at about 50.25c in the dollar. Once again, any overpayment would be refunded on filing a tax return. Should a person who deposits money in an interest bearing account not supply a tax file number, at least he will pay the withholding tax. In other words, if someone is not playing the game and has a vast amount of money in an interest bearing account it will be picked up. Of course, as Senator Haines said, there are many people who cannot afford not to supply the number, and if they have to supply a number someone else knows it.

SPEECH.PARA: What worries me is that, believe it or not, there are taxpayers who legally hold more than one tax file number.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite a lot hold them illegally.

—Yes, there may be many who hold them illegally but there are also many who hold them legally. A person may have a personal tax file number; he may be in partnership with his wife and have a number for that; he may have another tax file number for a partnership with another person; and he may have another for a company. So it is possible to have quite a few legally. Senator Maguire said yesterday that anyone with more than one tax file number is a criminal. That is certainly not correct.
—What about all those people who are running two identities and will have two tax file numbers? How is this going to pick them up?

—I will come to that later on. What worries me are the ones who quite legally have more than one tax file number. I think page 21 of the explanatory memorandum deals with that. I cannot see anywhere in the legislation where it says they do not have to go through that process. It seems to me that those who already have a number and who are doing the right thing in paying their tax and at the end of the year filing their tax return-unless someone can point out that I am wrong-still have to go through the same process and get themselves a tax file number. Getting a tax file number is not just a matter of writing to the Australian Taxation Office or filling in a return and the Commissioner of Taxation giving someone a number, even if it is a person's first return, whether early or late in life. He or she has to go through a certain procedure by going to the local post office. For instance, a natural person would be asked to provide two different category A documents plus one category B document or three different category B documents. One of those documents is an Australian birth certificate, which I suppose is fair enough. At least the local postmaster will know how old someone's wife is. Others could be a current Australian passport, a degree, a curriculum vitae and all that sort of thing. I think it is an invasion of privacy for one's local postmaster to know how well or how badly someone has done in a university course. In other words, everyone has to go through the procedure even though he or she has been playing the game all along.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the case of the Government interfering with systems that are already working properly. One system that was introduced some years ago that is working properly is the prescribed payments system. Page 13 of the explanatory memorandum tells us, amongst other things:

At present, where a payee fails to quote a TFN to a payer under the Prescribed Payments System, the rate of deduction is calculated at 30 per cent, double the applicable deduction where a TFN is quoted. From a date to be proclaimed, non-quotation of a TFN by a payee on a deduction form will result in a deduction of 50.25 per cent being made from the prescribed payment.

On my understanding that forces everybody who is subcontracting to supply a tax file number to a prime contractor. One would have to unless one had a mint of money. Taxation already takes out about 15 per cent from a payment for a contract, and that is most of the profit for that job. If that figure goes anywhere near 50 per cent, the Government will be taking not only the profit but also the working capital, which is being used to pay for materials et cetera. So if the subcontractor has 50 per cent or so ripped out, and he is probably paying his Medicare levy elsewhere anyhow, he will have no working capital left. No-one can tell me that this legislation does not force everyone to use a tax file number, even though this legislation says it is totally voluntary.

I take this opportunity to say that this legislation does not attack the areas it should. The first area I mention is the black economy. I believe most people accept that there is a black economy in Australia, something, incidentally, that this Government has done nothing about. This Bill will not be able to attack it either. It will not be able to attack the payment of employees or subcontractors, or whatever one can think of, being taken out of the till. The only way some employers in the hospitality, entertainment and other trades can get casual employees is by paying them out of the till. I do not know what the solution is, except that the Australian tax rate as a whole is too high and that is probably the reason why the black economy continues. As I say, the legislation fails to address the black economy in any way whatsoever.

The Bill does not attack the use of false names-a point made, I think, by Senator Haines. Of course, false names are used to defraud the social security system as well. The legislation certainly does not attack that fraud. It does not attack the problem of large amounts of money deposited in cheque accounts which do not earn interest. I gather that when opening a cheque account one will not have to provide one's tax file number. The legislation also does not seem to me to attack the problem of large amounts of money held in solicitors' trust funds. That matter is addressed on page 32 of the explanatory memorandum where it is stated:

A deposit of money with a solicitor (a defined term . . .) to be either invested by the solicitor or to be lent under an agreement to be arranged by or on behalf of the solicitor is included in the investments to which new Part Va applies.

As I see it, if a person has a large amount of money in a solicitor's trust fund but has not instructed the solicitor either to invest it or to lend it under an agreement, that situation does not appear to be covered by the legislation.

I turn now to the use of multiple bank accounts. This procedure has been used in the past by certain taxpayers to dodge their responsibilities. This Government has chosen now to limit to $120 the amount of interest that can be earned each year on bank accounts before investors have to provide their tax file numbers. I believe that in the case of children that amount of interest can be up to $420 or thereabouts. That matter is addressed on page 67 of the explanatory memorandum. I do not know how this will be policed. I do not know how the Australian Taxation Office can in any way prevent the breaking down of single accounts into multiple accounts to ensure that investors always earn a bit less interest than the maximum. By my quick calculation, one would need about $1,100 in an investment account to earn $120 interest in a year, at today's interest rates. One would need much more money in a passbook account which earns interest at only 4 per cent per annum. One would need about $2,700 in such an account. One could have a multiplicity of such accounts either in different banks or, indeed, in the same bank but in different branches. I cannot see how this legislation proposes to attack that problem. There is an attempt to cover it, and on page 67 of the explanatory memorandum under the heading `Conducting affairs so as to avoid file number requirements' it is stated that the intent is:

. . . to prohibit persons from structuring their investments to exploit interest thresholds proposed for pre-existing accounts with banks, building societies or credit unions . . . and certain investments of children . . .

This proposed new section applies in situations in which it would be `reasonable to conclude' that a person had structured an investment. How on earth will the Taxation Office decide that? How can it really trace those accounts? The Government should be dinkum in its intention to cover everyone and treat everyone fairly, regardless of whether they are millionaires or ordinary people trying to restructure their accounts to avoid taxation. People should be treated equally. If the Government were dinkum, it would have recommended a start from a nil balance, where any interest is gathered.

I have already covered casual employment, where most of the rorts in tax avoidance are going on. The Government has been very slack in attacking the black economy. Government supporters always call people on this side of politics friends of the tax cheats, but the Government is willing, as it has been for some time, to let the defrauding of the Department of Social Security go on and on, and it is doing nothing to stop it.

Some Government speakers last evening bore out what I have believed all along about this Bill, and that is that it will be the foot in the door for a future Australian ID card-while this Government is in power, anyway. The overall cost of the set-up will hardly make it worth while for what the Government is attempting to get. Whatever the cost will be, will it be worth while for what will be received? We are told that we will recover $3.3 billion over the next 10 years, which works out at about $330m a year.

The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have been running around the countryside over the last six months saying that if this Bill were not passed, once again we would be branded as the friends of the tax cheats. They further said that they may not be able to deliver next year's tax cuts, and that is probably about the third or fourth excuse for not delivering next year's tax cuts. We all know that they are not going to come or, if they come, they will come on a reduced basis whereby only a few people will benefit-mainly supporters of the other side and at a time when the next election is coming up.

The saving of $330m per year will hardly make up for the tax cuts that were promised in the first place-but that figure is coming down vastly as the days go on, and I understand that financing tax cuts will require $3 billion to $4 billion per year. As I said before, with a lot of work on this side of politics in pressuring the Government and negotiating with the Government to make this into better legislation, the main thrust was on the Privacy Bill. By ensuring that it was debated and passed through this House at the same time and came into effect on exactly the same date, we were able to give it our support. As everyone knows by now, the Opposition supports the legislation. Although I had strong reservations in the first place, as did most Western Australians, we are now behind the legislation, and through this Bill we hope the Government will be able to do something to overcome the tax cheating that is going on and get itself off our backs with its continual branding of us as friends of tax cheats.

Yesterday we had another serving from Senator Coates about how we have been doing that and how well the Government did by bringing in fringe benefits tax, and he talked about people bringing sandwiches in a brown paper bag for lunch. However, what the senator totally ignores every time, is the damage that fringe benefits tax has done in the remote areas, where various fringe benefits or housing must be provided to enable the jobs to be filled. If anyone does not believe me they should visit the country areas of Western Australia where the mining boom is really showing what Australia can do in that field. It is keeping Australia afloat.

TALK.START.PARA: —All those new taxes haven't exactly produced lower taxes.

—Certainly, those new taxes have not brought down the general thrust of tax. Taxes are only going up further and the Government is looking at more tax to come on. If the Government gets the help of the Australian Democrats there will be a corporate tax on gold which will be strongly defended by us.
—That's good. I am glad you are going to defend it. Finally, gold should pay its proper tax.

—Senator McKiernan should go to the country areas of Western Australia and give those people the same story he gave when he came to Merredin and told the farmers that it was going to rain next year. They worked out how much he knew about farming. If he tells that to the goldminers they will know what he knows about gold mining.
—And it did rain.

—It may have rained but Senator McKiernan should not tell me that he knew it was going to rain. He should tell his supporters in Kalgoorlie that fact and see how many supporters he will have left. What worries me is that with the help of our side of politics this Bill is going to go through. I have fears that it is going to be another Australia Card. Any small thing like this is generally a foot in the door. However, any attempt by the Government to sidestep or expand the provisions of this Bill or to further intrude into personal dealings of people or to accumulate data will be monitored. The main thing I am worried about is the accumulation of data. Plenty of my colleagues have pointed out-and the Democrats have pointed this out in debate-that it will certainly be rejected by our side of politics in time to come. It will not only incur the wrath of this Parliament but the wrath of the total nation because the nation has not forgotten what this Government tried to do to it last year in bringing forward the Australia Card legislation. We will make sure that it does not happen in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988 and the Privacy Bill 1988. Honourable senators will be aware that the former Bill is the Government's response to the failure last year of the Australia Card legislation. The Privacy Bill is an updated version of the Bill which was introduced with the Australia Card legislation in 1986 in an effort to seduce the public into accepting the ID card. It should be stated at the outset that the Government's updated tax file number (TFN) system must be accepted for what it is. It is a numbering system. It is an identifier. But because it is a system of identification there is a very real concern amongst the community that the tax file number will amount to a de facto ID card. Once introduced into Australia governments will find it hard to resist the temptation to expand its scope and to encompass transactions it was not originally meant to regulate.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also concerned about comments to the effect that the system is now, in all respects, voluntary. I have some difficulty with this notion, given the pecuniary penalties involved in not quoting one's tax file number. I suggest that the system operate with the assistance of a certain amount of compulsion. Further, certain aspects of the privacy legislation are unsatisfactory and fall short of the minimum standards recommended in 1980 by the organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development guidelines and protection of privacy and trans-border flows of personal data. My major concern with the legislation is that, in practice, the TFN system may quickly become another Australia Card-a universal identifier. It is for that reason that the coalition has gone to the great lengths that it has to negotiate with the Government a number of changes to the Bills to ensure that a back door ID card will not be introduced.

Overseas experience in particular demonstrates that legislation of this kind, even if originally limited in scope and intent, will quickly escalate to cover the fields of human transactions and dealings. The Australian Privacy Council calls this `function creep'; that is, `a substantial confinement of the uses of the identification system to taxation purposes is a constraint which will be eroded by the incremental addition of functions for which the tax file number will become an essential adjunct'.

This concern with `function creep' was reflected in the additional term of reference (b) given to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs when the Committee was requested to report on the `possibility of the scheme developing into a de facto national identification card system with unacceptable imposition being made upon privacy and civil liberties'. It was on that point that the Committee noted the Canadian experience with a social insurance number (SIN) and the United States social security number. In each case the number was introduced originally for a very limited purpose. The Canadian system was to assist the administration of an unemployment insurance scheme and the United States social security number was introduced to number accounts for persons who fell within the Act. Honourable senators will be aware that the use of the SIN in Canada reached the farcical stage where it was required for application for participation in the annual wild goose hunt. The Canadians have now realised that the SIN was being used as a universal identifier and are taking steps to dismantle many of its uses. The Hawke Government's TFN system could easily follow the same path. It is clear that the TFN was intended as a replacement for the Australia Card.

The Government announced on 30 September last year that it would seek to introduce a high integrity tax file numbering system, continue with its Cash Transaction Reports Bill and develop a national register of births, deaths and marriages. It is clear that, in principle, the TFN has many of the hallmarks of the Australia Card. The major differences are that there will be no card and a tax file number will not be issued to the entire population. The objects of the TFN legislation are contained in proposed section 202 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The first object of the use of a tax file number is:
to increase the effectiveness and efficiency of the matching of information contained in reports given to the Commissioner . . . with information disclosed in income tax returns . . .

It is proposed that income matching within the Australian Taxation Office will be the only role of the TFN. However, the Department of Social Security will be collecting tax file numbers for the Taxation Office in relation to unemployment and sickness benefits. The third object contained in proposed section 202 provides that the TFN will be used:
to facilitate the administration of any legisl- ation . . . under which benefits are provided by the Commonwealth to students in relation to . . . higher education . . .

It also appears that the Tax Office will be using TFNs for the purpose of administering the child support scheme. As the legislation now stands, the use of TFNs is restricted to the Taxation Office. Under proposed subdivision Ba of part IV of the Taxation Administration Act 1953, it is an offence for a person to require the recording of a TFN unless provision is made by or under a taxation law or a law relating to the higher education charge. However, it would not be difficult to imagine the seductive influence the use of TFNs would have for the Department of Social Security, for example. Presently, the Department of Social Security will act as any other employer in collecting TFNs in relation to unemployment and sickness benefits. The Senate Standing Committee noted at paragraph 9.54 that other indirect benefits will flow to the Department from the TFN. In evidence to the Committee, Mr Murphy of the Department gave an example concerning a person receiving family allowance while being paid unemployment benefit. Mr Murphy stated:

We will report the taxation file number of those people for unemployment benefit purposes but if we wanted to ask information about confirming taxable income for family allowance purposes we would not use the number because we are precluded from doing so.

As I said, it is not hard to imagine the Department of Social Security wanting additional access to tax file numbers. If granted, function creep will have begun and the TFN will be on the way to becoming a universal identifier with which we are all concerned. The Parliament and the people of Australia have a duty to be vigilant to ensure that governments of the day, particularly centralist governments, do not give in to the desire to extend the use of the TFN system.

I have some difficulty with the claim that the TFN system is now no threat to privacy because it is voluntary. The option exists for people not to quote their tax file number if they do not so wish. Under amendments to the Income Tax Regulations, however, a penalty must be paid for this privilege. This penalty is to be in the form of a withholding tax at the top marginal rate-that is, 50.25c in the dollar-plus the Medicare levy. This is the amount an employer will be required to withdraw from an employee's pay packet in respect of any given week's work.

Of course, this situation is far better than that which has existed previously. It is no longer an offence, for example, for persons not to quote their tax file number when required. Further, the original proposal of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to prohibit the withdrawal or transfer of funds from interest bearing accounts with financial institutions has now been scrapped. These and other concessions have been extracted from the Government by the coalition.

To say, however, that the system is now voluntary is, in my view, to overstate the situation. I ask honourable senators to consider how voluntary it is for ordinary Australian wage earners currently paying tax at a marginal rate of 29c in the dollar or 40c in the dollar plus the Medicare levy to be suddenly faced with deductions being made at the rate of 50.25c in the dollar simply because they wish, on principle, not to quote their tax file number. I suggest that, however much these Australians might have a fundamental objection to having to quote their tax file number and however much they want to stand firm on their principles, it is inevitable for economic reasons that their principles will run a distant second to having sufficient money to feed, clothe and educate their families. For these people, the non-quotation of their tax file number is simply not an option. For these people, the system is far from voluntary. Yet I am sure that it is these people, perhaps more than any other group in the community, who would feel the most resentment against any tax file number system.

The perception of losing one's identity and rights is strongly felt amongst ordinary wage and salary earners. These individuals are no doubt very concerned at what they see as a centralist government taking away their inherent rights and replacing them with a series of rights granted to them by the prevailing government and its bureaucracy. In my mind there is no better demonstration of this concern than the recent referendum, in which 70 per cent of Australian voters rejected question No. 4, which sought to enshrine certain rights in the Constitution. Further, I recall Senator Puplick on the original Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card saying that, at least to his mind, there was a grave concern on the part of Australians that we were reverting from being a common law society to a civil law society-in other words, we were gradually losing our inherent rights and having them replaced by granted rights.

Professor Martyn Webb of the organisation People Against the Australia Card made the point in evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on 20 July this year that the fact that the Government's proposed system involved numbering was not of itself the problem. In response to a question from the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Cooney, who asked him whether he saw the number itself as a problem, Professor Webb said:
No, not the number alone; it is the use to which that number is put and the compulsion that lies behind it.
Professor Webb went on to say:
. . . once you have adopted that position, you can find better solutions than the upgraded tax file number.
In this regard I note the addendum to the Standing Committee's report, written by Senators Alston and Hill, in which they stated:
On the evidence put to the Committee we are not satisfied that other less intrusive methods do not exist.
The honourable senators went further and said:
Indeed, we express disappointment at the cursory manner in which alternative approaches were treated in the ATO (Australian Taxation Office) submission.

Senators Hill and Alston made the point that an income matching facility had already been developed by the Australian Taxation Office which was capable of further significant upgrading with the consequential benefits to revenue and without the necessity of a new tax file number scheme.

Indeed, in July this year the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, stated that the Tax Office had received additional revenue of $2.4 billion over the last financial year as a result of increased recovery of evaded tax. To me, this suggests that the Commissioner already has extensive powers at his disposal to deal with tax evasion which would allow, to a great extent, the elimination of abuses in the taxation system. Examples of these powers are the 100 tax audit `hit' teams which the Commissioner let loose on the corporate world after recent improved auditing procedures had increased collections. The Commissioner estimates that these audit teams will net $315m a year.

As I said, the Taxation Office has sufficient powers under the Income Tax Assessment Act already. These powers are only now being tested in terms of scope and I would have thought a numbering system would be less than necessary until it is discovered exactly what limits are imposed on the Tax Office's existing investigation and recovery powers.

My final comments relate to the Privacy Bill 1988. As I said previously, this Bill is an updated version of the one which appeared in conjunction with the Australia Card Bill in 1986. The present Bill generally retains the 11 information privacy principles (IPPs) of the 1986 Bill, although with some amendments. These privacy principles are based on guidelines recommended by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) on 23 September 1980 as a result of a working group chaired by Mr Justice Michael Kirby. The OECD guidelines are expressed to be `basic principles of national application' and should be regarded as `minimum standards' for the protection of privacy and individual liberty.

As well as the information privacy principles contained in the Bill, clause 17 provides that the Commissioner shall issue guidelines concerning the collection, storage, use and security of tax file number information. Interim guidelines are contained in schedule 2 of the Bill. An interference with the privacy of an individual occurs when an IPP or a guideline issued under clause 17 is breached.

It is unfortunate that the information privacy principles in the Bill do not at least reach the minimum standards for the protection of privacy as declared by the OECD and as recommended by the Senate Standing Committee. Of course, the state of protection afforded by the Bill is far better than it was prior to the acceptance by the Government of a number of coalition amendments. Without these amendments, the Privacy Bill would have been totally inadequate for providing privacy to individuals from the use of the tax file number system. As a result of coalition recommendations, the Bill now provides for guidelines to be issued for the collecting, storage and use of tax file numbers. Defects, of course, remain.

Primarily, the Government has not seen fit to provide a right to sue for breach of an IPP or a clause 17 guideline. I urge the Senate to support the coalition amendment in this regard. Defects also exist in the privacy principles themselves. For example, the first three IPPs deal with the collection of personal information. The major defect is that a collector of information is under no obligation to inform an individual that information has been collected where that information is collected from third parties. The explanatory memorandum states:

The right of the individual concerned to be made aware of personal information supplied by a third party to an agency is catered for in IPPs 5 and 6 requiring information to be made available by agencies about records held by record-keepers and means of access to those records.

Of course, that is just not good enough. It is clear that, if individuals are not in fact aware that information about them has been collected, they have no reason to contact recordkeepers with a view to ascertaining whether or not personal information which concerns them is being held. The OECD and the Australian Law Reform Commission were both of the opinion that information should be collected with the knowledge or consent of the data subject.

Further, although IPP 1 prohibits the collection by a collector of information by unlawful or unfair means, there is no such limitation when information is collected by a collector from third parties who have obtained that information by unfair or unlawful means. IPP 2, which deals with the solicitation of personal information, also does not attain the standard required by the OECD purpose specification principle. The OECD guideline stresses that individuals should be informed of the purpose for which data is collected no later than the time of collection. IPP 2, however, requires that, if it is not practicable to do so prior to the time of collection, the collector need only make the information available to the person `as soon as practicable after the information is collected'.

It must be a fundamental right of the individual to know for what purpose information is collected and where it will be put. The decision whether to supply the information required may well depend on the purpose for which the information is to be used.

Paragraph (e) of the same principle also imposes an obligation on the collector to inform the individual of any person, `body or agency to which it is the collector's usual practice to disclose' the information. There is, however, no such requirement to inform the individual where disclosure is to be made to, for want of a better word, unusual agencies. I would have thought that informing the individual would have certainly been more important in the latter case. Indeed, it is a matter of some concern that the clause seems to indicate that the collector may not even know the final destination of the personal information collected.
