IPP 3 is similar to the OECD's data quality principle, which requires that information be `accurate, complete and kept up to date'. Principle 3, however, omits the requirement of accuracy. I am aware that IPPs 7 and 8 impose the duty of accuracy on record keepers. However, I would have thought that when personal information is actually collected, a standard of accuracy ought to be imposed. I note that the Standing Committee is not in agreement with me on this point. However, I cannot be persuaded, on the evidence that I have read, that in any way my position is not tenable. The Committee stated:
An obligation to ensure accuracy at the time of collection would be impracticable, particularly where information was not solicited from the person to whom it related.

Given, however, that the obligation imposed by principle 3 is for the collector to take `such steps (if any) as are, in the circumstances, reasonable', I suggest that this is sufficient to ensure that any duty of accuracy is not unduly onerous.

Finally, I want to raise briefly an issue in relation to privacy principles 6 and 7, which deal with access to and alteration of records of personal information. These provisions are based on the OECD's individual participation principle and basically confirm but do not extend the rights of access and amendment contained in the Freedom of Information Act 1983. As a general comment, I have doubts as to whether the freedom of information approach which extends `the right of the Australian community to access to the information in the possession of the Government'-as contained in section 3 of the Act-is appropriate to provide a person with access to that individual's personal information. In this regard, I note that the Standing Committee has recommended that:

. . . provisions for the amendment of records containing personal information, including provisions regarding the adding of notations to such records, be included in privacy legislation . . . rather than the FOI Act.

I am of the opinion that an individual about whom personal information has been collected has the fundamental right to ensure that the information is accurate and, if not, to require the record to be amended accordingly. I am concerned to ensure that the tax file number system does not operate to trample upon the rights and liberties of individual Australians. Equally, I urge the support of all honourable senators for the coalition's amendments to ensure that the privacy legislation, to be effective, will protect just that-that is, privacy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall reply very briefly on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill and Senator Tate will reply on the Privacy Bill. I do not want to say very much other than to express the Government's and my own gratification, I suppose, that the Opposition, with a couple of amendments, has decided to support the Bill, and to say that the Government will not be accepting the amendment to the motion for the second reading moved by the Australian Democrats, which seeks an alternative system. The reason the Government will not accept it is that the alternative system which had been proposed by the Democrats does not entail the use of a unique number and, therefore, would not be entirely effective even for banking transactions and bank interest and, more importantly, that employers do not number their employees at all, let alone number them in a unique way. It would therefore be inefficient per se; that is, it would not achieve the objectives as thoroughly as the Bill will do and would also be more expensive to administer. We will be opposing that amendment. Otherwise, I do not propose to delay the passage of the Bill any longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Privacy Bill is a matter within my responsibility in this cognate debate. I first say how constructive and helpful the conversations that I had with Mr Neil Brown, the shadow Attorney-General, were in coming up with a proposal for this chamber to vote on which I believe is properly characterised as a very great advance indeed in the protection of privacy of those Australians who find themselves in a relationship with a Commonwealth agency to which information is given concerning the particular individual and in relation to the provision of tax file numbers, both to relevant Commonwealth agencies and persons, institutions or firms within the private sector such as employers or financial institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, the Bill as it is now presented to this chamber incorporates many improvements to a basic structure which will now ensure that the privacy of Australians is well safeguarded. In relation to that huge flow of information which is made available to Commonwealth agencies, there will be in force 11 information privacy principles. Those information privacy principles cover a wide range of matters, ranging from `Manner and purpose of collection of personal information' through to `Limits on disclosure of personal information'. I am quoting there from the heading to information privacy principle 1 and then information privacy principle 11. Between those two principles one finds a very comprehensive regime indeed to ensure that, if observed, interference with the privacy of individuals is either avoided altogether or fully justified by reference to other important competing social principles.

If the privacy of an individual is interfered with by reason of an act or practice engaged in by an agency breaching those information privacy principles, then remedial action can be taken and the primary objective of such remedial action is to do away with that particular act or practice in such a way that the bureaucracy functions in accordance with those information privacy principles; that is, in a way which is properly conscious of the need to safeguard the privacy of those many individuals who come into contact with the particular agency.

The role of the Privacy Commissioner will, as has been commented on by many senators, be of crucial importance and, indeed, the status, integrity and independence of that Privacy Commissioner will be very crucial. I believe that that appointment will be the key to the success of this legislation. In particular, in those instances where the Privacy Commissioner determines that what would otherwise be an interference with the privacy of an individual should not be regarded as a breach, with all the consequences under the Act, but is justified by a substantial competing public interest, I think that that sort of role indicates the very important part which the Privacy Commissioner will play. But even there the Parliament retains ultimate control because such an overruling of the normal operation of the Act will be disallowable by this Parliament.

It was in relation to the role of the Parliament in relation to the devising of the principles and guidelines which should protect the privacy of individuals that the major discussion between myself and the Opposition took place. In regard to the tax file number information which is provided by an individual-for example, to an employer or to a financial institution-it had been the intention of the Government that the Privacy Commissioner should create those particular guidelines after taking advice, particularly from an advisory committee which would be composed of persons with expertise but able, obviously, to draw on a wide range of consultation, particularly with the private sector, so that the guidelines which emerge not only serve the purpose of safeguarding the privacy of individuals but are not unduly onerous, in a regulatory sense, of the private sector upon which they are imposed. However, the Opposition and, to be frank, many members of my own Party felt that it would be better for the Parliament itself to at least elaborate on the guidelines which should apply from the very commencement of the operation of this privacy legislation; in other words, we should see the colour, the nature, the scope and the types of guidelines that the Parliament envisages should be applicable to the protection and the erecting of further safeguards and barriers in regard to tax file number information. Indeed, that is what has been done in schedule 2 to the Bill before us, which has as its primary focus paragraph 1.1, which proclaims:
The tax file number is not to be used as a national identification system by whatever means.

That particular heading really governs the various guidelines which are then set out in relation to the collection of tax file number information, its storage and security and the guidelines which should govern its use and disclosure, its publicity, and certain matters that should follow on the cessation of employment or an investment, and so on. All of this is supplementary and further safeguard to the very onerous and stringent provisions contained in the tax file number legislation, which, by way of imposing very severe penalties, indicates the intention of this Parliament that there should be no use, disclosure or request for tax file number information which is not strictly required and provided for under the relevant legislation.

The Privacy Bill now provides a very interesting mechanism for this Parliament to ensure that the guidelines relating to tax file number information are adequate for the better securing of that privacy. The guidelines in schedule 2 will be interim guidelines. The Privacy Commissioner will undertake the task which I outlined as the Government's first option. After consultation, he or she will provide those guidelines in a way which the Parliament can then consider. Only if those new guidelines are not disallowed within the appropriate number of sitting days will they come into operation and displace, to the extent that they should, the interim guidelines in schedule 2. In other words, at all stages this Parliament, and particularly this chamber, will have an opportunity to ensure that the guidelines relating to the protection of the privacy of tax file number information is indeed adequate.

There are many other matters which I could touch on, but it is the wish of the chamber that the committee stage consideration of these Bills take place as soon as possible. In order to facilitate that, I will conclude my remarks. Finally, I believe that this exercise has been a very good example of the constructive work that can be done with quite contentious legislation if those sorts of discussions which did transpire are allowed to take place away from the glare and drama of public confrontation. In the Bills before us we see emerging a very good example of the parliamentary process working well.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Haines's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the Committee that the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988 and the Privacy Bill 1988 be considered separately? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

INTERJECT.PARA: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (TAX FILE NUMBERS) BILL 1988
Clauses 1 to 5-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation, as it is currently drafted, requires that individuals who are employed or who undertake investments of some sort with a financial institution, such as a bank, building society and so on, quote their tax file number as well as, of course, other details that are relevant to that institution. So somebody who starts employment or, as of next April, somebody who is in employment will be required to give his or her tax file number to that employer, and the same thing is going to apply to those people who undertake investments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has made much of the deal that it claims it has done with the Government, which finally persuaded it to support the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill and the Privacy Bill in toto. The Opposition claims that what it has done is to introduce an element of non-compulsion to the legislation, so that people will not be forced to give their tax file number to a range of employers, financial institutions and so on in the community, thereby laying the foundation for a centralised database that can be used in a year or two to implement a national identification system. However, the deal that was done between the Opposition and the Australian Labor Party on this is not a deal that is going to give much joy to many people in this country. Senator Panizza admitted this in reply to an interjection of mine during his speech at the second reading stage. Because whilst it is no longer going to be an offence punishable by a fine or a goal term not to quote the tax file number to the range of people listed in the legislation, there will still be, and there properly should be, a sanction. That sanction is that the individual who does not quote a tax file number will suffer a 50.25c in the dollar tax deduction.

I am not clear whether that starts from $1 or from the tax free threshold, but I presume it starts from $1. It is in fact giving no choice to the great majority of people. People on $100,000 or $150,000 a year, or the squillions that people such as John Elliott and Alan Bond are paid, can probably afford not to hand over their tax file number to their bank managers, investment advisers, stockbrokers, employers and so on, because they can afford to pay 50.25c in the dollar and then put in a tax return at the end of the year claiming overassessment and having that returned. But it is that level of people who will be helped by this deal that was done between the Labor Party and the Opposition that persuaded the Opposition to support this piece of legislation outright.

Nobody on average weekly earnings-indeed, I would not have thought there were too many people on even $30,000 or $40,000 a year, much less people on average weekly earnings and less-is in a position to take advantage of this so-called choice element. Somebody who is earning $22,000 a year, who has a dependent spouse and perhaps two or three children, is not going to be able to afford to lose $11,000 in tax. Even if he does get it back at the end of the year, he will starve first.

The amendments that we will be moving to clause 6 are certainly amendments I would have preferred not to be moving. The Australian Democrats would prefer to be in the position where this legislation had not even got this far, that governments had looked at some other way of recouping the $200m that they claim is being lost, the 26c per week per taxpayer that is being lost. But we are dealing with clause 6. I now seek leave formally to move both amendments to clause 6 in the name of the Australian Democrats which deal with two major elements of the legislation.
Leave granted.
Seantor HAINES-I move:
(1) Page 10, clause 6, after proposed section 202ce, add the following new section in division 3:
Tax file number declaration made by employees directly to Commissioner

``202cf (1) A person who, on or after the first day of the phasing-in period for this Division, becomes an employee of another person may, not later than 30 days after the day on which the person becomes such an employee:
(a) inform, in writing, the office of a Deputy Commissioner of the person's tax file number and the name and address of the person's employer; or

(b) where the person does not know his or her tax file number, inform, in writing, the office of a Deputy Commissioner of that circumstance and the name and address of the person's employer, and request that the person be informed of the number.

``(2) A person who informs the office of a Deputy Commissioner of his or her tax file number or requests that he or she be informed of the number, in accordance with subsection (1), shall be taken to have stated his or her number in an affective employment declaration for the purposes of this Part, provided that the person informs the employer, in writing, that he or she has written to the office of a Deputy Commissioner in accordance with subsection (1).''.
(2) Page 14, clause 6, after proposed section 202dg, add the following new section in division 4:
Tax file number declarations made by investors directly to Commissioner

``202dh (1) A person who, at any time after the beginning of the phasing-in period for this Division, is an investor in relation to an investment to which this Part applies may, not later than 30 days after:
(a) the beginning of the phasing-in period; or
(b) the day on which the person became such an investor,
whichever is the later,
(c) inform, in writing, the office of a Deputy Commissioner of the person's tax file number and the name and address of the investment body; or

(d) where the person does not know his or her tax file number, inform, in writing, the office of a Deputy Commissioner of that circumstance and the name and address of the investment body, and request that the person be informed of the number.

``(2) A person who informs the office of a Deputy Commissioner of his or her tax file number or requests that he or she is informed of the number, in accordance with subsection (1), shall be taken to have quoted the number in connection with an investment for the purposes of this Part, provided that the person informs the investment body, in writing, that he or she has written to the office of a Deputy Commissioner in accordance with subsection (1).

``(3) Where, after the beginning of the phasing-in period for this Division, a person becomes an investor as a result of a transaction carried out through a securities dealer, the securities dealer shall be regarded as an investment body for the purposes of the proviso in subsection (2).''.

My amendments to clause 6 attempt to achieve a genuine element of choice while still ensuring that this triumvirate that the Government is concentrating on continues to exist and that people are held to account. The triumvirate I refer to is, of course, the individual concerned, the institution concerned and the Australian Taxation Office. The Government's legislation, connived at with the support of the Opposition, insists that there be no flexibility within that three tiered system. The individual must give the tax file number to the institution. The institution, with the approval of the Australian Taxation Office, then takes out tax at whatever the set marginal rate is for that individual's wage or salary. What we are saying is that there are some people in the community who resent the fact that this proposal will lead to a national identification system. These people want the confidentially that has always existed in this country between the taxpayer and the Taxation Office to remain. By the same token these people do not believe that they deserve to be dragooned either into citing their tax file number or paying over half their salary in tax.

What we have suggested is this: give people a genuine option. Those people who do not mind declaring their tax file number to all and sundry can do so; that is their decision. It is a real decision if they are making it without compulsion. Give those people who do not want to give the tax file number to the institution, the employer, the bank, or any other institution the option to talk to the Taxation Office. Our proposed amendments allow any person who, on or after, the first day of the phasing-in period of this legislation, becomes an employee to inform the Australian Taxation Office in writing of the relevant details within 30 days of that employment. That is not so difficult to put in place. It certainly is an improvement on the so-called choice that the Opposition was conned into accepting-a choice which is only for very high income earners.

The proposed amendments will ensure that the taxpayer, the employer, the bank or whatever, and the Taxation Office, know that everything is above board. Does it matter whether that information goes A to B to C or whether it goes from A to C to B, for goodness sake? The three tiers are all involved. All the information is cleared by the Taxation Office. We are not allowing people to enter into little arrangements with employers, as currently happens, particularly in some service industries in which people are paid less than award rates and do not pay tax because they give false names. I have every sympathy for the Government wanting to recoup the proper amount of tax but I deeply resent the Government imposing on low income earners a system that it is not imposing on high income earners.

This type of social division is something that we have never seen legitimated in the statutes of this country. We have certainly got plenty of inequities and plenty of divisions. But this is the first time I can remember in which two main political parties have sat down and come to an arrangement whereby they divide people into low income earners and high income earners and put a form of compulsion on one group that does not apply to the other. For heaven's sake what has gone wrong with this place? I thought it was bad enough that a week ago I had to listen to Senator Messner say that the Opposition could not support us in taking the sales tax off a couple of items that were intended for use by children with disabilities, because that would have imposed unnecessary restrictions on the Government's revenue raising, and then three days later say that it will oppose the Government's gold tax. That sort of idiocy is bad enough but then to write into the statute books two classes of income earners in this country-low and high income earners, one of which is compelled to do something that the other is not-is quite extraordinary.

The amendments I have circulated look complicated. They are not. Their complexity arises from the need to deal with a number of different areas because the legislation covers not just employers as institutions but also banks, building societies and other areas in which investments can take place. Therefore the amendments in effect say that people should have the choice of giving their tax file numbers to institutions or contacting the Australian Taxation Office within 30 days. The amendments run to 3 1/2 pages because they deal with all those clauses in the original legislation dealing with those sorts of investment and income earning areas. I certainly hope that the Opposition parties can see their way clear to giving a real option to low income earners; the same option that they have negotiated with the Government to give to high income earners.

In conclusion, amendment No. 1 to clause 6 deals with tax file number declarations made by employees with regard to employment. Amendment No. 2 deals with declarations made by investors to those organisations that people use to invest what little money they currently have left.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the benefits of the amendments moved by Senator Haines relates to another Bill. When Senator Messner spoke in the second reading debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill he said that the tax file number would deal with social security fraud, welfare cheats and taxation cheats. By way of interjection I referred to another Bill which is presently before the House of Representatives, that is the Higher Education Funding Bill, imposing charges on higher education students. Later on in the debate Senator Michael Baume claimed that the Opposition's amendment had achieved a totally voluntary situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's proposal cannot apply to the Bill to impose charges on those people undertaking higher education. It is simply not possible to apply it to a charge on students which is, in fact, a loan. This is how the Government is dealing with the constitutional problem of the benefits. It can be applied when a person is earning income on which tax has to be paid. It can be applied to interest earned on money in bank accounts.

The benefit of our approach is that it works in all areas. It imposes the obligation on the person involved. I wonder whether the Opposition is of a mind to limit the exercise purely to those situations described by Senator Messner. If it is we would look forward to Opposition support in defeating the Higher Education Funding Bill when it comes in here from the House of Representatives. However, I believe that that will not be the case. The Government and the Opposition will combine on that exercise so that there will be compulsion on some groups of people to disclose their tax file numbers to others. I believe that people will not have the opportunity not to do so under the method devised by the Opposition. It had a very limited view of where the tax file number will be used. I think, in fact, it is attempting to con the electorate as to where the tax file number is to be used because it was in agreement with the Government that it would be used in as many areas as it could possibly be used in. The fact that the Government, at the same time as it was negotiating with the Opposition, was preparing to introduce a Bill, which was introduced immediately the Government had the Opposition's agreement whereby the tax file number system would be compulsory for certain groups of people, shows that the Opposition was either incredibly naive or simply attempting yet again to mislead the electorate with regard to the operation of the system.

When one looks at the amendment moved by Senator Haines one sees that it is a simple proposition-one which we have used elsewhere and which I think would be readily acceptable by everybody in the community-whereby the obligation is on the individual to communicate with the Australian Taxation Office where a person has a tax liability, for example, from interest earned. Where that did not occur it is obvious that some types of penalties would have to apply. I believe that method is one that would overcome most, although not all, of the problems that exist in this area, and that those who wished would have the ability to do so without penalty.

The difficulty of Senator Messner's proposition that the Government has accepted is that, as most people readily accept when they look at the figures, it is a little like a phrase that is often used with regard to the rights of individuals: that is, it is the right of both rich and poor to sleep under a bridge. There obviously is a massive distinction between people who do not have a roof over their head and their ability to sleep elsewhere and rich people's ability to organise themselves in such a way as not to suffer any penalty out of this exercise. It is not surprising that the Opposition looks after its rich mates. One comes to accept that type of proposition, but I should have thought the Government might have taken pause at the exercise and it may have been better to make sure that people, no matter what their income, were able to operate in a way that stays within the Government's original intention that the Taxation Office ought to know, when a person is employed, that person's address and tax file number, going together. Putting those two things together covers most, but not all, of the problems that may occur in the taxation area.

I should have thought it was equally simple for a person when opening a bank account or some other account from which interest might accrue, also to notify the Taxation Office that that account had been opened, and those two things could be linked. In other words, the tax file number would not have to be disclosed to any other group, and that is the important distinction between the approach that we have taken and the approach that the Opposition has taken. The tax file number would not have to be disclosed; it would provide, however, the same types of safeguards that the Government would be seeking so that people who had a tax liability would have to discharge it.

I go further to suggest that in a case when this information was not notified, it would then be up to the Taxation Office to investigate immediately, because quite a number of the areas will not be susceptible to legislation; they will only be susceptible ultimately to the Taxation Office having knowledge of an individual's activity, but for the Taxation Office to be able to cover those people it must obviously know where they are. The easiest way of triggering a number of those factors would be through the operations of a tax file number system which was operating effectively.

That is the position that we have held all along, but unfortunately, the way the Government has now gone about it is to set up a context in which it will be compulsory for some; it will be optional for the rich, but it will certainly not be optional for people on low income levels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of clause 6, I draw the attention of the chamber to proposed new section 202, which sets out the objects of the Bill. I would like to make some remarks concerning the higher education charge which Senator Macklin has been speaking of. Firstly, I make it absolutely clear that while we in the Opposition are giving our support to this legislation concerning tax file numbers, we are not implicitly or expressly giving our support to the Government's policy for the introduction of a higher education charge. We want to make it clear that no decision has been made by the Liberal and National parties on that question, because we have not yet received the legislation to discuss it. For that reason there can be no inference drawn from whatever is said or done in regard to this Bill today that we are lending support to the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to the main point of the amendments. I stated during the second reading debate that there were three criteria by which the Liberal and National parties determined their attitude on the question of support for this Bill. The first was whether the legislation would combat both tax and welfare fraud. The amendments which have been put forward by the Australian Democrats in turn have to be decided upon against those criteria. The Democrat amendments do not indeed assist the objective of seeking to bring down the curtain on tax and welfare fraud. In fact, it seems that the amendments would have the reverse effect of opening up the possibility for fraud to an even greater degree. I fear that the amendments fail, therefore, on that first ground by which the Liberal and National parties have determined their attitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us how. You have said it does, but you have not told us how or why.

—Perhaps that will emerge when I get to the third point. Secondly, I come to the question of cost-effectiveness. There is no doubt that the system and proposal put forward by the Democrats in their amendments would lead to intolerable burdens of cost and of administrative kinds on both the private sector-employers, large and small-and upon financial institutions that are handling all the paperwork, to such an extent as to significantly change the balance of the card in favour of more costs rather than benefits, so unquestionably the amendments fail our second test and again give us reason not to support them.

SPEECH.PARA: The third consideration which we set down against which we would judge support for the Bill was the question of civil liberties. We wanted to ensure that by our amendments both to this legislation, which have now been agreed to by the Government, and to the Privacy Bill, which have been negotiated by the shadow Attorney-General, we would be able to guarantee the confidentiality of one's tax file number and ensure that it could not be misused in the community without severe penalty. Those amendments have been incorporated into the tax file numbers Bill and will be incorporated in a moment when we get to the privacy legislation.

However, the amendments that the Australian Democrats are now proposing in relation to further freeing up or liberalising the use of the tax file number go a lot further by demonstrating that one's tax file number will become even more accessible to government agencies and to the private sector generally. It will thereby open up the very real possibility that confidentiality will be breached. The Liberal and National parties feel that to accept the proposals put forward by Senator Haines would be to provide a system where there would be pieces of paper floating around in the mail, on fax machines, or wherever, in absolutely immense numbers.

Opportunities would exist, as they currently exist, and would multiply many times, for people to find out what a person's tax file number would be in such a way as it could then be exploited by computer hackers or by people who want to stick their noses into other people's business. That is perhaps the most dangerous part of the Democrats proposals. It obviously opens further opportunities for confidentiality of the tax file number to occur. Above all, that is the reason why we will not be giving our support to the Democrats proposals. I want to emphasise that final point again because I think it is quite obvious that the Democrats want to bury this proposed system in a mountain of paper so that it just cannot work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you give us an example?

—Well, does not the Democrats amendment require letters to be going to and fro from commissioners of taxation to employers and financial institutions? Will they not have to quote numbers? Will there not be all kinds of opportunities to stick their noses into bits of paper and find out things about people? Of course they will and Senator Haines knows it. That is obviously what is going to be a direct result of what the Democrats are proposing. That appears to me to be putting not only an immense burden on the private sector but also allowing the possibility for the confidentiality that is well protected now by the privacy legislation to be breached.

SPEECH.PARA: Without going too much further on this subject I wish to make the point again that I believe that the Democrats amendment will spread paper around this community like confetti. There will be access to information available to persons wishing to find out about a person's affairs. For that reason we will not support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been in this place on and off for the last 11 years and I am used to listening to some fairly extraordinary arguments and speeches but this one probably takes the cake. One wonders what Senator Messner-who I understand before he entered this life was, in a previous existence, an accountant-thinks the group certificates do and are if they are not pieces of paper floating around between employers, employees, the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) and back again. We live under mountains of paper. The only change that has been made recently is that those bits of paper have been reduced somewhat because the banking sector and others have gone into computing systems. Instead of exchanging pieces of paper we have these little things that go beep in the night talking to each other. I find that last argument totally frivolous and non-convincing.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner talks about the fact that the plethora of papers being exchanged between individuals and the Tax Office and the Tax Office and employees is somehow going to create huge opportunities for breaches of privilege, breaches of privacy and invasions of civil liberties. We already have that happening. We already have group certificates and other pieces of paper going from employers and institutions to employees and the Tax Office and back again. Photocopiers and fax machines are hard at work 24 hours a day in this country. This is neither going to worsen nor improve the situation.

As for the rest of the arguments put forward by Senator Messner, I wonder whether he has looked at his own amendment. He said, `They apply three criteria to see whether something is worthwhile supporting in this instance'. He said, `Will it combat tax and social security fraud?'. If that is the major criteria I do not have the faintest idea why he is supporting this legislation at all. It is not going to completely combat tax and social security fraud. As I said in the debate on the second reading there are already people in the community who are successfully operating two or more identities. They have two or more false tax file numbers. The benefits are that they will get two or more tax free thresholds and pay tax at a significantly lower marginal tax rate than they would normally if they declared all the income earned under a single name. Are they going to go on doing this under this piece of legislation?

If somebody is working in a day job and calling himself John Brown and quoting a tax file number that has been issued to him under that name at that address to the employer the employer will deduct tax at the appropriate marginal tax rate. If that same individual works nights calling himself Bill Smith and using the tax file number that was allocated by the Tax Office years ago when he started this little scam the second employer will deduct tax at the lower marginal tax rate. I am almost 100 per cent sure that there is no more chance of his being caught under this system than under the one that already exists. Why should there be? We might pick up people who have not got a tax file number because they have been working a scam with an employer or because they have money buried in bank accounts that they are not declaring. That can certainly be fixed up under our system. So to argue that anything which combats tax and social security fraud is something that has the Opposition's support is ridiculous. This Bill will not do that any way.

Senator Messner went on to say that the Democrats amendment does not `bring down the curtain on tax and other fraud'. Yet he has calmly negotiated with the Government a deal that lets high income earners off the hook completely providing they are prepared to pay for the privilege. Providing they are prepared to lose 50.25c in the dollar they can get off that particular hook. He then says that the next criterion was cost-effectiveness and that if the amendment that we have moved is carried it will cost the Tax Office and private institutions a lot of money. Again, what does he think is happening now and what does he think is going to happen when all these records have to be kept anyway? I will tell him what will happen: the costs will be imposed on the private sector and the people who will pay eventually will be the public.

The banks will pass on whatever costs the current legislation causes them. That is what banks are in the business of doing more and more these days. Any institution that can entice people to lend money to it and then charge them for the privilege of withdrawing that money will not think twice about passing on the costs of servicing the requirements under this legislation. The cost to the bank will probably be less if the account holders tell the Tax Office and the Tax Office alerts the bank instead of it happening the other way round. If Senator Messner sits there in some sort of blue-covered cloud-cuckoo-land believing that the current legislation, or even the current situation, is not increasing costs on the private or the public sector, I suggest he take a little peek through the curtain that he thinks he has brought down on tax fraud and look at the real world.

The Opposition's third concern was for the protection of civil liberties. Again, the deal that the Opposition has done with the Government protects some people's civil liberties: it protects the civil liberties of the wealthy who do not have to provide the information for a fee of 50.25 cents in the dollar. Those people can choose not to hand over their tax file number or numbers. As Senator Panizza indicated at the second reading stage, those people probably have three or four numbers legally. They do not need to quote all of those and risk crosschecking, invasion of privacy or leaking of information, but the rest of us do. Senator Messner seems to feel quite comfortable about that. He would protect the civil liberties of the John Elliotts and Alan Bonds of this world but ensure that everybody on the unemployment benefit, $20,000 a year or family allowances of some sort goes through this system.

Our amendment cannot be used to breach confidentiality. Quite the reverse is true. Senator Messner is saying that if one gives one's tax file number to a bank, confidentiality will be preserved; if one gives one's tax file number and all the other details to a private employer, confidentiality will be preserved: but, if one gives it to the Australian Tax Office, see what happens. The only difference between what we are saying should happen and what the Government is saying should happen is that some people, if they choose to do so, can give it to the Australian Taxation Office instead of an employer or institution. Somehow or other, Senator Messner believes that, if an individual talks to the Tax Office and the Tax Office talks to an institution, we will get civil liberties infringements that we will not get if an individual talks to an institution and the institution talks to the Tax Office. Come on! This is not playschool, for heaven's sake.

The Tax Office is an institution which, of all institutions in this country, has pretty much the confidence of everybody because it has been able-admittedly, in its own interests-to maintain confidentiality. Where have the major breaches of privacy come from in the past? They have not come from the Australian Taxation Office's leaking of information, Mr Keating's late filing of a tax return notwithstanding. The major breaches of privacy come from the private sector-a sector which, I might point out, is not covered in the privacy legislation. People giving misinformation, information out of context or maliciously wrong information to, say credit bureaus in order to stop somebody getting a loan is an example. Those bits of information are not coming from the Tax Office: they are coming from the private sector. So do not try to tell us that if some individual informs the Tax Office who his employer is, what the details are and what his tax file number is-and he then gets the good housekeeping seal of approval from the ATO-somehow that information will be on the front page of a newspaper the next day. It is far more likely to happen the other way round.

Our amendment will do nothing to stop the Government combating tax and social security fraud. It will not worsen the cost problems already facing us in this country. It certainly will not increase in any way at all the paper war that goes on between institutions, and it goes far further to protect civil liberties for more people than that deal done between the Opposition and the Government to protect their rich mates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -On analysis, Senator Messner's proposition seemed to consist of three assertions and no examples. I invited him, by way of interjection, to give some examples which, of course, he singularly failed to do. I hope that he will come back into the debate with some concrete examples. The basis upon which the Opposition made up its mind on our amendment was its concern with three items, the first of which was social security and taxation fraud. If he had bothered to read our amendment he would have discovered that it in no way affects the operations or effectiveness of the Bill in that respect. Nothing in Senator Haines's amendment would do anything to lessen the Bill's ability to combat such things.

SPEECH.PARA: Our amendment deals exclusively with the way in which the Australian Taxation Office comes to know the tax file number of somebody who is an employee, the tax file number of a person who buys shares, the tax file number of a person who opens a bank account, and so on. In other words, our amendment deals exclusively with the interactive parts of information. It does not deal, and nor does it seek to do so, with those elements which would render the legislation either effective or ineffective. I reiterate Senator Haines's point that the Bill will stand or fall, with or without our amendment, in terms of whether it will be effective in these areas. Senator Haines said at the second reading stage, as have a number of speakers, that there are a number of areas in which it will do nothing.

For our part we have been willing to support those types of movements ahead despite the fact that they do not solve all the problems in the world. Fascinatingly, the Opposition has often opposed propositions on the grounds that they do not solve all the problems in the world. The Australian Democrats have been happy to move, in an incremental way, to overcome problems and we have been supportive of a whole range of areas in the taxation system which the Opposition sought to vote against.

I find it excessively odd that Senator Messner should come in here and give us a pious little lecture about why the Opposition has reached the decision that it now advocates after opposing year after year taxation measures which were specifically designed-and they have been massively effective-to combat the fraud that has existed in the taxation area. One example of this is the fringe benefits tax. The Opposition sought to oppose proposals that were put forward in one of the greatest rort areas in the whole taxation area. The prescribed payments scheme is another example. So the pious little lectures from Senator Messner do not really wash at all. But, of course, Senator Messner has not read the Democrats' amendments so he does not know that they do not relate in any shape or form to the point he raised. Whether or not the Bill is effective will not be affected in any way by our amendments.

The second matter raised by Senator Messner was cost effectiveness. The honourable senator again waved his arms and talked about mountains of paper. He referred to the concerns he has for his beloved private sector. I hope that what he said is useful in terms of any support that the Opposition may get in that area. But again the types of communications that are required by the private sector are not affected by our amendments. I invite Senator Messner, by way of response, to point to the part of our amendments which will increase impositions on the private sector. He might wish to do so by way of an example. He might even point to the part of our amendments that will do that.

The situation is that, even without our amendments, employers will have an obligation under the Bill. Currently, employers have an obligation to notify the Taxation Office when they employ somebody. That obligation is not going to be changed in any way by our amendments. Under our amendments an employee will be able to take on that obligation, if he wishes to do so, and proceed in a way that enables him to retain the confidentiality of the tax file number. In this way the information will not be available to the personnel branch. Personnel clerks, who do not have anything else to do when things are quiet on a Friday afternoon, and who may get out the files of a variety of people in order to get a bit of light entertainment will not be able to find out the numbers the amendments do say that an employee may communicate directly with the Taxation Office.

Senator Messner, having not read the amendments, presumably is not even bothering to listen either. That is probably fairly typical. By way of response, Senator Messner may in fact demonstrate where that mountain of paper is going to come from. Under our amendments, the Tax Office will be able to carry out the matching exercise and the Bill will operate in the intended way.

I believe that the most extraordinary statement was the third matter raised by Senator Messner about the decision that the Opposition had taken in regard to the protection of civil liberties. I think the area of civil liberties and tax is a difficult one for anybody to address. Undoubtedly, some liberties will be removed when the community seeks to impose a liability on an individual. I believe that the debate about civil liberties in our community should be one about the balance between those two items. That is not necessarily an easy balance to achieve. But I believe, other things being equal, that the preferred course is to achieve the same outcome without removing some of the liberties of an individual. I think that is what our amendments seek to do.

We have the opportunity to achieve the same result without everybody knowing a person's tax file number. We are seeking to allow the individual to assume responsibility for communicating information to the Tax Office. We believe-and our amendments recognise this-that it is not possible to do any more than that. It is up to the individual to decide whether or not he wants to follow that course. Our amendments do not seek to require people to disclose how much money they have. We wish to give people the opportunity to decide whether they desire to keep their tax file numbers to themselves and the Taxation Office or whether they are happy to have that information bandied around for all and sundry. I would imagine that a large number of people in our community would be quite happy to have their tax file numbers bandied around. It would not worry them in the least. On the other hand, it is clear that other people do care. If we can accommodate both of those wishes--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not because they are defrauders.

—As Senator Haines said, they might want this information to be regarded as confidential, not because they are defrauders but for other reasons. If we can achieve the same result and satisfy both groups of people, I believe that that is the way to go. That is the intent behind our amendments. We believe that it is possible to satisfy both groups of people-those who are happy to have others know what their numbers are and those who, for whatever reason, and I do not think one has to impute an improper motive, do not wish that information to be made available.

SPEECH.PARA: Off the top of my head, I can think of a number of reasons that are not improper motives. For example, I was a member of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform which was concerned with rewriting our electoral laws. We looked at, and in fact this Parliament enacted, a proposal to implement a secret confidential list on which an elector can apply to place his name rather than on an open roll. We did that because we know that electoral rolls are often used by private investigating agencies and others to track down individuals. I remember that the Committee was particularly concerned about cases such as that of a battered wife who does not wish her children or herself to be harassed by her husband. Such a person may have sought protection by changing her name, her accommodation and often the State in which she and her children are living. We said that such a person ought to be able to vote but that she should not have to do so in a way that places her in danger. That seems to me to be a perfectly good reason.

The tax file number will become a very useful piece of information which will undoubtedly end up in the hands of innumerable agencies. If this Bill is passed, I think that everybody will accept that that will occur. It is all very well to write various things into the legislation to try to stop this from happening. The only effective way of stopping the spread of this information is not to have it bandied about and this is what our amendments seek to do. Our amendments will ensure that people who, for good and proper reason, do not want information bandied about will have the opportunity to ensure that that does not happen.

I believe that each of the items that Senator Messner raised-the combating of social security fraud, cost effectiveness and civil libertarian issues-are maintained, enhanced or improved by our amendments. In particular, the civil liberties protection is definitely improved by our amendments. I think it is a pity that the Opposition has engaged in a grubby exercise in trading off whatever it is going to get out of the deal it has entered into-and I think we will probably see in due course, in terms of some other legislation, what it has managed to secure-against the protection of the liberties of individuals who do not wish to go down this line. I would have thought that there ought to have been a clearer approach from the Opposition spokesperson in this area based on the amendments circulated in the chamber. I hope that that will take place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reasons that I set out in replying to the second reading debate, the Government will not accept these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Haines's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 7 agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

(7) Page 41, Schedule 2, proposed amendments to the Income Tax Regulations, proposed subparagraph 43c (4) (c) (ii), after ``be taken to have quoted the number because of the application of'', insert ``section 202dh or''.

The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 33, subparagraph 52 (1) (b) (iii), lines 14 and 15, leave out ``except where the complaint was dealt with as a representative complaint-''.
(2) Page 33, subclause 52 (3), lines 23 and 24, leave out ``(other than a determination made on a representative complaint),''.
(3) Page 33, subclause 52 (4), lines 29 to 31, leave out the subclause.

We have three series of amendments to the Privacy Bill. The first concerns a representative complaint and would have the effect of amending subparagraph 52 (1) (b) (iii) on page 33. It is basically concerned with the fact that, at the moment, where there is a representative complaint and somebody is acting on behalf of two or more complainants, it is not possible for a declaration to be made that the complainant is entitled to a specific amount by way of compensation for any loss or damage suffered by reason of the act or practice the subject of the complaint. In other words, one of the remedies available to the Commissioner in the case of an individual complaint is not available in relation to a representative complaint, as the Bill stands at that moment. We in the Opposition cannot see why that remedy should not be so available. At the moment it is a disincentive to representative complaints when that might be the most efficient way in which to deal with a series of complaints arising our of the same circumstances. Therefore, our first series of amendments dealing with clause 52 (1) (b) (iii) is to that effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments moved by Senator Hill relate to the question of damages being available to an individual where one has a representative action. I draw the attention of the chamber to clause 39:

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing in this Part prevents a person from making a complaint under subsection 36 (1) about an act or practice about which a representative complaint has been made.

As the heading to that clause indicates, individual complainants are not to be precluded by representative complaints. It is just a simple analogy with what happens under sex and race discrimination legislation; that is, that a representative complaint can occur but an individual who wants to make a claim about the quantum of the compensation that should be awarded in his or her particular situation will just bring an individual complaint after the representative complaint has dealt with what is, after all, the most important issue, which is the changing of the act or practice which has given rise to the problem-the interference with privacy that might affect a range of people. We think that, the representative complaint being disposed of and the act or practice being changed and thereby the situation remedied, an individual complainant can then properly go through the process to get a tailored quantum compensation. Clause 39 is in the Bill for that particular purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were aware of clause 39 and our amendment does not seek to vary that clause. It would allow it to continue. In some circumstances, it might be appropriate for an individual complainant subsequently to move in the direction indicated by Senator Tate. That option is available and would remain available. But there may be other cases such as a matter which concerns a representative action of three complainants-it might be three individuals within a family-arising out of the same circumstances where the principle of any compensation would apply to each member of that family or group in the same way. It may seem to the Privacy Commissioner that there are circumstances in which he or she would want to award an equal amount of compensation to each of the three complainants. The most efficient way in which the matter could be disposed of would be to allow the Privacy Commissioner that option. All we are seeking to do is to add another option for the Privacy Commissioner. In some circumstances where it seems appropriate in the case of a representative complaint, he should have the option to provide compensation for any loss or damage suffered by reason of the act or practice, the subject of the complaint. Therefore, we are seeking to add another option to improve the flexibility available under the Act, and we see that as being of benefit to the community as a whole.

—I wish to say very briefly that at this stage the Government is not prepared to accept the amendments. I can see some merit in what Senator Hill has to say, but I believe that at the moment we need to give more consideration to, for example, the report of the Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) on class actions and the mechanism that might be put in place to enable a distribution between individual members of the representative action. We shall look forward to the Privacy Commissioner reporting on it to this Parliament. When we have some experience of how it works and, as I say, in the light of the Government's consideration of the ALRC report, I would be very happy for us to undertake a review and perhaps try to build in the flexibility and the option that Senator Hill speaks of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I ought to indicate at this stage that the Australian Democrats will be supporting the Opposition's amendments. I know that, if we were truly the churlish types that some like to believe, the fact that we had absolutely no cooperation from the Opposition on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill, the partner to this one, would have led us to say, `If you are going to oppose ours, we will oppose yours too'-a reverse of the usual phrase.
—It would be out of character for you.

—It would indeed, and I thank the Minister for that. We do make a point of saying that, unlike some others in this chamber, we actually look at legislation on its merits rather than on which of our donors is going to benefit or not by the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt, as I said during my speech at the second reading stage, that the Privacy Bill is deficient and requires improvement in a number of areas. Whilst it is long overdue, or perhaps because it is long overdue, we might just as well have, at the end of this exercise, the best piece of legislation that we can, a Bill with the fewest possible deficiencies, anomalies and so on.

In any event I do not believe that this privacy legislation is going to be an adequate protection against misuse or abuse of the tax file number legislation. But since the arrangement has already been made between the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Government-and as an ex-mathematician I can at least count; I know when the numbers are against me-we might just as well face the fact that we have now got in place the basis for a national identification system. We therefore need to come up with a piece of privacy legislation that is going to go as far as we in this place can make it go to protect people from all the problems that ensue from a national ID system. So while we have the legislation before us we might as well correct, however piecemeal or inadequate that correction might be, the anomalies and deficiencies in the legislation and insert the things that are missing which need to be placed in it.

I certainly believe that the question of representative complaint does need to be dealt with in a more effective and encompassing manner than it is in the present legislation. We will be supporting the Opposition's amendments Nos 1 to 3.
Amendments agreed to.
