INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly about a matter that I brought to the attention of this Senate earlier this year following a letter that 31 members of the Senate wrote to the Secretary-General of the Communist Party of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Mikhail Gorbachev, in February of this year. The 31 members of the Senate urged Mr Gorbachev to allow the Lithuanian and Estonian people to honour their national independence days peacefully and to take all necessary measures to guarantee that they do not become targets of state sponsored harassment as a result of these commemorations. That letter was forwarded to Mr Gorbachev, via the Russian Ambassador in Australia, on 19 February. We received an acknowledgment of the letter on 11 March 1988 from Mr Zemskov, the Minister-Counsellor with the Soviet Embassy in Canberra. He acknowledged receipt of the letter and said that the Embassy was asking the parliamentarians in Estonia and Lithuania to answer the message. At the same time, he refuted many of the facts that we stated in our letter to Mikhail Gorbachev. Mr Zemskov since then has achieved much more publicity and a higher profile in the Australian community following the assertions in the latest edition of the Reader's Digest that Mr Zemskov is a member of the elite KGB Special Reserve. I point out that the knowledge of his membership of the Special Reserve was well known to the Australian authorities and to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) before Mr Zemskov arrived in Australia in 1986. The advice of ASIO at that time in relation to Mr Zemskov was overridden and ignored by the Hawke Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Soviet Embassy did forward the letters to the Estonian and Lithuanian parliamentarians. We have received no reply since that time from any parliamentarians in Estonia, but I have now received a reply from four deputies of the Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic. The reply was in Russian but the parliamentarians were kind enough to provide an English translation. The letter is dated 10 May. It was posted to me direct from Lithuania. It arrived in a fine envelope with many fine looking stamps. The only problem was that it took about six months to arrive. It reached me only about two weeks ago, hence the delay in bringing it to the attention of the Senate. I do so now, and I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the English version of the letter.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator James Short
Australian Senate
Canberra, A.C.T.
Australia
Dear Mr Short.

We have thoroughly studied Your letter you had addressed to the General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Soviet Union Mikhail Gorbachev on February 19, 1988. In your letter You urged the Soviet authorities not to take any measures which would have impeded to commemorate the Independence Day of Lithuania on February 16.

It is true that on February 16, 1918, there has been signed a pact which led to the establishment of Lithuanian bourgeois state. This is an undisputable fact. But we would like to point out that the 10th of December is a proper day of Lithuania's independence. On that day the Soviet power was proclaimed in Vilnius, capital of the Lithuania. Regretfully, the Soviet power existed for a short while, it was suppressed by the occupational and local counterrevolutionary forces. According to the will of Lithuanian people the Soviet power was reestablished in 1940. The same year Lithuania entered the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

Under the Soviet power Lithuania with the assistance of all Soviet nations has changed from the backward agrarian appendage of the Western Europe in to the republic with highly developed industry, intensive agriculture and cherished culture.

We are not going to deny the fact that there is a small group of individuals who are dissenting with historical realities looking back to the bourgeois power in our republic. They are trying by various means, very often illegally, to attract the attention of Western mass-media, to win the support of foreign politicians. Of course, the handful of intriguers do not represent the interests of the people of Soviet Lithuania. Lithuanians condemn their activities.
The 16th of February was an ordinary working day, without any demonstrations and disturbances. By the way this could have been witnessed by western journalists visiting this day Vilnius.

By all means we have problems, as well as other nations which are heading towards progress. We are convinced that process of perestroika, the democratization of public life, glasnost will help to solve those problems in the spirit of constructive discussion.

On this occasion we would like to express the respect to You and the people of Australia. We would like to extend an invitation to the parliamentarians of Australia to visit our republic in order to have a close look at the life of the people of Lithuania.
Respectfully
The deputies of the Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR
Albertas Laurinciukas-The chairman of Foreign relations commission of the Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian SSR
Jurate Kupliauskiene-The chairman of student's trade-union of Vilnius Civil Engineering Institute
Vytautas Levickas-Director of the K. Giedrys fur processing ammalgamation
Marijonas Prakurotas-Brigade-leader of Vilnius planning and construction ammalgamation

TALK.START.PARA: —Because I have now had the letter incorporated I will not proceed to read it all, but I want to comment on one particular aspect, which was the main point about which we wrote to Mikhail Gorbachev-the historical question of whether 16 February was the true Independence Day date for Lithuania.
—Is that according to the Cyrillic or the Gregorian calendar?
—Gregorian, I think.
—Cyrillic is a script.

—I agree. In the reply that we have received from the four Lithuanian parliamentarians, they point out that we had urged the Soviet authorities not to take any measures which would have impeded the commemoration of Independence Day of Lithuania on 16 February. The parliamentarians say:

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that on 16 February, 1918, there has been signed a pact which led to the establishment of Lithuanian bourgeois state. That is an indisputable fact. But we would like to point out that the 10th of December is a proper day of Lithuania's independence. On that day the Soviet power was proclaimed in Vilnius, capital of Lithuania. Regretfully, the Soviet power existed for a short while, it was suppressed by the occupational and local counter- revolutionary forces. According to the will of the Lithuanian people the Soviet power was reestablished in 1940.

The letter then goes on to comment that there is a so-called small group of individuals who are dissenting from the historic realities and looking back to the bourgeois power of the Lithuanian Republic, and that the majority of Lithuanians condemn the activities of this group. I wish to give the complete lie to that point. I did so in my speech in this place on this matter in March of this year, and I will not repeat all of that, but I seek leave to have incorporated an information note supplied to me by the Lithuanian community in Melbourne on the whole question of the true Independence day of the Lithuanian state.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
LITHUANIAN COMMUNITY IN MELBOURNE
THE TRUTH ABOUT THE SO CALLED ``VOLUNTARY'' INCORPORATION OF THE BALTIC STATES INTO THE SOVIET UNION

(1) In the non-aggression treaty signed between the Republic of Lithuania and the Soviet Union on 12.7.20 the Soviet Government solemnly renounced in perpetuity claims to the territories belonging to Lithuania.

(2) On 23.8.39 the Ribbentrop-Molotov pact was signed in the presence of J. Stalin who proposed a toast to Adolf Hitler calling him ``molodiets''-a jolly good fellow. In the secret protocols of this treaty the two dictators divided Eastern Europe between them as follows: Finland, Estonia and Latvia were assigned to the Soviet spehere of influence and Lithuania to the Third Reich.

(3) After Lithuanian government refused Ribbentrop's invitation to declare war on Poland, a second secret protocol was signed between Moscow and Berlin on 28.9.39 leaving Lithuania also in the sphere of influence of the Soviet Union.

(4) On 26.9.39, two days before signing the second secret protocol, Molotov invited the Lithuanian foreign minister Urbsys to Moscow and offered him to sign a mutual defence treaty between the Soviet Union and Lithuania. Lithuania, Molotov insisted, should allow the Soviets to have their military bases in its territory. The Lithuanian minister refused to sign such a treaty incompatible with the sovereignty of his country and returned to Lithuania to inform his government about Moscow's strange demands. First of all the German ambassador to Lithuania, Mr Zechlin, was appealed to. He answered that the Third Reich couldn't do anything at all about the Soviet demands. No positive promises were received from other Western countries. For the first time the Lithuanian government understood the seriousness of the situation. On his second visit to Moscow on 7.10.39 Mr Urbsys offered a mutual assistance treaty but without the Soviet military bases. J. Stalin got impatient and interrupted the minister: ``you are arguing too much!''. The treaty had to be signed under Stalin's terms.

(5) On 14.6.40 Moscow gave ultimatum demanding that an unlimited number of Soviet troops were to be allowed to march into Lithuania. In addition, Mr Molotov warned that the Soviet troops would invade Lithuania whatever its answer to Moscow's ultimatum. The massive armed invasion took place before the ultimatum's time expired.
LITHUANIA AFTER THE OCCUPATION

(6) On July 2, 1940 Lithuanian prime minister V. Kreve-Mickevicius went to Moscow to speak with Mr Molotov making the last attempt to save Lithuania's independence. Mr Molotov was extremely frank. He told the Lithuanian minister: ``For centuries we dreamed of possessing the Baltic coast. Now we have the opportunity and we decided to use it. Lithuania together with the other Baltic States and Finland must be incorporated into the Soviet Union''.

Molotov explained how Moscow would legalize the incorporation and make it a ``voluntary'' one. ``Your people will be asked by Accepted Soviet Methods to enter into the family of the Soviet Union. You will see that before 4 months pass the Baltic States peoples will give their votes in favor of such an incorporation''.

(7) On 27.7.40 Molotov's announced general election in Soviet style took place. In strictly obligatory voting people had to vote for the only list prepared by the Communist party (it had 700 members in Lithuania, 3/4 of which were not of Lithuanian nationality) and Mr Dekanazov representing the invaders. As stated in a private conversation by the new Lithuanian president (named by Moscow's leadership) Mr J. Paleckis, 85% refused to vote. The puppet government informed the people that the election was highly successful with over 95% votes in favor of the candidates nominated by Moscow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The simple fact is that Lithuania was illegally annexed in 1940 by the Soviet Union, by Stalin, as a result of perhaps the most criminal of all secret pacts between countries-the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact, which annexed illegally the Baltic States to the Soviet Union. That annexation has been, with very few exceptions, completely ignored and rejected by the Western world, with the very unfortunate exception of a period under the Whitlam Government in the 1970s when de jure recognition was given. That recognition was repealed immediately on the election to government of the Fraser Ministry in 1975, and the Hawke Government has, thankfully, maintained that position.

SPEECH.PARA: The assertion that the will of the Lithuanian people as a whole is shown by the acceptance that Lithuania is now a legal part of the Soviet Union is a lie which must be continually rejected by the peoples of the free world. Otherwise we will continue, as a Western free world, to be beguiled by the attempts to rewrite history by the Soviet Union over many years. Whilst I welcome the apparent move in the Soviet Union towards a greater openness, a greater frankness and a greater and more meaningful relationship with the Western world through the policies of glasnost and perestroika, I believe that it is far too early to be taking policies and approaches at face value. If we do so without putting the Soviet Union to the test-a very meaningful test on the policies that it is now pursuing, a test of its bona fides-as to whether it wants a peaceful, constructive working relationship with the Western world, to the benefit of all nations on earth, I believe very sincerely and very strongly that we will fall into the trap of being beguiled by sweet siren words which we have heard before, and policies which we have seen adopted before and which did not last very long. Whilst I am very hopeful, and very pleased to see the developments that are occurring in the Soviet Union, I think that under no circumstances should we allow the Soviet Union in this era of greater openness to attempt to make the re-write of history that I believe the reply we have received from the parliamentarians of Lithuania implies. The concluding paragraph of the letter states:

On this occasion we would like to express the respect to you and the people of Australia. We would like to extend an invitation to the parliamentarians of Australia to visit our republic in order to have a close look at the life of the people of Lithuania.

That is an invitation that I look forward, hopefully, to accepting one day. I know that some of our colleagues have been on similar tours, but mainly organised through the Soviet Union at the central level. I find it very interesting that this invitation has come in the way that it has, and I hope that it is an invitation that we as senators will look at very closely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday evening, at my invitation, His Excellency the Ambassador for Greece came to Parliament House to talk to senators and members of the House of Representatives regarding the bid by Athens to host the 1996 Olympic Games. As honourable senators, particularly those from the eastern States, are no doubt aware, three cities-Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne- are currently bidding to be the Australian contender for those Games. The round of negotiations within Australia should be completed within a couple of weeks, when one of those cities will be chosen by the Australian Olympic Federation to be the contender in the run-up to the decision being made in Tokyo in 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important when one looks at this issue to reflect somewhat on the Games of 1896. Athens was chosen by the International Olympic Committee, which had been established at that time. The decision was made in 1894 that Athens would be the city to host the first of the revived Olympic Games. Athens at that stage was a town of about 50,000 people, quite a small town by anyone's standards. But one also remembers that the vast bulk of people then on the International Olympic Committee were people from France and Britain. Admittedly, it did have as a Chairman a very distinguished Greek citizen; nevertheless-numbers being what they are in sport or in politics-the overwhelming numbers on that committee would have been able, if they so chose, to allow London or Paris, the most splendid and important cities of the time, to host the first of the revived Olympic Games. Members of the Committee, however, had the enormous foresight to look beyond the immediate advantage to their own cities of Paris and London and instead choose Athens, a small country town, to be the city to host the revived Games. In doing so, they were recognising the unique contribution that Greece has made to world sport and, in particular, to the Olympic Games. It was not only a recognition; it was an acknowledgment of the central role played by Greece in that very important international event.

It seems to me, therefore-I have expressed this view publicly and in this place-that it is fitting for Athens to be the venue of the 1996 Olympic Games. I acknowledge that it runs counter to bids being made by the city in which I live and of which I am proud to be a citizen, and by other Australian cities, but I believe that on this occasion we need to take an international view. We need not to be miserly in our attitude. Australia, of all countries, is known around the world for being a generous and fair country. I think this is one of those occasions when we should employ that fairness and that generosity. The hosting of the golden Olympics, the hundredth anniversary Olympics, quite rightly ought to be the prerogative and the privilege of Athens. This is not just because it will be the hundredth anniversary, though that to my mind is an extremely important reason.

I am mindful of the fact that my own city of Brisbane was chosen to host a very successful World Expo 88. One of the reasons why the international community decided that an Australian city should be the host of the World Expo was obviously our bicentenary. The international community was saying to Australia, `We wish to share in your celebrations'. I think, when the international community is willing to do that for us, we ought in our turn, where we have the opportunity, reciprocate. This is one of those opportunities. The next Olympics will mark the hundredth anniversary, and the Olympic spirit first arose in Greece, where those games were first held and celebrated and when even wars were put aside so that people could contend in a peaceful way, bringing together not only physical strength and prowess but also, in the Olympic spirit, culture and art. But, over and above those reasons, there is another very important one. The Greek bid has been expressed in terms which are unique to Greece. It is not that it wishes to hold yet another Olympic Games in the fourth year after the Games in Barcellona, but that it wishes to raise in people's consciousness the reason for having such Games and to have people look back to the original purpose and intent behind the Games. As Greece has made clear, the original intent was not to stage a world event to sell sports goods or to advertise multinational logos. On the other hand, it was an international event to bring out the physical, the spiritual and the artistic qualities of the human race so that for a short period we would celebrate the achievements of the human race and not necessarily the types of things that divide us.

I believe that the extraordinarily beautiful, all marble Panathenaic Stadium, which was so impressively restored at extraordinary expense in 1896 on land that had originally been donated by an Athenian citizen to the world community for the hosting of such games, which saw the first event of the revived Olympics and which saw the end of the first revived marathon, should also see the entry of the Olympic torch in 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to bring to the attention of the Senate a matter which I regard as very serious indeed. It is an example of what I think is bureaucracy gone mad. It relates to the operations of the Child Support Agency which has recently been established under the Child Support Act 1988. The motivation for the establishment of the Agency is well known. There have been a significant number of persons in default under maintenance orders and as a result it was thought desirable that an agency be established within the Australian Taxation Office to be responsible for the collection of maintenance payments, which it would then remit to the Department of Social Security, which in turn would be responsible for making the payments to the beneficiaries.

SPEECH.PARA: The scandal and the outrage of the actual method of operation is that there will be a delay of up to eight weeks between the time the new system comes into operation and the time people receive their maintenance payments. For any maintenance orders made after 1 June 1988 it will be compulsory for a beneficiary to register with the Agency and the Agency will then be responsible for the collection of moneys. At the moment attempts are being made to coerce those whose maintenance orders were made prior to 1 June into being voluntary registrants. Whether or not they remain voluntary is another matter, because high level negotiations are going on between the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, and I imagine, all of the State Premiers. Certainly, in Victoria, Mr Cain is in active negotiation with his Federal colleague.

Let us consider what this means in practice. I put to the Senate an example of a constituent of mine who for some years has been in receipt of maintenance payments of $260.89 per month. As a result of the new scheme she has been told that she must register and that there will then be a two-month delay, during which period she will not receive any maintenance moneys. She has always received her moneys through the clerk of courts and there has been about a 24-hour turnaround. Her ex-husband pays the moneys to the clerk of courts, they are receipted and processed and a cheque goes out to her straightaway. She has been getting that money on a regular basis for a long time, but now she is told that for an eight-week period she will be denied maintenance payments. This is all for the sake of suiting the bureaucracy, which is trying to impose this solution across the board, no doubt to catch up with the 70 per cent of maintenance orders that are not properly or fully enforced, at the expense of the 30 per cent who are in receipt of maintenance payments on a regular basis, and in respect of whom people are not in default at all.

My constituent is a classic victim of a bureaucratic fix that has gone wrong. She is not going to get that money during the eight-week period, and it will not be made up until the very end of the maintenance order. Those with young children will not get that money until the children turn 16. That is an outrage. There is no justification for it. The Department suggests that the moneys will be paid into a trust fund established under section 74 of the Act. My examination of that section does not reveal any mention of whether interest is to attach to the fund, but undoubtedly it will. Section 74 does not say what will happen to any profits that are made but, undoubtedly, the surplus funds will be available to be used to pay for the costs of the establishment of the Agency.

I do not have any precise figures but I am told that to date some 10,000 people have already registered with the Agency. If they were receiving an average of $60 a week, according to my calculations over that eight-week gap the Agency would be looking at some $5m. Obviously, the period of delay will vary from case to case, but if we are talking about more than 10,000 people being deprived for up to eight weeks of an average of $60 a week, we are talking moneys that will be available to the Govenment for a period of years. The interest payments that will then accrue will be retained by the Government for its own purposes and denied to the real recipients-those entitled to the payments. I think that is scandalous.

I would very much like to be told that this interpretation is wrong, but we have made inquiries from the Agency, from the Minister's office and from the Department. They all confirm that the system is designed to punish the 70 per cent or thereabouts who do not fully comply with their orders. It will clearly disadvantage those who are getting regular payments. That is simply not good enough. Millions of dollars are to be held wrongly by the Government at the expense of those who are very much entitled to them. I do not need to spell out the real hardship that will flow to those who have children for whom these moneys are paid, who suddenly find that over Christmas they will be completely out of pocket.

My constituent does not work. She has relied heavily on $60 a week, or $260 a month, for her two children. She is unable to work because of a car accident. She suddenly finds that she is going to be completely without this money for a period of eight weeks and that, as a consolation prize, once the orders finally expire, in many years to come, a one-off payment will be made amounting to that sum. There is no mention of interest accrued; entitlement is simply to be deferred for a period of years to satisfy some crazy bureaucratic solution to a problem. I regard it not only as ham-fisted but also as manifestly unfair. I call on the Government to take urgent steps to ensure that those who are already struggling to make ends meet do not have to put up with such an unfair solution. Those who have no quarrel with the way in which the system has previously operated, who have been getting their moneys on a regular basis, should not be compelled to move to another scheme that will put them very much at a disadvantage.

DEBATE.TITLE: JUDICIAL AND STATUTORY OFFICERS (REMUNERATION AND ALLOWANCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 November, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Judicial and Statutory Officers (Remuneration and Allowances) Amendment Bill. Therefore, it is not my intention to keep the Senate long, but there are a few points that we believe are of particular importance and should be stated. The Bill is to give effect to the most recent recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal on salaries and allowances for judges and the President and members of the Inter-State Commission. The Tribunal's recommendations follow its 1987 review of the remuneration and allowances of justices and judges and the new rates of salary are proposed to take effect from 1 January 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point that should be made is our concern and, not surprisingly, the concern of the judiciary about the long delay in the presentation of this matter to the Parliament. As I understand it, the decision of the Remuneration Tribunal was received by the Government in February. It has taken until now to bring this Bill to the Senate. It was not introduced into the House of Representatives until August of this year and, although the figures will be backdated, I remind the Senate that the Bill provides that the Act shall be taken to have commenced on 2 December 1987. Although the figures will be backdated, it seems to us to be a most unsatisfactory way of dealing with increases in allowances for two judges and other members of the judiciary. I would hope that, while this Government remains in office, it might deal with these matters more promptly in future. If it does that it might find that there is less dissatisfaction on the part of the judiciary. The rising levels of dissatisfaction on the part of members of the judiciary in relation to a number of matters is a matter of concern to us all.

The second point I wanted to make is related to that matter. I refer to the concern of the judiciary that under the second tier increase the Government has, in effect, determined that it is satisfied that there have been changes to practices and procedures in the courts, and therefore increased efficiency and greater productivity, to justify that second tier adjustment. This is something of a sham. The Remuneration Tribunal itself acknowledged that it was inappropriate to work out the adjustment to judges' salaries on that basis, but it has been necessary for the Government to fit this area within its overall practice and therefore that sham has developed. Nevertheless, it has received criticism, from the judiciary and from the Law Council of Australia and, we believe, reasonably so. It is important that the standards of justice are maintained rather than that so many judgments, for example, be written within a given week. I refer the Senate to the criticism of the President of the Law Council, Denis Byrne, who said:

Of course judges have a duty to be efficient and expeditious, but they have an over-riding duty to perform their work with the greatest care, and they must be free from any pressure that would interfere with their ability to act in that way.

We on this side of the chamber would support that sentiment. The third matter that I want to mention, which is also of concern, is the overall question of the level of judicial salaries. This is causing considerable concern not only to the judiciary but to all those who are seriously interested in the administration of justice in this country. Honourable senators will no doubt be aware of the concerns that were expressed by Sir Anthony Mason at the recent conference of the Australian legal profession in Canberra. These concerns have been expressed by a number of judges and reported in the press, and have been made known to the Remuneration Tribunal. It is quite clear that the salaries of the judiciary are falling a long way behind the salaries of senior barristers. Nobody suggests that the salaries--

TALK.START.PARA: —They do better than we do.

—Many people in the community do better than we do. That is irrelevant to this debate. There is no suggestion that judges' salaries should strictly equate to those of senior members of the Bar; nevertheless, if they fall too far behind it is obviously a disincentive to go to the Bench. We on this side of the chamber believe that the best within the legal profession go to the Bench in order that the standards of justice in this country might be maintained and ever enhanced. There has been experience in recent times of judges retiring and going back to the Bar. That is a concern to the extent that it is being done because of the very significant shortfalls in the remuneration level.

SPEECH.PARA: We on this side of the chamber urge the Government to look seriously at the question of the appropriate level of judicial salaries. We look forward to the pending determination of the Remuneration Tribunal on the subject of judicial salaries generally, and we hope that when we have that information and, as a result, more material on the table, this debate might be continued, with the result that judges, particularly Federal judges, who see their salaries falling considerably behind those of State judges, find this shortfall redressed.

As I said, we support the Bill. It is important that the independence of the judiciary should be maintained and that is why Parliament, and not the Executive, is given the responsibility of fixing these salaries. We urge the Government to reconsider the level of judicial salaries because we believe that the existing shortfall means a loss to the community as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Hill for his remarks. The Judicial and Statutory Officers (Remuneration and Allowances) Amendment Bill, as he has said, implements the recommendations made by the Remuneration Tribunal in its 1987 review concerning the remuneration and allowances of the Federal judiciary, including persons who, by virtue of an Act, have the same status as a judge, and the President and members of the Inter-State Commission. It provides for a 3 per cent second-tier salary increase and adjustments to various allowances.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently the Tribunal has jurisdiction to make recommendations only in regard to the remuneration of the Federal judiciary and related officers. This differentiates judges from other groups within the jurisdiction of the Tribunal; that is, secretaries of Government departments, statutory office holders and parliamentarians whose remuneration is determined by the Tribunal. The fact that the Remuneration Tribunal does not have the power to make legally binding determinations in respect of judicial remuneration has meant that judicial salaries and allowances must be implemented by legislation. This necessarily creates delays for judges in receiving their appropriate entitlements and consumes the time of Parliament in debating the required amendments to the relevant Act. This is indeed a point that Senator Hill mentioned in his remarks.

I understand that it is the view of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that there is no constitutional constraint on the Remuneration Tribunals Act being amended to give the Tribunal determination-making powers in respect of the judiciary. The Government considers that this would be a desirable step and would eliminate, to a large extent, delays that have taken place in the past in implementing increases to rates of salary and allowances payable to the Federal judiciary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not that it is any different for us.

—That is a point I feel strongly about, but I will not respond to it in the context of the judiciaries Bill. It would also ensure that the remuneration of the judiciary is fixed in a manner consistent with that applicable to other groups within the Tribunal's jurisdiction and other senior public sector groups whose remunerations are fixed by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is the Government's current intention to legislate in 1989 to enable determinations to be made and thus eliminate the necessity for legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill raised in his remarks a matter which I think it might be appropriate for me to comment on, and that was the application of national wage fixing principles in the consideration of the Remuneration Tribunal. The Remuneration Tribunal, in setting the salaries and allowances of the groups within its jurisdiction-all of those classifications of groups that I have referred to-is required to have regard to the national wage principles and decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Whilst all of the provisions of the Commission's decisions may not, in their literal terms, be applicable to groups within the Tribunal's jurisdiction, it is nevertheless appropriate to apply them where feasible and to observe the intent and spirit of the Commission's decisions and principles. I do not believe that the setting of judicial remuneration in a manner consistent with that applicable to members of the work force generally has the effect or even the potential to infringe judicial independence.

TALK.START.PARA: —What new efficiencies were negotiated?
—It is a matter that was considered in the context of the determination, and that is for the members of the Remuneration Tribunal to set out in their considerations.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 September, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate now has before it the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill 1988. This Bill has been introduced for several purposes. Firstly, it increases the level of penalties for offences which are already in place but the penalties for which have not been reviewed for many years. Secondly, it transfers the definitions of various offences from the regulations into the principal Act. Thirdly, it allows inspectors, who are generally officers of the Government of Queensland, to pursue offenders outside the limits of the park provided that the pursuit commenced within the park and provided that no regular police officer is available, thereby extending the doctrine of hot pursuit on the high seas. Fourthly, it permits the Minister to take remedial action to repair damage done to the park and then to recover the cost of such action from any party or corporation which may have been responsible for causing the original damage, and to have the capacity to enforce this repayment through the courts. Fifthly, it allows the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to invest its surplus funds, which will come primarily from the operations of the aquarium at Townsville, in investments which have been approved by the Treasurer. Finally, it allows the Authority to provide its expertise to other bodies or institutions subject to the approval of the Minister and, if appropriate, to provide them on a commercial fee-for-service basis.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports this piece of legislation. The increase in penalties is to be welcomed. They are generally set at the level of a maximum of $10,000 for individuals and $50,000 for corporations. They cover such things as breaches of conditions of permits. These things have always been offences but have been provided for under the regulations. There are new and heavy penalties of up to a quarter of a million dollars for the dumping of prescribed matter, and especially for the dumping of dangerous wastes, and these are generally in line with the penalties in similar pieces of environmental legislation.

As I said, the power of inspectors to undertake hot pursuit on the high seas is being extended. At present, any pursuit which commences in the park must halt when the offender being pursued leaves the park. The new regime allows the park inspectors to continue their pursuit provided it commenced in the park, it has been uninterrupted since it commenced and, in addition, a police officer is unavailable. Generally, one would have thought, police officers, unless they are hanging about on the reef for no particular purpose, are unlikely to be available to continue a pursuit which has commenced in the park when the offender leaves the boundaries of the park. Therefore this is an entirely reasonable proposition, although I propose to say something about what I think is one of the pieces of nonsense in the legislation in relation to this matter at a later stage. The inspectors, as I said, are nearly always employees of the Government of Queensland, and I understand that the State Government of Queensland supports this particular proposal.

The Minister may now, under this legislation, take steps to repair damage and recover the appropriate costs from offenders. This clarifies a power which it is believed has always existed in common law dealing with trespass and damage. The system is underpinned by the issue of injunctions and enforcement orders by the normal process in the courts. The Authority is to be given the power to invest its surplus funds-that is now a widespread provision for like authorities under the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth-and the Bill allows the Authority to make its undoubted expertise available outside the Federal Government. Where appropriate, this will be on a contract fee-for-service basis. Such arrangements must be approved by the Minister and cannot be approved if they might, in the words of the legislation, `affect adversely the performance of the functions of the Authority'. Again, that has the support of the Opposition.

I draw attention to the fact that back in 1981 the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment dealt with the question of the adequacy of the legislation affecting the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park in general, and made recommendations which have been largely taken up in this Bill. So this Bill responds to some previous comments and queries raised by the House of Representatives in that inquiry.

I wish to raise a couple of minor matters in relation to the Bill, which contains an interesting redefinition of the reef to include what are referred to in the legislation as bommie fields, reef slopes, moats and ramparts. When the triticale legislation was introduced earlier today, there were massive looks of disbelief around the place as to what exactly it was that was being provided for by way of levy. Indeed--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know what it is?

—It is a cross between wheat and rye, for the honourable senator's information. It reminds me of the first occasion that I was introduced to a `field of rape'. The bommie fields, I understand, are groups of crowns of corals which are not joined. Moats, ramparts and reef slopes and other things which are provided for in the legislation extend the definition of the term `reef', although I understand this does not apply for what are commonly called, in that area, `sandy flats'.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw attention very briefly to an example of one of the sorts of nonsenses that we are starting to get into legislation. I refer to the powers that inspectors are to be provided with under section 46a (3), which deals with taking people into custody and conducting searches. We have the following extraordinary piece of draftsmanship:
An inspector who conducts a search under this section shall not use more force, or subject a person to greater indignity, than is reasonable and necessary in order to conduct the search.

The question of what subjects a person to greater indignity than is reasonable, given that force can be used provided it is not more force than is reasonable and necessary, seems to me to be the sort of thing that is now creeping into legislation. Frankly, I believe that the attempt to write what, after all, are basically questions of commonsense, into legislative form, is really getting a little out of hand.

I want to mention in particular, and I commend the Government for having taken this action, the capacity which this legislation gives for action to be taken against people who cause damage to the reef. There is, for instance, a matter under way at the moment concerning a floating pontoon-Fantasy Island, I think was the matter in question-put there in order to provide public entertainment. The thing was erected, no doubt at some cost, and promptly sank. It is now sitting around on the seabed. The owner of the pontoon undertook to have it removed by 3 September this year. I understand that the pontoon has not been removed and, indeed, that it is unlikely to be removed by the end of the year. It is my understanding that it is not the intention of the Authority to allow the pontoon to be refloated and to remain within the park. I hope that, given this new piece of legislation, the Government will be quite vigilant in taking action against the owner of this particular facility if damage is done and there are remedial costs to be borne in removing the item from the area. This is an important addition to the power provided to the Authority, and one which is welcomed.

I raise, however, one other matter on which the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) may be in a position to give some advice. A report appeared in the Australian newspaper in September of this year that a reasonable size ammunition dump had been discovered off the John Brewer Reef, just 75 kilometres or so off Townsville. Although it was believed that there was no immediate danger, there is certainly a prospective danger of an explosion among the 100 tonnes of unexploded ammunition which is there. I would be interested to know whether anybody has any direct responsibility for that and whether any steps are being undertaken to render it less hazardous or, indeed to remove the ammunition dump.

The final point that I make is that, in the course of the hearings of Estimates Committee D this year, I raised with Mr Kelleher, the Chairman of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, some details about the success of the aquarium which you, Madam Acting Deputy President, as a Queensland senator, would undoubtedly be familiar with. That aquarium, which last year, I believe, won the award for the best tourist facility in Queensland, had some 311,000 people passing through it in the last year. I have not had the opportunity to visit it yet, but I propose to do so on Tuesday of next week. The revenue which has been generated from that will now be capable of being invested by the Authority. I believe, from what I understand of the facility to date, that it is to be congratulated on the development which has taken place and the attempt to ensure that, at least in this instance, the integration of tourism and environmental protection is handled in an appropriate and proper fashion. It is my pleasure on behalf of the Opposition therefore, to lend our support to this piece of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not be necessary for me to go into the analysis of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill. Senator Puplick has done that quite adequately. He is well able to understand environmental matters; he is just, seemingly, incapable of doing anything to control his friends in the resource rip-off industries when it comes to environmental protection. I do not see any major problems with this Bill. In fact, some of the proposed provisions are long overdue.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick brought up the issue of Fantasy Island, a bizarre proposal which was basically a bunch of mobile homes arranged in a doughnut shape with palm trees protruding at intervals and which, of course, sank in a strong wind. This Fantasy Island fiasco may have prompted the clauses dealing with the removal of wreckage. The owner, Dough Tarca, claims that it will cost $268,000 to shift the remains and has used the defence that the wreck is a great place for fishing and diving. He is also having fights with his insurers, who do not want to pay. Anything that will prevent such a situation from happening in the future, of course, is very welcome.

Another project is mooted for the Barrier Reef which could cause environmental difficulties even if it does not sink-and, of course, if it has the same fate as Doug Tarca's Fantasy Island it could be a disaster. I refer to the P and O proposal for a pontoon and day visits to Masthead Island. Masthead Island is a very important part of the Great Barrier Reef. It was declared a national park in June of this year. Geoff Muntz, the Queensland Minister for Environment, Conservation and Tourism, gave a press release on 30 June 1988 in which he summarised the island's major environmental attributes as follows: the second largest coral cay on the Barrier Reef; the second largest pisonia forest in Australia and one of the last forests of this tree in the world remaining intact; the second largest wedge-tailed shearwater colony in eastern Australia, with up to 60,000 birds, and a major Pacific Ocean colony; the second largest black noddy colony in Australia, with up to 17,000 birds, and a major Indo-Pacific colony of this species; the largest colony of roseate terns, globally threatened species, in eastern Australia; the principal nesting site for green turtles; and an important nesting site for white capped noddies, crested terns, bridled terns, blacknaped terns and colonies of lesser crested terns and eastern reef egrets.

The island is currently managed as a wilderness camping area, with camping limited to approximately 3,000 people per annum. There is a complete ban on motor driven appliances, and the total capacity is limited to 30 people at one time in the summer and 60 at one time in the winter. That is all very fine. It shows that the present plan is meant to allow people to visit the island and see it without doing undue damage. However, the P and O proposal is for a floating pontoon which is 45 metres long by 16 metres wide-that is a big floating pontoon-to be anchored off the reef flat to the north-west of the western end of the island. Daytrippers would be unloaded from the Heron Island fast cat in the morning and picked up in the afternoon. There would be an underwater viewing platform and glass bottom boats, and other activities such as snorkelling, diving and reef walking would be pursued. Access to the island would be restricted to small parties under the supervision of a guide, according to the proposal. The Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service has apparently conceded to a six-month test period for this access.

I think this proposal should be vigorously opposed. Masthead Island has a high natural value because of the number and size of the nesting colonies of birds, the vegetation, the turtle rookers and the surrounding platform reef, as has been admitted by the Queensland Government. Masthead should be retained as a low-key recreation area and have access restricted during periods of high nesting numbers. It will be very difficult to restrict visitor numbers to the island, particularly if 100 seasick passengers are unloaded onto a pontoon which rocks. They will want to go ashore. How will one keep them from going ashore, and who will keep them from doing so? P and O could provide adequate day visitor facilities on Heron Island or, alternatively, it could locate a pontoon on one of the reefs which does not have a coral cay.

P and O intends to dispose of sewage by on-board treatment and disposal on site. This is utterly appalling. There is no arrangement for the treatment of water from showers and washing facilities associated with catering. Again, this is utterly appalling. We are talking about a national park, about the Great Barrier Reef. Yet P and O wishes to dispose of sewage and waste water. Under many wind and tide conditions the site is dangerous for inexperienced swimmers and snorkellers. It is intended to moor the pontoon using four anchors, each at the end of 110 metres of chain-the size of a football field. The company says that it will move live coral to allow these chains to rest on the bottom without damage. However, the chains will be subject to considerable movement during a heavy swell and reasonable winds and will stir up sediments. These heavy mooring chains will disturb the bottom. An analysis of this proposal clearly demonstrates that the pontoon will not withstand a big cyclone and will have to be sunk in situ to limit damage to it and its surroundings. If the winds get strong they will sink the barge, and then, hopefully, they can raise it again. Environmentally destructive activities such as fish feeding and reef walking are proposed.

There are a number of other reasons-many complex reasons-why this proposal should not go ahead, but I think I have outlined the major ones. I do not wish to delay the Senate any longer. I urge the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and his Government to take a good hard look at the P and O proposal for the pontoon on Masthead Island. If it goes ahead it will further degrade one of Australia's greatest natural assets and one of its greatest tourist assets, the Great Barrier Reef.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Minister for Resources, it is indeed a pleasure to stand here where Senator Graham Richardson would be standing as Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.
—Why? Do you want his portfolio?

—No, I just think it is an interesting comment on the flexibility of this Government that we can change positions and argue these matters as they come before the Senate. Had I risen a few minutes earlier, I would have been bathed in a glow of natural light through the skylight, which may have put a patina of even more purity upon me. However, instead of talking about oil gas and mining I am now talking about the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill 1988 and such subjects as Fantasy Island and hot pursuit a la Smokey and the Bandit, hot pursuit to be provided within the Bill.
—Which role do you see yourself as playing?
—The hero's role, of course, Senator Puplick should not have bothered to ask such a question.
—I just wanted to see whether you were casting Graham Richardson as the bandit.

—I do not see any rivalry. That is the point. This is the Third Hawke Government, we are entirely united, unlike, I would observe, if I were to make a political speech, the Opposition. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill proposes the following amendments: to incorporate into the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act a number of offences currently in the regulations, with an associated increase in penalties; revised clauses on declaration of pecuniary interests, which flowed from the recommendations of the 1979 Bowen committee; to empower the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority or interested third parties to seek injunctions; and the recovery of costs in rectifying damage flowing from a breach of the Act and payment of the reasonable costs of rehabilitation and restoration. It will also allow the Authority to provide assistance to other outside organisations and a number of other amendments to bring the Act into line with current drafting practice.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that this chamber, often sharply and heatedly divided, is heatedly in agreement that this Bill should go through. I thank the Opposition spokesman for the environment, Senator Puplick, and the Australian Democrats spokesman for the environment, Senator Norm Sanders, for concurring that this Bill will have undisputed passage.

A number of comments have been made in the speeches by the two spokespeople for the other two parties. I first turn to the question of Fantasy Island. As Senator Puplick and Senator Sanders have observed, Fantasy Island, a tourist pontoon floating adjacent to the floating hotel, has sunk. It broke up and sank in high winds on the night of 30 May. Although there were a number of staff on board at the time there was no death or injury. No environmental damage has been done as yet and it is not in the opinion of the Department or, indeed, of anyone, I think, a navigational hazard. The wreckage is resting on the seabed in about eight metres of water. The operator of the pontoon, Reeflink Pty Ltd, was directed by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to remove the structure from the marine park by 3 September. Some material has been salvaged but the operator has failed to meet that deadline and has sought an extension of time to remove the wreckage. The Government shares the anxiety and concern expressed by both speakers in this debate, and we want to see the thing removed as quickly as possible and at no cost, of course, to the Commonwealth. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) has sought legal advice from the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) on how that might be expedited if it is necessary to take steps to expedite it, and at this point I cannot comment further pending the outcome of the Attorney-General's considerations.

The other matter raised by Senator Puplick was the ammunition dump that has been found in the marine park. This is on the John Brewer Reef near the floating hotel. I think Senator Puplick said it was reported in the Australian in September of this year. He asked what we were doing about it and how it could best be dealt with. An unexploded World War II ordnance has been discovered adjacent to the outside perimeter of the John Brewer Reef. It was apparently dumped at the reef during 1945 and 1946, after the hostilities in the war had ended. Both the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, and Senator Richardson have been kept fully informed of the matter. On the discovery of the dumps the Royal Australian Navy immediately declared the area to be `foul ground', and the public has been warned to keep clear. The Chief of the Defence Force has directed a Navy clearance diving team to survey the area. They report that there are 12 dumps of ordnance, comprising a mixture of anti-tank mines, artillery shells and machine gun and rifle ammunition. The dumps are partly buried in sand, are coral encrusted, lie in water depths between 20 and 31 metres, and vary in distance from 950 to 2,600 metres from the floating hotel. The condition of the ordnance has not been established, but it is not likely to constitute a hazard as long as it remains undisturbed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean, it is not dangerous until it goes off?
—Well, it would be very inadvisable to start fiddling around with it. An appropriate sign to be posted in the area would read `Approach with great care'.

SPEECH.PARA: Further technical examination and assessment is being organised by the Department of Defence to determine the exact condition of the ordnance and to assist in assessments of options for subsequent action. No doubt it is calling for volunteers. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the operator of the floating hotel are being kept informed. In summary, we should say that the Defence Department has got the matter in hand and, consistent with the need to remove the ammunition, is dealing with it as well as one could expect in the circumstances.

Senator Sanders raised a question about a pontoon proposal from P and O in the proximity of Masthead Island. I am informed that an application on that matter has been received and is being processed. The proposal is subject to a public environmental report, a PER. Under the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, the Marine Park Authority is waiting to receive advice from the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Territories and Tourism before commenting further. The PER should review all the possible impacts and effects that have been referred to in Senator Sanders's speech and, indeed, all the possible impacts and effects that would relate to the matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Sitting suspended from 1.54 to 2.00 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE BROADCASTING OF PARLIAMENTARY PROCEEDINGS

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings met this afternoon and adopted the following resolution:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Committee supports the temporary transfer of the broadcast of parliamentary proceedings to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's standby transmitter network.
The Committee has also sought advice on the possibility of broadcasting Question Time and the adjournment debate live on Radio National, and also a summary of the day's proceedings at 7.15 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's recent description of the award restructuring process as `massive' and `dramatic' and also to the Government's submission to the last national wage case which stated that award restructuring should not be restricted to a revision of job classification structures and should include working time arrangements. I also refer the Minister to a recent circular to all Australian Council of Trade Unions unions from the secretary of the ACTU, Mr Bill Kelty, which makes it clear that the ACTU position is to `keep the issues confined to skill formation, classification structures, related training requirements and associated wage rates'. Does the Minister agree that the ACTU position contradicts the decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that all matters in awards that affect industry's competitive requirements should be reviewed, including working time arrangements, and indeed that the ACTU's position contradicts the Government's position? What action will the Government take to ensure that the ACTU does not sabotage award restructuring negotiations, and how will it ensure that all matters affecting industry competitiveness are on the agenda?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no question of the ACTU sabotaging award restructuring negotiations. The ACTU invented it. It was not industry or management that invented it, but the ACTU. It is very committed to it. The ACTU has had to take along with it, in the view that there should be restructuring of classifications and so on, a considerable number of employers and employer bodies. I think that there is now a consensus about the importance of that. In so far as the last decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission contains the phrase that negotiations should not be restricted and should deal, among other issues, with all matters including working time, that is a decision of the Commission and when the Commission reconvenes next year it will be asking the parties what they have done about these issues. The Commission, I think, will not in any way be confining its observations from what it said in the last national wage case hearing about this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: If the ACTU puts out a circular about negotiating strategies and lays emphasis on particular matters, I do not see that as being inconsistent with the Commission's decision. The issue of time worked, for example, embraces an issue such as whether it is much better for people to work a four-day working week of 12-hour shifts rather than a working week of five days with eight-hour shifts, and so on. That is happening in a lot of places and with union agreement-people working 12-hour shifts for four days. I think it is a very important issue, particularly in capital intensive industries where machinery should be used as much as possible around the clock. I do not see any inconsistency in what Senator Chaney has dug out of an ACTU circular to unions and what the Arbitration Commission said in the course of its last hearing. All these things involve a process of change, negotiation and reaching a sensible position in which both sides from time to time have to be accommodating.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put on your H. R. Nicholls tie.

—Senator Stone interjects, and I think that even he in his wildest imaginings would concede that sometimes it is worth while accommodating positions which represent progress in industrial relations or anything else.

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his Alice in Wonderland answer which seems to involve words meaning what the Minister wants them to mean. Does the Minister agree that the ACTU is seeking to restrict the scope of award restructuring? Does the Government agree that negotiations on award restructuring should be so restricted, or does the Government believe that the negotiations should be open on all matters which affect industry competitiveness?

—Now Senator Chaney is asking me a different question altogether because that is not what the Arbitration Commission said. It did not say that it should deal with all matters affecting industry competitiveness. Senator Chaney talks about me living in an Alice in Wonderland world-Alice could at least read, and Senator Chaney has not read the decision very clearly. The Arbitration Commission laid down the guidelines--
—What is the Government's view?
—If Senator Chaney will not keep interrupting me, I shall answer him.
—If you give me an answer to my question, I will.

—Do not get hysterical, senator. The Arbitration Commission laid down certain guidelines. The Government argued for those things and welcomed that decision. In my original answer to Senator Chaney I said as much as that-that the Arbitration Commission would not regard itself as being restricted from anything it said in the last national wage case and the Government would not regard it as being restricted from anything said in the last national wage case. If Senator Chaney wants to interpret an ACTU circular as representing a restriction on the Arbitration Commission, I must point out that, of course, it is not.
—It is a restriction on the negotiations; that is what we are talking about.
—The ACTU circular which Senator Chaney read out was a document directed to the issues upon which concentration should be mounted in negotiations by the ACTU. That is all that can be said about it.
—It says `keep the negotiations confined to'.

—In the course of these negotiations various things will emerge. It takes two to negotiate, two to tango. Those negotiations will take place and there will be reports back to the Arbitration Commission, which will then pronounce on the success or otherwise of the negotiations in the light of its own guidelines.

—I refer the Minister for Finance to my previous question in 1986 concerning production of coins by the Royal Australian Mint for overseas countries as one means of helping improve Australia's balance of payments. At that time the Minister advised that the Mint would pursue vigorously opportunities for foreign coinage contracts in view of Australia's increased competitiveness due to the devaluation of the dollar. Will the Minister now advise of any contracts subsequently sought by the Mint for overseas coin production, and what contracts, if any, have been awarded?

—The Royal Australian Mint, as I stated in answering a question from Senator Maguire on this topic a couple of years ago, is actively seeking contracts to print coins for other countries and is working through Austrade and its own marketing initiatives at present to get contracts for minting coins for Middle Eastern countries. The Mint this year sought and obtained a contract to make New Zealand's 1988 requirements, which involved a total production of 61 million coins and for which the contract price was just over $4.5m. Also, the Mint is seeking the contract to produce New Zealand's 1989 requirements, including the new $1 and $2 coins which the New Zealand Government has recently announced will be introduced. Therefore, the 1989 contract, if it is secured, is expected to be worth over $6m for around 100 million coins. The Mint is also seeking a small order for 1989 from Tokelau, as well as producing in 1988 smaller numbers of coins for the Cook Islands, Western Samoa, Fiji and Tonga. In addition to those circulating coin orders, the Mint has produced collector and numismatic coins for these countries. That work has been done by the Mint this year in spite of the heavy domestic requirements on its capacity, including the minting of the $2 coin and the bicentennial coin collection.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I ask: Is he aware that a demonstration of some 50 to 100 people was held yesterday at the offices of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) by persons objecting to the dismissal of Charles Perkins? Were the offices occupied for some considerable time and use made of the office facilities and telephone services? Why did the General Manager, Mr Cedric Wyatt, send the ADC staff home and yet not call in the Australian Federal Police nor invoke the established procedures for removal of demonstrators? Was Mr Sugar Ray Robinson of Charleville one of the demonstration leaders? If so, given the serious issues raised at the Estimates Committee hearings about Mr Robinson's criminal background and dealings with the ADC, what protection of files and property was undertaken?

—During the lunch hour I became aware of a demonstration, if it may be termed such, at the offices of the Aboriginal Development Commission yesterday. I understand that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has sought a report on the whole incident. No doubt, when that report is received he will be in a position to advise me as to the proper response for Senator Tambling.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to newspaper reports about confusion in the ranks of supporters of the goldmining lobby about the justification for opposing the removal of the exemption from tax of income derived from the mining of gold. I ask: What are the disbenefits of not taxing income derived from the mining of gold and the implications of continued opposition to it? Who will be the losers from the decision to apply normal taxation rules to gold?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The losers are very easy to identify. When the proposed legislation is passed and proclaimed, as I confidently expect it will be before the end of this year, the losers will be the spivs who are funding the State election campaign of the Western Australian Liberal Party, and their own campaign, and the United States Treasury which will lose the $70m a year it is presently getting in unplanned and unofficial foreign aid from Australia.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Minister has just made an extremely unpleasant and defamatory statement which, of course, is covered by privilege. I draw your attention to the fact that the stance taken by the Western Australian State Liberals to whom the Minister is referring is exactly the same as the stance taken by Premier Dowding. There is a provision in the Standing Orders which prohibits disorderly reflections upon members of another Parliament. I ask you to consider what the Minister has said because he is clearly intending his remarks to be a reflection on those Western Australian members of the Liberal Party who, as it happens in this case, are accompanied in their pleas, as I understand, by Premier Dowding. You cannot have it both ways, Mr President. I suggest that the answer is out of order.
—There is no point of order. I do not think Senator Walsh referred to members of parliament. I call Senator Walsh.

—One group that certainly will not lose when the Government's legislation is passed are those people who actually work in the goldmining industry; that is, the workers who have always paid taxes on the wages they receive. The people who will lose is that succession of spivs who lounge around in Perth, who have done for as long as I can remember. I have seen them all; Tony Motion, Duncan Bell, Ian Cornelius, who incidentally did a bit of time in the slammer, along with Peter Briggs, for conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth-not as much time as he should have done; but he did go to the slammer for it. Of course, this is the group of people that the Liberal Party is pandering to in Western Australia in order to pick up, it hopes, votes and, more importantly, donations.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make it very clear that the spivs are wasting their money because the legislation will be passed; it will be proclaimed. Even if, in the highly unlikely event of a Liberal Government being returned federally and the Liberal Party being able to sort out its internal confusion, to which Senator Beahan referred at the beginning of his question, it will not have the numbers to repeal the legislation anyway. So the spivs are wasting their money.

In reference to the United States Treasury, a couple of days ago I explained that because of the double taxation agreement tax paid in Australia is deductible for United States equity holders against their United States tax liability. Because the tax is not paid in Australia, it is paid in Washington instead. As I have said before, although the United States has deteriorated very badly economically under the Reagan Administration, it is certainly not a Third World country and does not deserve to be the recipient of Australian foreign aid, which it currently is and which the Liberal Party would have it continue to be.

I note that yesterday morning in an interview on the wireless, Mr Tuckey, a Liberal Party member of the House of Representatives, claimed that because of the imputation system it really made no difference to the revenue collected by the Government whether gold companies were taxed or whether, through the imputation system, dividends were taxed when distributed to shareholders. That is not entirely true; it is partially true. Let us assume for a moment that that is entirely true and that it makes no difference to the revenue so far as Australian shareholders in goldmining ventures are concerned. If that is true, all that leaves is the $70m presently being donated to the United States Treasury-the taxes paid in Washington, in lieu of taxes which ought to be paid in Canberra. Therefore, on the basis of Mr Tuckey's analysis of the situation I invite anybody in the Liberal Party to justify having the United States as a recipient of Australian foreign aid. There are plenty of countries, if we were inclined to increase our foreign aid by $70m, more worthy than the United States to receive it. I also invite the Liberals who will be voting on this matter to table in the Senate the list of their shareholdings in goldmining companies.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED SHIFT OF NAVAL FACILITIES FROM SYDNEY TO JERVIS BAY

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence whether it is a fact that the main reason for the proposed shift of naval facilities from Sydney to Jervis Bay was the desire of former Premier Neville Wran, Prime Minister Hawke and former sport and tourism Minister, John Brown, to obtain and develop the 260 hectares of land now occupied by the Newington Armaments Depot for a range of purposes, including the 1989 world student games? Second, has the main reason for the shift now become the possible use of the Newington site for the construction of an athletics stadium and village for the 1996 Olympics? Third, what is the latest date that the shift of the armament depot from Newington to Jervis Bay can take place, while still allowing timely access to the Newington site for the construction of facilities for the 1996 Olympic Games? Fourth, is it a fact that the completion date for the Jervis Bay environmental impact statement (EIS) has been brought forward in order to accommodate the intention of the Federal Government and New South Wales Government to sacrifice Jervis Bay to Sydney's Olympic bid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed, to say the least, in the tone of the question. The idea that this Government or, indeed, any government, would consider undertaking something as major as the shift from Sydney to Jervis Bay on the basis that we wanted to support an Olympic Games bid is, I hope, impossible, but at best I can only describe this question as far-fetched. I do not normally ascribe to Senator Sanders a belief in all conspiracy theories, but this would be the ultimate conspiracy theory and would involve the sacrificing of all the principles of economic justice which this Government holds so dear. So the answer to question one is no. The answer to question two is no. The answer to question three is that as far as the Commonwealth is aware, the date of relocation of the armament depot will have no impact at all on the availability of land at Newington, in which the State is understood to have an interest for Olympic Games purposes. The answer to question four is no.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Any examination of Australian success in exporting our products shows that there is a high correlation with adequate, extensive and excellent research. I understand that at the National Science and Technology Analysis Group Forum which the Minister opened on Thursday of last week a common theme during the two days of discussion was the need for greater collaboration between the public and private sector in research and development. Does the Minister agree with this view, and how is the Government facilitating such collaboration between the public and private sectors in research and development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do agree with this view-because Senator Crowley might not have asked me the question otherwise-and my colleague, Mr Kerin, agrees with the view, too, as I read in the newspaper this morning. I want to say one or two things about the National Science and Technology Analysis Group Forum because it was a very important forum, and there was a very good interrelationship there between industry and the scientific community. Government support for research and development in Australia is stronger than in most other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries, including, for example, Japan and the United States of America. However, during the decade of the seventies and even earlier than that, private sector research and development in Australia let this country down substantially.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government now provides a comprehensive package of measures aimed at encouraging industry research and development, and part of this package is the generic technology scheme. This is designed to encourage collaboration between researchers in the public sector such as universities and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and companies in new or emerging technologies considered fundamental to future industry development. There have been four technologies designated as generic technologies as part of the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Generic technology! That is about the eighty-fourth scheme that your Department has going.

—I know Senator Lewis has difficulty with these big words, but I will say it again: they are called generic technology schemes. There are more big words in the next part of the answer. The four schemes are biotechnology-the generic technologies-information technology, communications technology and new materials technology. Twenty million dollars is to be provided under this scheme in 1988-89 for projects most of which will extend over three years. Already the scheme has been running for just over two years and has been remarkably successful in fostering public and private sector collaboration. As a recent example, the Industry, Research and Development Board announced on Monday of this week grants worth $2.6m for projects in the field of new materials, each involving a high level of technological collaboration. Those collaborative arrangements were between the CSIRO Division of Manufacturing Technology and Wollongong University, and BHP Steel International, Bunge Industrial Steels and Eglo Engineering; between the University of Queensland and Ampol; between the University of Wollongong and C-Ramic Australia, SECO Tools and BHP Steel International; and between the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology organisation and the University of Adelaide with MM Metals Ltd.

ANSWER.PARA: Generic grants usually require collaboration between the private sector and the public sector or else the grant will not be made. The Government has consistently argued that stronger links must be developed between public and private sector organisations in research and development as a means of changing both public sector and private sector cultures. There are a number of other incentives to stimulate private sector research and development, including the discretionary grant scheme, the 150 per cent tax concession, the national teaching company scheme, and the national procurement development program. Since the Government introduced the grants for industry research and development (GIRD) scheme in 1986-87, grants have increased from $11.2m to $33.4m for the current financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and it follows the careful answer he gave yesterday to the effect that no taxpayers' funds were to go by way of grants to the provision of poker machines for the Woden Town Club.
