Since that answer also made clear that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs knew since May of proposals for public underwriting by way of loan of the provision of these poker machines, will the Minister please explain what is the moral difference between taxpayers providing assistance for poker machine purchase on the one hand by grants or on the other hand by loans? Is it correct to interpret yesterday's answer to mean that had the proposal remained one to lend money to underwrite the purchase of poker machines, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs would have raised no objection, as he had raised no objection between May and October, even though there had existed a contingent call on taxpayers' funds from the time the loan was agreed to?

—I do not accept that the assumption that Senator Peter Baume makes in the latter part of the question is the case, and indeed, though I do not have the statement I made yesterday in front of me, the honourable senator keeps contrasting--
—I have.

—Well, in that case the honourable senator should read it more carefully because, as I recall, the contrast is to be made not between a loan and a grant but between a guarantee of a loan provided by a bank and a grant, and I think there is a substantial difference.

—I ask a supplementary question. In view of what the Minister has said, will he please explain what is the moral difference between taxpayers providing assistance for poker machine purchase on the one hand by grant or on the other by giving a guarantee for a loan?

—I am glad that the honourable senator has now got his question in order and is now making the correct contrast between a guarantee of a loan and a grant, and I believe there is a substantial difference. Certainly the Minister himself thought that there was such a substantial difference that he was obliged to take the action which this chamber is aware of.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance and refer to a report in today's Australian about the shadow Minister for Transport, Mr Charles Blunt, criticising cuts to road funds, which on his figures have been cut by $350m in four years and by a further $100m in legislation which was before the House of Representatives yesterday. Will the Government accept the advice of the National Party on road funding and, if so, will it make the necessary adjustments to spending that that would require?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the last part of the question, which asked whether the Government would accept the advice of the National Party on road funding, it depends which bit of advice one is talking about. The advice coming from Mr Blunt yesterday seemed to be that more taxpayers' money should be spent on roads, but the policy put out just over 12 months ago on behalf of the National Party by Senator Stone-or Mr Stone, as he then was-said:

ANSWER.PARA: Cut road grants to the States (and Northern Territory), estimated at $1,200m in 1987-88, to save $120m.

Adjusting for inflation since that 12-month period, the current level of road funding in real terms is $120m higher than that advocated by Senator Stone on behalf of the National Party 15 months ago. The National Party does not seem to be able to make up its mind whether it wants to spend more money on roads or less. What it really wants is to do a bit of cheap political stunting and grandstanding, hoping it can pick up a few more votes in the bush than it has been getting in the past. Its vote has been steadily declining, as it deserves to do. This is a desperate attempt, through a bit of cheap political stunting, in the hope that it can get through all those country newspapers the fact that the National Party is in there fighting for people on the land and in the bush. Of course it is not. If it ever got into government-we have seen the punches that have been telegraphed by Senator Stone-there would be $120m less for road funding. Senator Stone-and I will give him his due for this-is the one person in the whole Opposition who would actually have the courage if he were in a position of power to keep expenditure under control.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security read the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) paper No. 35 on income support policies, taxation and incentives? Has the Minister read that many low income people, especially families with children, have to survive on insufficient nutrition, are unable to afford to heat their homes in winter, are often unable to afford medication and are denied most forms of recreation? I take it that the Minister is getting a briefing from Senator Walsh. Has the Minister read this paper? Has he read that the proportion of families with children in relative poverty has been higher during the 1980s than in the previous decade? Has the Minister read that poverty has increased among prime aged adults and children, with the most significant increases being among single parents and larger families? Has the Minister read that long term unemployed persons have been particularly adversely affected? Has the Minister read that low income families with children and individuals and families with low incomes and high housing costs are among the neediest groups? Has the Minister read that current marginal and average tax rates are appreciably higher for most taxpayers than they were in the 1960s and the 1970s? Has the Minister read that because of the interaction of the social security system and the income tax system many people on low incomes are in poverty traps? Has the Minister read that in many cases a person's equivalent marginal tax rate could be--
—Oh, come on.

—Is the Minister embarrassed by this? It is all set out in the EPAC paper. He can read it all. Has the Minister read that in many cases a person's equivalent marginal tax rate could be above 75 per cent, or in some cases over 100 per cent? Finally, in the light of this report is the Minister prepared to acknowledge that for very many Australians there has been a significant fall in living standards and that the policies of this Government have been misdirected in favour of the Prime Minister's rich mates rather than the ordinary Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read the full report but I have obviously had aspects of it brought to my attention. In answering this question I should bring to Senator Lewis's attention a bit of history in terms of this Government's record in the areas of children and compare it to the record of the previous Howard-Fraser Government. Let us remember that in 1976 under the Fraser-Howard regime, before it started hacking into the living standards of the poor, there were 372,000 children of pensioners and beneficiaries living in that classification. Payments for each child amounted to 15 per cent of the married rate pension. From the period 1975 to 1983-over the seven years of conservative rule-the number grew each year. It grew by 50,000 children a year for almost every year from 1976 to 1982. Then the Howard-Fraser regime destroyed the labour market in 1982-83 by a massive 150,000 children.
—Your trade union mates are destroying the labour market.

—The compassionate Senator Stone was there all the time but he has no recognition of the plight of those people. Over the seven years of the Opposition regime there was an increase of 410,000 children. Their parents were forced into dependency by the direct policies of that Government. Not only should we look at numbers but we should look at the level of support for those children. Whilst the number of children was increasing under the Howard-Fraser regime the income support levels for children also decreased. In 1977 payments were at a level of 15.2 per cent of the married rate pension. By 1983 this had decreased to 11.1 per cent of the married rate pension. I would like to know what record Senator Lewis stands on when he comes in here criticising the Government's record.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us have a look at this Government's record in comparison. We inherited the situation where in 1983 there were 266,900 children dependent on unemployment benefits. We have reduced this number. In January this year there were around 204,940 children dependent on such benefits. We have cut the number of children in unemployment beneficiary families by over 60,000. We have cut the number of children in pensioner and beneficiary families overall. The other important criterion in terms of payments is that we have made very significant improvements in the level of payments for children. We have increased it from 11.1 per cent at the start of 1983 to 14.1 per cent now for children under 13 and 17.2 per cent of the married rate pension for children between the ages of 13 and 15. Our commitment does not end there. The commitment that Senator Lewis referred to is one that is ongoing. Our commitment is to lift the levels to 15 per cent of the married rate pension for children under 13 and to 20 per cent for older children.

Senator Lewis mentioned the EPAC report. EPAC is not the only organisation that has made some judgments in this area. Helen Brownlee of the Institute of Family Studies was commenting on the Government's achievements in this area. She said that the Government's performance was a magnificent achievement. Let us not run away from that. Senator Lewis talked about other aspects of the EPAC report. Let us look at what this Government has done in this area in recent years. It is addressing the problem of poverty traps faced by low income working families, the problem that EPAC addresses. In the 1988-89 Budget we announced changes to the family allowance supplement (FAS) to operate from the start of January 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sit down.

—Senator Lewis asked a long question so he is going to get a full answer. Once the FAS entitlement is determined under the new assessment procedures most families will continue to receive FAS for up to 12 months, regardless of any changes in income. This has been geared very much towards the poverty trap situation that EPAC addresses. There will no longer be an overlap between the withdrawal of FAS and the Medicare levy, another problem in terms of the poverty trap. We will also integrate child payments for pensioners and beneficiaries. As a consequence, because of initiatives involved in this integration and because of other measures to alleviate poverty traps, more than 400,000 pensioners and beneficiaries will be able to get employment by removing that disincentive caused by poverty traps.

ANSWER.PARA: We do not have to look at the other areas such as rent assistance which the Government is increasing in this particular area. It does not just end there. Since coming to office this Government has introduced a number of measures to reduce poverty traps for pensioners, including the 1987 poverty trap measures, increasing the free area of child disregard, the introduction of pensioner earnings credit and the increase in the pensioner rebate. I could go into these at length if honourable senators wanted me to but I will not. I can mention rent assistance, mothers and guardians allowances, additional payments for children and so on. The bottom line is that this Government recognises the special problems of children. We also recognise the special problems faced by those in this area who want to go back into the work place and need assistance to do so. We introduced the Job, Education and Training program to help overcome work force barriers for those families and assist them to escape the poverty cycle.

Senator Lewis mentioned a couple of points about the EPAC report which I should also dwell on. The EPAC report claimed that the numbers of people in poverty have increased in recent years. Let us compare the figures. The figures in the EPAC report are heavily influenced by the choice of years. For instance, the numbers in the EPAC tables compare figures from 1972-73-the height of a somewhat expansionary Whitlam era-with those from 1985-86 and also compare figures prior to the introduction of the family package. I think that that should be recognised. Similarly, the figures on the increase in tax rates compare 1985-86 rates with those of the 1950s and 1960s and, in fact, fail to take into account international trends in tax transfer arrangements. If Senator Lewis wants to get up here and talk about this Government's record and commitment in the area of child poverty, he should do two things: firstly, make an honest comparison and, secondly, look at his Government's record between 1976 and 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister acknowledged that he had not read the whole of the EPAC report; he had read only parts of it. Did he read that part of the report which said that the proportion of families with children in relative poverty has been higher during the 1980s than in the previous decade; that is, during the Fraser Government's decade? If the Minister has read that section, does he acknowledge that there are very many Australians living in poverty under this Government? What does his Government intend to do about it?

—Probably the easiest way to address this problem is to repeat the answer very slowly so Senator Lewis can understand it. The Government has a commitment; the Government is working towards achieving that commitment, and it has made major advances on it. As I said during the first part of my answer, that has been recognised by people such as Helen Brownlee, a recognised worker in this area. I said that the comparison suggested was not appropriate because of the factors I mentioned in the first part of my answer. All I should do, in response to Senator Lewis, is to say, once again, that the Government has a commitment and is working towards achieving that commitment, which is a lot more than the Opposition ever did.
—Would the Minister be prepared to table Senator Walsh's paper from which he was reading?
—There is only one problem with that, Mr President; Senator Walsh still has his paper.
—Order! If the Minister was quoting from a document he can table it if he wants to do so. It is his decision.
—Mr President, I was quoting from my own notes. They were not Senator Walsh's and I do not wish to table them.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to an article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 7 November entitled `Chilean sect pounded by Nazis seek refuge in Australia'. In that article reference was made to Colonia Dignidad, a group of Nazi and ex-Nazi sympathisers, who appear to fear the return of democracy in Chile and wish resettlement in Australia. Will the Minister assure the Senate that such groups and individuals so involved will not be granted immigration to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —The Colonia Dignidad is a secretive commune of mostly German citizens located at Parral, Chile. It is commonly known as the dignity, education and benefactor society. It was founded in 1962 by Mr Paul Schafer who had fled Germany in 1961 while under investigation for alleged sexual abuse of children. He arrived in Chile with 60 adults and children. There were allegations that some of the children were taken from Germany illegally. The commune is now said to comprise some 300 Germans operating a large dairy farm, mine and a hospital which serves the surrounding community. It also maintains an office in Santiago.

ANSWER.PARA: Public allegations, mostly in the German media, have been made about the group for many years. Those allegations include forced labour, sexual abuse, mind-altering drugs, corporal punishment and segregation of men from women and parents from children. The group claims to be simply a disciplined commune which desires privacy. We have no information to indicate that members of the Colonia Dignidad are considering migration to Australia. However, our overseas posts in Santiago and Bonn have been aware of this group for over a year. I should point out that all migration applications are decided on merit. Membership of any group which is engaged in, or supportive of, anti-social or illegal activity would result in rejection of an application.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories say why the people of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) have been left without adequate facilities for the treatment of skin cancer and other dermatological conditions, following the retirement of Royal Canberra Hospital's only dermatologist and the subsequent closure of the dermatology unit at Royal Canberra Hospital? Why has ACT Community Health Services not been able to attract a specialist dermatologist to the ACT health system to treat the reported 5,000 patients on its books, including 300 skin cancer patients? What action will the Minister take to ensure that those requiring these services, including many pensioners and ex-service men and women, are able to receive treatment in the ACT and not have to travel to Sydney or elsewhere to obtain what should be available here in Canberra?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not deny that there is a problem in dermatology in the ACT and in the treatment of patients who are affected. I would include that problem as one of the major issues to be addressed in the ACT. I think that the honourable senator is well aware of the review to be conducted by Dr Kearney which will cover both administrative problems and the sorts of issues that dermatology and the problems associated with maintaining the treatment of patients raise. Hopefully, Dr Kearney will complete that review fairly quickly and I can then announce to the Senate what we will do about the problem.

—Mr President, my question is directed to you. Are you aware that yesterday I sought to have a press release printed by the Senate Printing Unit with an attachment and I was informed that the attached material breached the sexual harassment guidelines, common, I understand, to the Commonwealth Public Service and the Department of the Senate? In other words, the attached material was of such a trashy and offensive nature that the guidelines prevented the Senate Printing Unit being asked to copy it. Further, are you aware that the said material was simply photostats of the covers of X-rated videos which this Government allows to be sold around Australia, through mail order from the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), including stills from those videos which I asked Senator Reynolds about six months ago? Can you indicate whether the rationale behind the guidelines is consistent with the Government's recent decision to allow the sale and distribution of X-rated video material in the ACT to continue? If it is good enough to sell, why is it not good enough for any public servant or Senate staffer to be asked to print it?

—I was made aware of the incident to which Senator Vanston e referred only during Question Time today. I will investigate the facts as she has pointed out to the Senate and give an answer as soon as possible.

—Is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women pleased with the outcome of the first year of implementation of affirmative action legislation? Will the three companies named as not complying be expected to introduce a plan by next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is delighted with the response of companies to the affirmative action legislation. We have had an outstanding compliance rate. All of the 67 higher education institutions have complied with the legislation and only three companies, as Senator Childs indicated, have not complied. What is important in relation to affirmative action and this first reporting procedure is the very outstanding cooperation of businesses throughout Australia. I do not really want to focus on negatives because, after all, a situation involving only three companies is scarcely worth talking about. The companies concerned have already been named in Parliament, and I will comment on them in a moment.

ANSWER.PARA: But I want to focus on some of the very positive statements that have been made by national highly respected companies. I think what they say is an indication that the Government, despite the attitudes of the Opposition, was very much on the right track when it introduced this legislation amidst some uproar by some Opposition members and some controversy. I would like to quote statements that have been made by a number of these companies. First of all, Woolworths Ltd made the following comment:

Woolworth's is giving and will continue to give full support to its program under the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act 1988. The legislation echoes Woolworth's long held policy of ensuring that job applications and staff are treated and promoted on their merit.
ICI Australia Ltd wrote:

ICI commenced equal employment opportunity programs in 1983 before it was a legislative requirement because we recognised it was good business management. If Australia is going to be competitive in the world markets, we can't afford to ignore half our human resources.
Perhaps the three companies that have been named would do well to listen to those words of ICI. Digital Equipment Corporation (Australia) Pty Ltd wrote:

Digital's Australian Affirmative Action Program has been developed in a Company environment fully committed to taking Affirmative Action to provide equal opportunity for all employees. Digital believes this program will assist us in achieving our business goals as well as complementing social and legislative change in the community.
Finally, I wish to refer to another statement which I cannot neglect. The South Australian Gas Company Ltd said:

The greatest benefit of our program has been the realisation and general acceptance that women can, should, and are playing a diverse and important part in an industry which has previously been considered as predominantly a male domain.

It is well known that the three companies referred to by Senator Childs in his question have been named. Those companies are Inghams Enterprises Pty Ltd, which produces chickens; Mathers Enterprises Ltd, a footwear undertaking; and Suttons Motors Pty Ltd, a car sales company. Those companies will have the opportunity to implement a plan of action. Surely these companies will be encouraged to take positive steps by the fact that they are substantially in the minority. The three companies should be looking at what they are missing out on by not taking advantage of affirmative action. In fact, Inghams may find that more of their chickens will come home to roost if it were to take positive steps. I am sure that Mathers, whose stores are so popular with the women of Queensland and New South Wales, may find that it does not pay to be out of step with affirmative action. Finally, I am sure that if Suttons, the car investment company, were to introduce affirmative action it would find that it could drive its dollar further.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware that the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, which sat for four years and on which there was a majority of Labor Members, brought down a recommendation curtailing violence in video material? Can the Minister tell the chamber why the Government has seen the need to set up a Labor back bench working party to look into exactly the same term of reference as the Select Committee did, that is, violence in videos? Is there a time limit for the working party to report or can the working party take another four years to report to Caucus? Why was the Attorney-General not able to get his Bill into the Parliament? Why was the Prime Minister not present in the Caucus during the debate on this issue? Was it because he was playing golf at the time?

—I am aware of the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee which examined much of the ground and material which has been the subject of discussion in this place and in the general community over the last several weeks. I explained fully only a couple of days ago in an answer to Senator Harradine why the parliamentary Labor Party came to the decision it did. I believe that any fair reading of the Hansard report of that answer would be quite adequate in this respect. As to how long this working party might take, I am sure that it will not take the four years which was necessary, apparently, for the deliberations of the committee on which Senator Walters sat. As for the attendance of the Attorney-General in the chamber--
—No, I did not ask that.
—I thought the honourable senator did. If she did not ask that question, I do not need to answer it.
—I asked why wasn't the Attorney-General able to get his Bill up in the Parliament. I asked why the Prime Minister was not in Caucus. I asked whether he was playing golf.

—Mr President, I do not intend to go further than I have in explaining the decision of the parliamentary Labor Party. I will leave it at that. As to whether the Prime Minister was present at a particular meeting of the parliamentary Labor Party, that is none of the honourable senator's business.

—Is the Minister for Consumer Affairs aware of recent press articles which imply that he is planning a mandatory recall of Neroa condoms? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether this is true? Can he shed any light on the allegations that have been made of anti-Japanese discrimination and of inappropriate testing procedures on the part of the Commonwealth Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I suppose this is what one would call a very timely question. The Senate might remember that on 17 October Senator Zakharov asked me a similar question about this incident. At that time I mentioned that the Department of Community Services and Health had undertaken a number of tests in regard to Neroa condoms. I informed the Senate that in fact the condoms had failed the test conducted by the Department. I also outlined that my involvement in the area was as a result of the provisions of the Trade Practices Act which are designed to protect consumers from goods that either will or may cause injury. I also stated that the Government's preferred option in this area is to work the problem out with manufacturers and suppliers. I indicated that a degree of responsibility was being shown by the suppliers in this instance in agreeing to undertake voluntarily to withdraw the goods. I also mentioned-and I should repeat what I said-that tests were conducted by the Department of Community Services and Health as well as by an independent recognised testing authority and both those series of tests showed that the condoms in question failed certain standardised tests. It was very apparent that there was a breach of the Therapeutic Goods Order Australian Standard 1919. The Department of Community Services and Health has been negotiating with the supplier. I think I even thanked Senator Messner for his kind work in obtaining an acceptable agreement at that time.

ANSWER.PARA: The only problem is that since that time, and having placed advertisements in relevant newspapers, the company concerned has not fulfilled the conditions of the agreement with the Department of Community Services and Health. It has failed to contact in writing all known wholesalers, suppliers and retailers of the product and to inform them of the recall. In view of the fact that there has been failure to cooperate with the Department and in view of previous failures, I have raised this matter again with Mr Staples, and he in fact has recently written to me.

Since the product convincingly fails to comply with the Australian standard, I have no choice now but to institute a mandatory recall under the Trade Practices Act to ensure that consumers are protected from the potential health risk associated with the use of these products. I understand that the articles to which Senator Zakharov refers cast some reflection on the testing that has been done within Australia. I state and restate that the testing has been done by recognised authorities. I think in respect of the allegations made in the articles, the person who was testing them was testing them for a laboratory that was registered with the National Association of Testing Authorities and in fact was a person trained in accordance with the guidelines set down by that authority prior to any testing being undertaken.

In the circumstances involved, and in response to Senator Zakharov, there is no question of doubt that the test results performed within Australia are appropriate and satisfactory. In terms of tests taken overseas, the Department here and neither the Minister nor myself have been given adequate results and details of such tests. I think in the light of the fact that the tests conducted within Australia have been done according to our standards, then they are the tests that we have to go by. As a consequence, as I indicated, I have no alternative but to institute a mandatory recall.

There is one other part of the question that Senator Zakharov raised to which I should refer and that is very quickly to rebut any allegations of anti-Japanese discrimination. I find them unacceptable and ridiculous, and I see them as being a very poor attempt to discredit. The allegation has been made that we are introducing this recall because we have not forgotten the war. That is a statement made out of South Australia. I reject that totally and indicate that the Government's decision has been made very much on proper standards and procedures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. There is an Australian Associated Press (AAP) report in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald under the heading `Suva warns Canberra over aid', which includes a statement attributed to the Fijian President, Ratu Sir Penaia Ganilau, whom I met in Sydney last weekend. The passage in question is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The statement claimed Senator Evans now believed the draft constitution was broadly acceptable to the majority of Fiji's people . . .

I simply want to make clear for the record that I made no such statement to Ratu Sir Penaia Ganilau. I am not sure whether the statement that appears in the AAP report is a product of misunderstanding by the President or, as is perhaps more likely, some inadvertent misreporting or misunderstanding by the journalist in question.

The point that I was making to the Fijian President, which is the one that I have made directly to other Fijian spokesmen and I have made constantly in media statements, is that if the draft constitution or any variation on it proves broadly acceptable to all the Fijian people, then Australia will respond accordingly in its policy response. I certainly made no such statement that the present draft constitution was assumed by us to be broadly acceptable. I think it is important that that misunderstanding be cleared up.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday during Question Time Senator Newman asked a question relating to Army rations. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following information: Last year the Army spent $22.2m on rations. This financial year, $26.7m has been allocated. Given a slightly higher carry over of claims from 1987-88, the special provision of $1.4m in 1988-89 is to produce combat ration packs for 1989 and the effect of price increases. The level of funding in Army rations in 1988-89 compared to 1987-88 is very similar. Once funds are allocated to commands, military districts and units, the responsibility for selection and purchase of fresh rations, such as those mentioned by the honourable senator, rests with the local commanders in accordance with the Australian Defence Force rations scale. This gives him or her the discretion to vary the items purchased based on local cost and availability, including seasonal commodities. Currently expenditure is running higher than planned and as a consequence a direction has been issued principally as a reminder to local commanders of the need for economy whilst maintaining the nutritional content based on the rations scale. The rations available remain of a high standard in terms of both quality and quantity. Accordingly, there will be no reduction in rations and quarters charges.

—In response to a question asked by Senator Short of me yesterday, I consulted with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and the answer to the first part of the honourable senator's question is no. The answer to the second part is that Mr Winroe did request, as is his responsibility as Acting Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, advice from the Department about a range of issues relating to staff rationalisation, one of the options being the integration of DAA and Aboriginal Development Commission staff to overcome the work load that exists. The Minister is proceeding with government policy towards the introduction of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented. Yesterday, Senator Robert Ray, the former Minister for Home Affairs, answered a question from Senator McMullan concerning the Castlereagh by-election in 1980 and the tape I tabled of one Mr John Patrick Begg, who boasted that he had arranged for 400 dead men to vote for the Labor Party in that by-election. SPEECH.PARA: My allegations concerned a Wran Government employee boasting of his feats. I am disappointed that Senator Ray would seek to misuse Mrs Curran's concern in the way he has done, as at no time have I mentioned Mrs Curran in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY

DEBATE.TITLE: NEW MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES IN MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology:
Current Australian experience with new management techniques in manufacturing industry.
I have a statement explaining the background to the reference which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Committee intends to evaluate the current experience in Australia with such techniques as Value Added Management, Total Quality Control, Just in Time, Materials Resource Planning and Critical Path Planning. They are all different varieties of, what for Australia, are new management processes.

For our overseas competitors, particularly Northern Europe and Japan, they have been mainstream management techniques for decades. In Australia, particularly since the early 1980s, there have been various attempts to spread these techniques through the manufacturing sector in the hope of ``catching up'' with the competition.
A full evaluation of the experience with modern management systems has not been undertaken to date. The points to be considered are:

the implementation of these management techniques which appears to have failed to recognise the peculiarities of the Australian industrial climate. There seems to be little adaptation for local or plant level environments;

the sufficiency of the effort put into ensuring that the philosophy and practice of these techniques penetrates the whole management system, and not simply the top level and planning departments. In particular, is sufficient education put into middle management and line supervisors to explain the changes to their roles and responsibilities? As often as not many programs have been put in jeopardy by supervisors who see them as threats to their jobs;

the apparent little genuine recognition that the success of these techniques depends on the commitment of the employees and their organisation, and employees' early involvement in the planning and implementation including their degree of control over work processes; and

the existence of infrastructure, both internally in enterprise training and externally in TAFE, Australian Institute of Management etc., to support the changed roles implied in these techniques. Is sufficient emphasis placed in trade training and non-trade training on changing techniques? In particular, is there increased emphasis on responsibility for quality?
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled The Potential of the Kakadu National Park Region, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate the text of the tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
The report results from the Committee's examination of the potential of the Kakadu National Park region with particular reference to:
the nature of the resources available for exploitation and
the impact of the utilisation of these resources, particularly mining and tourism.

This matter was referred to the Standing Committee on National Resources in October 1985. The National Resources Committee received submissions from 69 individuals and organisations and held eleven days of public hearings. It also carried out a number of inspections of the Park region. Other areas were visited to examine, in particular, mining rehabilitation work.

In September 1987, following the reorganisation of the Senate Committees, the inquiry was referred to the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. This Committee (which includes two members of the former National Resources Committee) undertook further briefings in Darwin and carried out an inspection of the Kakadu National Park region. We also received two additional submissions and numerous supplementary submissions. In addition we sought further and updated information on many matters. I would like to acknowledge the many individuals and organisations who gave unstinting assistance to both Committees and without whose help the report could not have been produced.

We have defined the Kakadu National Park region as the area within the outermost boundaries of the Park. Defined in this way the region includes areas such as the Ranger Project area, the Jabiluka project area, the Koongarra Project Area and the Conservation Zone, which are excluded from the Park proper.

The Kakadu National Park region is of immense importance, and not just to Australia. Stages 1 and 2 of the Park, together forming an area of 13 073 square kilometres, are already inscribed on the list of World Heritage Properties and the listing of Stage 3 has been foreshadowed. This listing identifies their environmental importance not just to Australia, but to the world. It recognises the abundant and diverse physical, biological and cultural resources of the region.

At the same time, the region has mineral deposits of world significance. These include not only the uranium deposits which are on a par with the world's largest, but also substantial deposits of gold, platinum and palladium. According to one estimate, for example, the total value of the gold, platinum and palladium deposits in the Conservation Zone exceeds $1.5 billion.

The region is also significant because of its Aboriginal associations and because it supports viable, contemporary Aboriginal communities. Almost all of the 6144 square kilometres of Stage 1 of the Park is Aboriginal land, which has been leased back to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. Nearly seven per cent of Stage 2 of the Park is also owned by Aborigines and the Stage 3 region, including the Conservation Zone is the subject of a land claim by Aborigines.

Quite apart from land ownership however, are the cultural and religious links of Aborigines to the land. The Kakadu region contains the largest and in general the best preserved body of rock art in the world. No one seeing it can fail to be impressed or moved by what is an important part, not just of Aboriginal culture, but of Australian culture.
The very richness and diversity of the Kakadu region means that its potential can be viewed from many different perspectives.
It can be seen as a unique environment that should be protected from the further depredations of man at all costs.
It can be seen as a reservoir of living resources, both native and introduced, that can be exploited commercially.
It can be seen as an area of immense mineral wealth that should be used for the benefit of Australia.
It can be seen as providing a wilderness experience for those wishing to experience nature in their own solitude.
It can be seen as an area providing stunning scenery and wildlife that should be made available to the many by providing the necessary infrastructure.
It can be seen as an area unparalleled for the opportunities it offers to research into the ecosystems of the wet dry tropics.
And, because the Park itself encompasses 19804 square kilometres, it can also be seen as an area able to meet all these needs.
Overlying all of these other uses is the need to be responsive to the Aboriginal owners and to assist them in maintaining their choices about the way they wish to live in the region.

The Committee has gathered evidence on the various resources of the region, how they are being used, how they might be used and what impacts result from their utilisation. In all the report makes 39 recommendations which address matters relating to the use and the management of the Park region. They are intended to ensure that the potential benefits of the region are realised in such a way that the natural beauty and environmental integrity of the Park remain undamaged. They are also directed towards ensuring that the rights of the Aborigines living in the area can be exercised freely and are not jeopardised by any of the commercial or other activities taking place.

Tourism is the most important and pervasive use of the Park itself. It is the Northern Territory's second most important industry after mining and Kakadu National Park is one of the most critical components of that industry.

Visitors from Australia and around the world are attracted by the stunning scenery; the variety of plants and animals, including the crocodiles and especially the birds; and the magnificent rock art and other archaeological sites. In 1987 there were 185 000 visitors to the Park with, on average, each visitor staying more than three days.

The Committee noted the very rapid increase in the number of tourists visiting the region and examined their impact on the Aborigines resident in the Park and on the Park environment. The report contains a number of recommendations designed to remove or minimise the damaging impacts that have occurred, or might occur.

Several of these recommendations are intended to ensure that people visiting the region are given accurate information about the area so that they can properly appreciate why certain restrictions apply and understand the vulnerability of art work and other features of the Park. Combined with necessary display and other facilities these should add to the enjoyment of visitors while preserving the important sites from unnecessary damage.

The rapid increase in tourist numbers over recent years is beginning to put a strain upon some of the facilities in the Park, although the opening of a new motel at Jabiru will have a beneficial effect.

The report recommends that a series of charges be introduced for entry into the Park and for the use of facilities such as camping grounds. The fees levied should be related to the provision, improvement and maintenance of services and facilities in the Park. By introducing the fees in association with an advance booking system it should be possible to ensure that the most popular areas and facilities can be made available to the maximum number of visitors in a fair and equitable manner.

It is likely that the number of visitors will continue to grow and the report recommends that a long-range tourist strategy be developed for the Park. This should examine the growth in tourist numbers at particular destinations, the maximum visitor carrying capacity of different areas and the optimum pattern of tourist infrastructure.

Exploration for minerals or mining is expressly prohibited on any lands within Kakadu National Park by 1987 amendments to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. However, a number of mineral rich areas with the region are not contained within the Park. These include the Ranger, Koongarra, and Jabiluka mining project areas, and the Conservation Zone in the Gimbat and Goodparla area.

Mining activity in the region has had an economic impact not just on the local economy but on Australia as a whole. The Ranger Uranium Mine itself employs around 500 people and total indirect employment is put at 485, not including those in government departments and agencies providing services in Jabiru or monitoring the impact of uranium mining in the region.

The Committee examined the environmental impact of Ranger and has made a number of recommendations relating to the need for continued monitoring, particularly in relation to water management. The report also discusses the impact of the Ranger mine and the royalties received from the mine, on the local Aboriginal population.

The Jabiluka and Koongarra deposits are not at present being mined. The Jabiluka uranium/gold deposit has a gross value in excess of $A20 billion while the non-discounted ten year total export revenue from the Koongarra deposit is estimated at $1.76 billion.

The report does not make any recommendations as to whether permission should be given for Jabiluka and Koongarra mines to go into production. The view of the majority of the Committee was that a wide range of matters would need to be considered in making such recommendations, including the state of the world market for uranium, a matter outside the terms of reference for our inquiry. However, in saying this I note that both the Jabiluka and Koongarra project environmental impact statements have been approved by the Government and that the companies responsible for both of these projects have reached the necessary agreements with the relevant Aboriginal groups.

The Coronation Hill gold, platinum and palladium deposit is valued at over $500 million. It is located in the Conservation Zone, which is considered highly prospective. One estimate is that there are more than $1.5 billion of in situ mineral resources to be discovered in the Zone. An environmental impact statement for the Coronation Hill project has not yet been finalised. The report makes recommendations on the particular matters to be covered by the environmental impact statement which, in its view, will need special scrutiny given the mines location near the South Alligator river. It also recommends arrangements to ensure that the site will be effectively rehabilitated should mining take place.

Exploration and mining activity in other parts of the Conservation Zone would need to be carried out in an equally sensitive way if environmental damage is to be avoided. A further factor requiring extreme sensitivity in this region is that a land claim has been lodged by the Jawoyn people over the whole of the area covered by the Conservation Zone. This claim has not yet been heard. The report makes recommendations designed to ensure that any delays in settling the land claim will not result in the Aboriginal interests in the area, including those relating to their sacred sites, being ignored, and that the views of the Jawoyn people on exploration and mining in the area are taken fully into account.

One side effect of mining in the region has been the establishment of a town within the Park, at Jabiru. The town was planned for 3 500 people but its present population is only 1 200. In some ways that town has been the biggest impact of mining of the region. Although originally a purely mining town, with the recent opening of the crocodile shaped motel developed by the Gagudju association with the royalties obtained from uranium mining, it will begin to play an increasing role in tourism. We have recommended that the Office of the Supervising Scientist be given a clearly defined responsibility to monitor the environmental impact of Jabiru and that proposed developments within the town be subject to environmental evaluation.

Fish and buffalo are two of the major living resources being exploited in the region. We have not opposed the continuation of recreational fishing, recognising the important role that it plays in tourism in the Park. However, the majority of the Committee believes that the commercial exploitation of native living resources is incompatible with the high standards of resource preservation required by World Heritage listing, and the report recommends the phasing out of both commercial fishing and crabbing, as well as the maintenance of the existing ban on hunting. Buffalo are in a different category from fish in that they are introduced and have been responsible for considerable damage to the environment. Moreover, they can serve as a resource for exotic bovine diseases. However, buffalo also appeal to tourists and have become a favoured source of fresh meat for the Aboriginal population. For this reason the report recommends that the feasibility be examined of establishing a disease free herd or a buffalo park in the region.

The issues addressed in this report all relate in one way or another to the management of the Park. Because of the deficiencies we have identified in Park management, and particularly to ensure greater consultation with all interested parties, the report recommends that a Board of Management be created to manage the Park.

The Committee also examined in some detail the role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in the Park and in the region, and its relationships with the various bodies with which it has to deal. The majority report recommends that the Government urgently consider locating all operations of the OSS in the Northern Territory, and that the need to strengthen and increase the responsibilities of the Office be examined. In order to ensure that the Office of the Supervising Scientist maintains its present level of cost recovery, the report also recommends that a levy be placed on exploration and mining activity in the Conservation Zone in line with the responsibilities of the Office in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts has attached to it a minority report, probably one of the more substantial minority reports that have been brought down in the Senate. It is over 100 pages long and indicates the clear division in views of members of the Committee. The minority report is signed by me, Senator Panizza and Senator McGauran because we found ourselves separated in some fundamental areas. Perhaps I could just go through some of those.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say at the outset that there was a great deal of debate, for instance, on the simple matter of the aesthetic beauty of the Kakadu National Park itself and the various parts of it. But of course these differences are quite natural because judgments of this type are subjective and depend on individual tastes and perceptions. It is our view that the description provided in the majority report, without being unkind to the authors, more resembled a travelogue one would expect to find in a glossy brochure rather than a dispassionate and objective description of a park. Accordingly we dissented and provided our own description of the park. The evidence that we received varied as to the aesthetic value of the park and various parts of it. For instance, a Professor Messel gave evidence on a number of matters and described the park in this way:
Do not get carried away with all the nonsense you read down here-
as I recall it, his evidence was given in Canberra-
about the wonderful place it is up there. Ask us, we will tell you.
The Professor had spent some considerable time doing research in the park. He continued:

At most of the places there is nothing to see except bloody mud banks, mangroves and a few buffaloes staggering around. When you get into the upstream sections, up in the hills and rocky places, the scenery is very spectacular but for the 100-odd kilometres downstream to the mouth there is very little to see. The crocodiles are the most interesting things. The bird life is very scarce.
He went on:

I would say that if you did not have crocodiles below Cahills Crossing and the barramundi were as depleted as they are, I have no idea why people would ever go there. If you went you would go once to see the mangroves and return and never go again and tell all your friends not to bother.

Once you have been there for an hour you have seen it all . . . The upstream sections of Kakadu National Park are very nice but, as I said, once you get beyond Cahills Crossing there is nothing to see . . . If you have a lot of dangerous crocodiles swimming around in the water and tour boats going over there-
that is of some interest.
I do not necessarily subscribe to that description of the park, but it certainly fits comfortably, in my view, with very large parts of it.

I have to say, in referring to another group which gave evidence and which has been quite vocal on the issue of the intrinsic beauty of the park, that it is not without significance that by and large those who are opposed ideologically to uranium mining within Kakadu, or uranium mining per se, are interestingly enough able to find beauty in all areas of the park. To these people even the most scorched, barren, windblown areas of sandy spinifex have a natural and unique, breathtaking beauty. I believe that there are parts of the park which are very beautiful and very spectacular to all of us. I refer to the Jim Jim Falls, Obiri Rock, Twin Falls, UDP Falls and the escarpment at Cooinda, and the area at Yellow Waters is in parts very beautiful, as is the flood plain region. But it is not unreasonable to say that there are thousands and thousands of hectares of boring, monotonous country very similar to millions of hectares of country that one will find in any part of the north of Australia. The most charitable view of a contrary opinion is that it defies logic. If it were not for the discrete areas of natural beauty in the park, I suspect that it would be like some other parts of Australia-somewhere one goes when one is on the way somewhere else. Professor Messel, for his money, found the area decidedly uninteresting.

Perhaps Kakadu came very much to the fore of tourist interests and news as a result of the movie Crocodile Dundee, but the contribution made by that movie to Kakadu was to distort the picture of the scenery of the region. The areas in the park shown in Crocodile Dundee were many miles apart and, as I recall the film showed UDP Falls, Twin Falls and parts of Yellow Waters. But, looking at the movie, one would not realise that poor old Mick was walking hundreds of miles a day with the delicious Miss Kozlowski to get from one point to another. That highlights the fact that vast areas of the park are uninteresting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it proper in this place for you to refer to a women as delicious?
—It is no problem for me, not in the slightest-delectable, delicious, delightful, however Senator Button likes it.
—Don't make it worse.

—It is interesting that I can describe a person in that way and do not find it offensive, but Senator Coates is happy to have women being used and abused and appearing in X-rated videos and he does not find that a bit offensive. But the moment I use a description of the kind I did, in his eyes that is offensive. I think that is a subjective, hypocritical judgment, to say the least. However, she is a very attractive lady by any measure.
—How about getting on to the report.

—My comments clearly interested Senator Coates otherwise he would not have interjected. There are some very attractive parts of the park, but the movie Gallipoli could easily have been made in that park. There are attractive areas and areas that are not quite so attractive. I raise those matters not out of idle curiosity but because it raises an issue of the emotional debate with impinges on people's judgement as to the virtue of the World Heritage listing of the park and the appropriate declaration, and also consideration of mining within the region. I remind the Senate that the total areas of stages 1, 2 and 3 of the park amount to 1,980,400 hectares. The Ranger uranium mine, for instance, covers an area of 0.02 per cent of those two million hectares. If a tourist entered the park looking for the Ranger mine, I do not know whether he would die of thirst or starvation but he certainly would never find the mine.
—Oh!

—Senator Coates demonstrates the difficulty that faced the Committee. Because my views do not agree with his they have to be found to be wrong. One wonders why it is difficult to get a consensus on a committee with people like Senator Coates sitting in judgment upon it. He thinks that there is room for one opinion and that is his. That is very sad for all of us.
—Don't be like that. There is no need to be like that.

—I am a charitable soul, Senator Button, and you have touched the more generous part of my soul. My objection to much of the material offered by the anti-uranium lobby is that it was presented when it was known to be factually untrue. Much of it was presented in a highly emotional way. The movement against uranium mining was as bad as anybody else. Its evidence can be found in part in the majority report. I can only assume that it was left to the majority report to show the quality of some of the evidence that was given to us.

SPEECH.PARA: No technical evidence was offered which demonstrated that uranium mining at Ranger had had any deleterious effects on the ecology or had in any way damaged the environment beyond the fact that the mine was physically there. Absolutely no evidence was given that showed any detrimental effect on the ecosystem. The Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS) made it quite clear that in its view mining could continue in the park without in any way being detrimental to the park. It should be remembered that the Ranger mine has now been subject to around 1,000 inquiries and reports, including 150 into the tailings dam. The Office of the Supervising Scientist, which is responsible for environmental standards at Ranger, has a staff of over 80 and has spent so far some $42.5m in monitoring the effect of mining in the park. The Supervising Scientist, in all his annual reports, has found nothing of consequence or significance to indicate that Ranger's presence in the park is having any environmental impact.

The sad fact is that the poor quality of some of the evidence proved that those who have an ideological or philosophical objection to mining, milling or use of mining promptly jettisoned any facade of intellectual rigour and cast their arguments into the cloudy mire of the unknown. When it was able to be demonstrated that mining has had no deleterious effect on the park-and the evidence that led to that conclusion was compelling-we found that the anti-uranium people fell back on the premise that there was much still to be learnt about the effects of mining in the park and that a great deal is still not known. That ignores the fact that the Ranger uranium mine has been there for eight years and that there have been 1,000 reports and inquiries into its effects and 150 reports relating to the tailings dam, and that the OSS has spent some $46m on monitoring. It should be clearly understood that the anti-uranium mining lobby is not one constituency. It is a coalition of different groups with different agendas. The one significant part of that coalition is the group who are opposed to nuclear weapons. Their essential objection is not to mining within the park; it is to the use of uranium in weapons manufacture. Part of their agenda is to deny access for this purpose. It is not remarkable or surprising to find that I have not yet discovered one person who is opposed to the manufacture of nuclear weapons who can find that uranium mining can take place in the park. Exactly the same people find environmental problems as those who would wish there not to be the manufacture of nuclear weapons. When one is taking evidence it is not to the credit of witnesses who, rather than put their agenda on the table, find dishonest ways of seeking to deny access to the park. I, in common with my colleagues, would defend with my last breath those who take up and fight for any cause, whatever its merit, provided they do so honestly and with conviction and not with dishonesty and connivance.

As I interpret the evidence, the interesting thing is that perhaps uranium mining has far less potential to damage the environment of Kakadu, if it is properly managed, than does the mining of many other minerals and metals. One might find that due to mismanagement the elements resulting from the mining of copper, lead or zinc, could be decidedly more detrimental to the environment than elements resulting from the mining of uranium. However, uranium is elevated and then shrouded in mystery, fear and danger. Of course, as our minority report states radon gas and radium are perfectly capable of management and control.

A number of matters deserve some attention. Perhaps I could turn for a moment to the water that is retained within the Ranger mine area. Much was made of the danger that that water poses to the park. Certainly no evidence was given to the Committee to suggest that that water is likely to be a danger in any way. I remind the Senate that, for instance, on occasions water is released from retention pond 4. It is proposed also to release water, if necessary, from retention pond 2. As I think we point out in our minority report, water from retention pond 4 simply is water which is run off over waste dump rocks. By definition, that is material that has not been milled as overburden and contains less than 0.23 per cent uranium. To put it in some sort of perspective, the water found in retention ponds 2 and 4 is very nearly of drinking water standards. In fact, it is quite safe to drink. The water from retention pond 2 is simply rain water trapped after running off the area of the mine plant and, as I said, undiluted it meets the Australian drinking water standards, with the exception of one or two elements. However, we had evidence to suggest that that water would have a vile effect on the ecology of the area. That has not been found to be the case.

Perhaps one of the more significant recommendations that was made by the minority report was that which said that mining ought to commence at Jabiluka and Koongarra. On the evidence, we could find no reason why those mining operations should not begin immediately. Both the companies concerned have fulfilled their responsibilities in respect of the environmental impact statements. In the case of Koongarra an environmental impact statement for the project was prepared in 1979. In 1981 the Minister advised that there was no environmental objection to approval being given for the project. The minority report stated:
The company was able, in the words of the majority report, to confirm that:

following the preparation of the environmental impact statement for the project, it had been informed in September 1981 that the then Minister for Environment, Housing and Community Development had advised that there was no environmental objection to approval being given to the project. Environmental requirements for the project have been endorsed by the Commonwealth, the Northern Territory, the Northern Land Council and the Company. Draft applications filed in 1982 and 1983 under the Uranium Mining (Environment Control) Act 1978 to mine and construct a uranium mill facility were approved, among others, by the Commonwealth Departments of Environment, ANPWS, the Australian Radiation Laboratory, the Office of the Supervising Scientist, the Northern Land Council and the Northern Territory Conservation Commission.

I might just add that the royalties flowing to the Aboriginal community from the operation of that mine will amount to $256m during the life of the mine. The status of the Jabiluka project is as follows:

All conditions and requirements of the Federal and Northern Territory Governments have been met. An agreement has been entered into with the Northern Land Council and approved by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. A mineral lease was issued by the Northern Territory Government on 12 August 1982 on the advice of the then Minister for Resources and Energy administering section 41 of the Atomic Energy Act.

One of the other recommendations of material consequence flowing from the minority report was our view that it was suitable to apply a multiple land use to Kakadu National Park. It was a view supported by the Western Australian State Government in its submission No. 43. Also it was supported by the Northern Territory Government. We were ably assisted in our deliberations by the support of the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, when he said:

. . . subject to appropriate protection there ought to be no intrinsic rational reason why a multiple land use regime should not be established for national parks, which already accommodate a variety of different land uses anyway, such as tourism and so on, and in some cases agriculture. Therefore, there ought to be in principle no objection to a wider ranging multiple land use regime.
He then went on to describe much of the area as `clapped out buffalo country'. I make no judgment about that except to say that there are parts of the park to which that description is appropriate.

There is one other matter I wish to raise at the moment concerning the interaction between the Coronation Hill joint venture partners, the Jawoyn community, the Sacred Sites Authority and the Northern Land Council. I make it clear that I speak for myself when I say that on the basis of the evidence provided to the Committee in my judgment there is reason for grave concern as to the status of the relationship between the Jawoyn Aboriginal community and the personalities within the Northern Territory Sacred Sites Authority. I am far from satisfied that the Sacred Sites Authority reflects in its conduct or attitude the views of the traditional owners or the majority of the Jawoyn people. Regrettably, I have been drawn to the conclusion that in particular Mr Cooper of the Sacred Sites Authority has his own agenda for the mining of uranium in particular and mining in general.

My view is that the Jawoyn people are not opposed to mining at Coronation Hill and most of them do not consider the Coronation Hill site as significant, as was made clear in the evidence given to the Committee. However, the Sacred Sites Authority, or at least Mr Cooper from the Authority, and characters or personalities within the Northern Land Council clearly are opposed to that mining. I suppose that it is not without significance that at the 1 July meeting called to approve mining-this is referred to in our report-notwithstanding three-quarters of an hour of haranguing of the Jawoyn people by Mr Cooper, approval for mining was given. However, a subsequent meeting was held on 4 July which was attended by what one might describe as the heavies of the Northern Land Council, people such as Robert Lee, Raymond Fordimail, Mick Dodson and one or two others. We then found that the decision was reversed. I put it to the Senate that the second meeting was dominated by the Northern Land Council and the Jawoyn people were bullied and harassed into agreeing to the decision.

It should be understood that from the very first day the Northern Land Council and the Sacred Sites Authority were involved in shaping events. It is not without significance to note, as does our minority report on page 304, that on 17 September 1985 the Northern Land Council contacted the Coronation Hill Joint Venture partners to ask them what was going on at Coronation Hill. On the same day, after they were accordingly advised, a request was made to list the area as a sacred site. On that same day, if my memory serves me correctly, Mr Cooper of the Sacred Sites Authority was found on Coronation Hill's licence area. When he was asked to leave, it was with some reluctance he gave his name and his responsibilities.

Mr Ellis, in evidence, said that Mr Cooper must have been lost; that he was in the Eva Valley area updating the information that the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority had. However, my further information is that in fact Mr Cooper went directly from Katherine to Coronation Hill and so returned upon being asked to leave the site.

I have drawn the conclusion that since day one the Sacred Sites Authority and the Northern Land Council have-in my view, with growing enthusiasm-opposed mining at Coronation Hill; but I do acknowledge that the Sacred Sites Authority chose not to reverse the permit to explore in the region following the 4 July meeting. However, as our minority report says, and as is shown by the evidence given by the Jawoyn people at Barunga, the Jawoyn people are not opposed to mining at Coronation Hill, and on the evidence they never have been.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of them.

—It was suggested to us by Mr Cooper that they did not understand what would result from exploration and that the approvals that have been granted were granted in an incremental way, and the ultimate result would not be understood. However, I remind the Senate that Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd itself took the Aboriginal community to Groote Eylandt to give them first-hand knowledge and experience of the applications of exploration, mining, blasting, drilling and open cut operations. The Aboriginal community returned from Groote Eylandt and declared its support for mining, as is shown in the evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: We were told also by Mr Cooper and two members of the Jawoyn community-as I remember it was Raymond Fordimail and Peter Jatbula-that the Jawoyn people working on Coronation Hill would withdraw their labour in the event that they were so asked by those two elders. At a subsequent meeting held by the Jawoyn people they resolved that they would continue to work on the site. There are about 50 or 60 further Jawoyn people who have their names down for employment, and a number of them live at Coronation Hill. There is nothing in the evidence I can find other than that of Peter Jatbula and Raymond Fordimail, as I recall, that leads us to believe that mining is opposed on Coronation Hill. I suggest that those who have not already done so might care to glance at that evidence which was taken at Burunga.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in camera evidence.
—It is available now because the report has just been tabled.
—Only what you put in your report. What about the rest of it? It is very selective.

—It is all there. I went to a great deal of trouble to ensure that all the evidence was there. It is very clear that there is support for mining. Nipper Brown, who claimed to be the most senior of the witnesses, said he was quite happy with mining at Coronation Hill; quite happy with exploration at Coronation Hill. Sandy Barroway said exactly the same thing.

SPEECH.PARA: The sad thing for the Aboriginal community is that I have no doubt that the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority and the Northern Land Council will round up one or two Jawoyn people with their normal tactics of intimidation and convince them to say publicly that they are opposed to mining, when previously people like Nipper Brown, Sandy Barraway and the more senior-in some cases, the most senior-members of the Jawoyn community have said they give their unqualified support to mining by BHP at Coronation Hill. They have also expressed their satisfaction with their negotiations with BHP and with the conduct of BHP. I have no doubt that now we will find the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority trotting out people who will be giving different evidence, and that is a tragedy for the Aboriginal community. When these people with their hidden agendas move on, who will be left to pick up the pieces? It will be the Aboriginal community. These people will go on to some new cause, some newfound ambition, and the Aboriginal community will be left with the pain and suffering that will be inflicted on them by these people who have used them in a way which is disgraceful. It is no credit to those who ought to know better.
Mr Acting Deputy President, I regret that it was necessary for us to have a minority report, but the differences were, as you can gather from the expressions so far, quite substantial.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne, a few moments ago, by way of answering an interjection from Senator Button, spoke about his soul. I am reminded of the opening words of the rhetorical question in the poem:

SPEECH.PARA: Breathes there the man, with soul so dead,
Who never to himself hath said,
This is my own, my native land?

I wonder whether Senator Crichton-Browne and those who are responsible for this minority report have considered that in dealing with the Kakadu National Park we are dealing with one of the largest and most pristine natural areas not only in Australia but in the whole world, and that we have a responsibility to not only the present generation but future generations to look after that area, which has values that far exceed the mere mining and tourist values to which Senator Crichton-Browne and his colleagues have devoted so much intense interest in their minority report.

TALK.START.PARA: —His colleagues have not spoken yet; what are you talking about?

—I have your minority report in front of me, Senator. I would like to address a few remarks initially to the matter of the Kakadu National Park itself. I remind honourable senators that in attempting to protect large areas for national parks-and I emphasise the words `large areas' because that is a point that Senator Crichton-Browne has referred to in a certain pejorative way-the necessity to preserve large areas relates to the necessity to preserve a sufficiently diverse genetic base to ensure that those areas can continue, even given very significant environmental changes. Anybody who considers the future and the past of the Kakadu area will know that the extensive wetland areas which are a very important component of Kakadu have, in the relatively recent past, speaking geologically, been under the sea and, in the relatively near future, given the greenhouse effect, are likely to be under the sea again. We already have the experience of highly competent scenic photographers going to Kakadu and saying that they want to photograph some of those areas while they are still available.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to recognise that the shape of Kakadu over the next several centuries will probably be very significantly different from the shape of Kakadu as we see it today. It becomes extremely important to protect those large areas so that the genetic diversities which now exist on the flood plains can continue to exist as those areas recede inland.

The Kakadu area is one that I have taken a particular interest in over a long time. I have been a member of the Australian Conservation Foundation Council since 1973, which predates the establishment of the Kakadu National Park, and I visited that area long before there was a park there. I am particularly concerned that after so many years we still hear from people like Senator Crichton-Browne that the area has values in such a limited range of exposures and human experiences.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't discuss values; I was talking about aesthetic beauty.

—Let me pick up that point about aesthetic experience. I do not know whether Senator Crichton-Browne has been out in what he describes as the very uninteresting and arid back country of South Australia, out on gibber plains where one has to almost get down with a magnifying glass to find the small species of plants and turn over rocks to find lizards. It is hard to find much life at all in that country. Frankly, I find the experience of being alone in such a vast desert a very moving and valuable experience. To sit out there at night-time under stars which are so bright that one feels one can almost reach up and pluck them out of the heavens, and to be in a stillness without intrusion from vast numbers of tourists, is an extremely valuable and very moving experience. Senator Crichton-Browne would deny that experience to many people because he wants to pack as much mining, tourism, fishing and other activities into those areas as possible. That is quite clear from the minority report.
—Yes, just keep it for you.
—Let me pick up Senator Panizza's point. Page 250 of the minority report states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Australian's environment ought to be available for all Australians, not just healthy hikers.

We have seen the likes of Senator Panizza wanting to put cable cars up to the top of Ayers Rock, to put roads into areas that are pristine, natural areas and to make them available to the most infirm people in wheelchairs in the country. What the honourable senator has said is that he will destroy the environment to make it available to all Australians. I make the point that that process destroys most of the very values that he is trying to make available. There are areas which are intrinsically worth preserving for their own sake and which in that process of preservation will be available only to those who are prepared to put a pack on their back and walk in there. Even then this extremely valuable experience will only be available to relatively small numbers of people at a time. To simply say that it is selfish to deny those experiences to all Australians and to so mess up the environment in an attempt to make them available is simply to deny those experiences to any Australian. That is the end result of the attitude which I find repeatedly coming from the minority report.

We find in the report the statement that the low land is very monotonous. The implication of that statement is quite clear; that is, that there are many other representations of that type of country elsewhere. Within Kakadu that low land area has been protected from the intrusion of foreign species, something which the Kakadu Park authorities have found quite difficult. In other areas those same representations of that so-called monotonous land are not protected from the intrusions of mining, roads and all sorts of other developments.
