As a representation of that so-called monotonous country, from the biological point of view, it is important to have substantial representation of that country within national parks.

Page 248 of the report says that there should be a commitment to `opening up' more archeological and art sites. Again, it is extremely moving to stand alone in front of Aboriginal art works which have been there for thousands of years to get some sense of the environment in which those art works were put down when populations were small and when the areas were isolated. There was a sense of the human being only one element in the environment, and by no means the dominant element. That sense and experience is simply not possible when there are thousands of tourists trooping past, pushing and shoving and simply looking at the art works. The sense that comes through in the minority report is that tourism is all about the sense of sight, about looking at things. We get no idea that it understands that being a visitor into a natural area also involves the sense of oneness with nature, of being alone with nature, the ability to be private, to be quiet, to listen, and to smell. Those are also very important human senses which not too many centuries ago were within the range of everybody's experience. But the way the Opposition is going-and I must say a great number of people on the dominant side of the Government would seek to open everything up to exploitation-those experiences are going to be denied to all future generations.

The Coronation Hill site is mentioned in the report. The Coronation Hill proposed developers have spoken about these minerals-particularly, gold, platinum and palladium-being strategic minerals. Presumably they are the sorts of minerals that in times of world shortage, in times of imposition on trade restrictions or in times of warfare would be absolutely vital to Australia's survival. That is what I understand is meant by strategic minerals. Yet what does the Opposition want to do? It wants to open the mine now and flog the minerals off in a few years or decades. They are not going to be there as strategic resources. One of the things one notices about resources is that if they are not exploited now they are still resources which remain there for future generations. In much of the Opposition's rhetoric it talks about the resource richness of Australia. Yet it still wants to get into those small parts-and I stress small parts-of this country which are set aside as national parks. If we are so resource rich let us look at exploiting-and I use that word quite deliberately-those resources which are not in national parks. The resources in national parks are not going to go away. If the next generation or the generation after that desperately needs to get at the platinum, palladium and gold in Coronation Hill those resources will still be there.

A moment ago I used the term `resource exploitation'. Unfortunately, in several places Senator Crichton-Browne talked about resource development. There is no such thing as a resource development. Resources are not developed; they are exploited. I wish to quote yet again Amery Loven's expression which I think very aptly describes the process. He said, `Whoever talks about developing a bank account by taking money out of it?'. That is precisely what we are doing with resource exploitation. There is no advantage to Australia in exploiting resources by the liquefaction of those resources, that is turning resources into money, if that money is not used for durable purposes. If it is frittered away it is not a resource at all. I am really surprised at the Opposition, which has been highly critical of Aboriginal people in recent days for frittering away taxpayers' money. The example is before them of the way in which resources can be misapplied and cease to be resources. Yet it talks about developing resources in the ground-in other words, turning them into money-without expressing any concern for what that money is used to provide. If it is used to provide services such as education and to raise the cultural levels of society-those elements which are sustainable in the long term-it is indeed providing resources which are valuable. Many of the things on which money is spent are simply not of any long term value, so the resources simply cease to be resources in any sense whatsoever.

The Opposition, unfortunately and very disappointingly, has drawn on evidence which was given in camera to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. I find that distressing and distasteful because the evidence was not given to the Committee to be used in that way. It was given in camera; it was private information for that Committee. Moreover, if that practice becomes at all widespread, it will seriously inhibit the ability of parliamentary committees to have witnesses appear before them. Witnesses simply will not be prepared to come forward if they know that their evidence, which is given honestly in camera-in secret, to be heard only by that committee-is exposed to the public gaze.

I have become convinced that the Jawoyn people do not want Coronation Hill to be mined. I think that Senator Zakharov attempted to point out, by way of interjection, a few moments ago that, as recently as last week, the Jawoyn people came down here and spoke to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other Cabinet Ministers. They pointed out that they did not want either exploration or exploitation to occur in what they regard as the sickness country, which includes Coronation Hill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you just talk about your part of the report.

—I am glad that Senator Panizza raised that point because it was a source of great worry to me that it was very difficult to get written into the majority report protection of the potential claim which the Jawoyn people may be successful in prosecuting in relation to a land claim over the area, including Coronation Hill. I am pleased that the majority report includes that suggestion of protection, such that, if that land claim is successful, mining royalties for those people can be recognised.
—You believe in retrospectivity; that's why.

—The Opposition wants to rely entirely on the trickery of the timing of particular provisions, when there is a serious clash of cultures in relation to the way in which decisions are made, to deny people what is their legitimate right or, should I say, potentially their legitimate right as I am not foreclosing the option that their application may be unsuccessful. But, if it is successful and takes some months to prosecute, why should those people be denied that right simply because of the time required for that process compared with the few minutes required for a signature on a piece of paper giving Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd the ability to proceed with its mining operation?

SPEECH.PARA: For the reasons which I indicated earlier, I believe that the whole of the Kakadu area, including the so-called conservation zone-it is euphemistically called a conservation zone, but it is actually a zone which has been set aside for mining exploration and includes the whole of the relevant catchment-should be set aside as a national park. The evidence is clear that it is important that that be done because the area will undergo very significant environmental changes within the lifetime of the children who only a short time ago were in the upper gallery. Of necessity there will be very significant migrations of species within that zone. If that large area is not protected, we will simply see mass extinction of species. It is unfortunate, I think, that we will find within the lifetime of many of those children who were in the gallery a moment ago many of our other smaller national parks will be simply quite incapable of doing the job for which Kakadu has been set aside. Kakadu is a World Heritage area. It is a large area. It is very worthy of protection. It is certainly not appropriate for the Opposition to attempt to impose what it calls multiple land use but which is simply a euphemism for getting in there and ripping the guts out of any piece of territory that it wishes to do that to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The utter hypocrisy of Senator Coulter's statements lies in the fact that he depends on this nation's wealth and the taxes of ordinary Australians to keep him in his state of karma and his desert experiences that we have had to endure during his speech. He never gave any credit to the Opposition for declaring Kakadu as a park. We simply heard about his pitiful desert experiences. We must not forget that those who put their name to the minority report come from the land. They have a closer attachment to the environment than he and his lousy mob of Australian Democrats have ever had. It is an insult to declare that any member of the National Party of Australia would not have an affinity with the land.

SPEECH.PARA: I join my colleagues who put down the minority report. Before discussing the report in depth, I congratulate the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, Senator Black. Quite obviously, from the great array of views that we have heard here already, he had a difficult task. He did such a great job that I think it is about time he placed himself in a good position to move to the front bench, removing a few of those non-performing Ministers, particularly those from the right wing in Victoria. Certainly Senator Black has my support in that respect. In fact, I am thinking of writing a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to that effect.

A great variety of views has been expressed. The view has been put that the many untapped deposits in Kakadu, which would provide great wealth, need to be mined or exploited. There is the other extreme view that the area should be held purely as an environmental zone. The extreme view is that there should be no mining exploration at all. We consider that that is utterly unrealistic, uneconomical and out of touch with the great majority of Australians. The minority report clearly sets out a view that is a balance between the ability to maintain the park as a conservation zone-a World Heritage listed area-so we can enjoy the great features of Kakadu National Park and at the same time exploit the mineral deposits in that area. Regrettably, we were unable to hand down a unanimous report.

The crux of the difference between the minority report and majority report lies in the very fact that we believe in multiple land use. The minority report makes that very clear and it is very decisive. We accept that Kakadu National Park is a magnificent conservation area and is one of Australia's greatest tourist attractions. That is undeniable. Of course, we uphold the rights of the Aboriginal people within the area of the Kakadu Park. However, this in no way negates the ability to exploit the great mining deposits in that region.

In fact, the area has a very long history of multiple land use. Next to Ayers Rock, Kakadu is the second most popular tourist attraction in the Northern Territory. The popularity of the region is borne out by the statistics which show that 45,000 people visited Kakadu in 1982 and 185,000 visited the area in 1987. The Northern Territory Government has declared the importance of Kakadu as a tourist attraction. It says that Kakadu is one of the most critical components of the Northern Territory tourist industry. It is important to take note of that Government's view. We often hear from people on the other side of the House that the Northern Territory Government is very gung ho, that it always acts in favour of the mining companies and that it has no sympathy with the environment. The statement that I have just read shows that this claim is utterly false. The Northern Territory Government recognises that Kakadu National Park is of great tourist significance and of great benefit to the Northern Territory economy.

Sadly, some of the submissions made to the Committee were in favour of clamping down further on this great Australian tourist attraction. Disappointingly, those submissions came from the Australian Conservation Foundation, the World Wildlife Fund and the Australian Heritage Commission. One of the views expressed was that recreational fishing was incompatible with the concept of a national park, and that fishing should be prohibited. Of course, not wanting to buck the extreme conservationists such as members of the Australian Conservation Foundation-the original suburban greenies-the majority report expressed sympathy for this particular view. Our report argues that recreational fishing and the national park are entirely compatible so long as over-fishing is prevented. We believe that that is a fair recommendation. We went on to say:
That ANPWS should, as a matter of urgency, carry out a study of the fish populations of the Park with a view to determining the impact on them of various levels of recreational fishing.

So we are not against looking at the matter. But we believe that fishing is compatible with the concept of a national park. Listening to Senator Coulter and other members of the Committee who are in favour of the majority report, I wonder what type of tourist attraction they want. Do they want people to drive round Kakadu National Park and view the area through bus windows? If that is the case, it is certainly a ridiculous situation. If that is the type of tourist attraction they want, the sorts of figures I have just outlined in respect of the popularity of Kakadu as a tourist attraction would decline very dramatically.

The majority report also recommends that recreational hunting be banned. This would mean that hunting of feral animals, in particular buffaloes, would not be permitted despite the threat of damage by such animals to the environment. The recommendation in the majority report is against the very recommendation of Dr Landsberg, a Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation scientist. Again, I wonder what type of tourist attraction those members of the Committee in favour of the majority report are looking for.

The views that they hold on mining in Kakadu are just as bad as their views on the matters I have already outlined. Incredibly, the majority report failed to make any recommendations on whether the Jabiluka and Koongarra mines should go into production. That is a very sad indictment of the authors of the majority report. It is remarkable to think that after 3 1/2 years the Labor and Australian Democrats majority on the Committee were unable to come to a firm decision. By failing to make a recommendation, those responsible for drawing up the majority report have left the Government and the people of Australia in the same undecided position as they were in in 1985. What a waste of taxpayers' money and a disappointment that is.

TALK.START.PARA: —The majority report.

—The majority report did not contain a recommendation. Although the Committee sat for 3 1/2 years, the Government and Democrat members of the Committee could not decide whether or not they wanted mining at Jabiluka or Koongarra. I will tell the Senate a little later why they could not make a decision. But I can say for sure that the minority report contains a very firm decision.

SPEECH.PARA: I will read out the majority report recommendation in which a decision was not made. The report stated:

The Committee does not make any recommendations as to whether permission should be given for the Jabiluka or Koongarra mines to go into production. A wide range of matters would need to be considered in making such recommendations . . .

Are we being told that the Committee never considered those matters at all? It is embarrassing that this should be the position after 3 1/2 years of investigation. The question of whether to allow mining is probably not an environmental question but a political question. This is the reason supporters of the majority report could not make a decision. We know the views that members of the Committee have on uranium mining. We know the views of Senator Collins, Senator Zakharov and Senator Coates on uranium mining. Quite obviously, they have different views. No doubt they got together in some back room deal. We know the view that Senator Coulter has on uranium. We know that he is against it too. There was a 3/2 split, so obviously they got together and said, `Let us make no decision at all. Let us dumbfound everyone'. This was a political decision-not an environmental or well-judged decision. This makes a mockery of what Senate committees are all about. One would think that Government members of the Committee could be a little at arm's length from the other place. But they are not and they never will be.

The report by my colleagues and I states that no compelling evidence was submitted to the Committee to sway us and that we believe that mining in those areas should go ahead. We were not swayed by any of the evidence that was presented. Therefore, we recommend that work at the two projects be approved without delay. Quite rightly, Australia cannot afford not to mine in Kakadu. The Jabiluka deposit contains a known uranium resource twice as large as Ranger and its gold deposits are the highest grade of any Australian mine. Pancontinental Mining Ltd, which holds a 65 per cent interest in the joint venture seeking to develop the Jabiluka project, told the Committee that the gross value of the resources was in excess of $A20 billion. The Koongarra project also has some equally stunning figures which show the damage being done by not proceeding with these projects. We are missing out on valuable exports to the tune of $1.7 billion and the Government alone is missing out on tax revenue of $1.76 million.

The most interesting statistic is the fact that the local Aboriginal people are missing out on $256m. This was never mentioned by Senator Coulter. That sort of money, if properly managed, would go a long way to helping Aboriginal people in terms of schools, health care and housing. This money would not have to go through the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, which we all know is an absolute shambles and mess at the moment. This is money that would go to the local Aboriginal people. In reality, this money is being denied to these people. They are being robbed of this money because of a political decision. As Senator Crichton-Browne pointed out, the local Aboriginals want uranium mining to go ahead. But they are being overridden by the authorities. The evidence of that is in the minority report. Paragraph 126 at page 297 of the minority report states:

Mr Stan Tipiloura, a full-blooded Aborigine and a member of the Arafura, which contains the Koongarra and Jabiluka uranium prospects, has said as recently as June this year (1988) that his Aboriginal constituents were totally in favour of a change to the three mine uranium policy and felt they were being discriminated against:
Well, the shoe is on the other foot.

Another area under consideration to be mined for gold is Coronation Hill. It has managed to get a great deal of press of late. The joint venturers are currently in the process of preparing an environmental impact study in compliance with the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act of 1974. We believe that mining should go ahead in this area subject to a full and detailed environmental impact statement. We have no doubt that adequate incentives and safeguards can be built into the project.

An important principle must be laid down in relation to Coronation Hill and the whole conservation area-the principle of multiple land use. To enforce that principle-the ability to have multiple land use in these national parks-in recommendation 113 and 114 we have added words that deny that the only decision that has to be made in these conservation areas is a conservation decision; there are many other factors to be taken on board. But that does not seem to be the way the majority report has gone. The majority seem to think that conservation is the only element and the only reason to make a decision as to whether mining should go ahead.

In conclusion, our dissenting report is founded on the belief that multiple resources use in Kakadu National Park should be permitted to the extent that the natural environment has adequate safeguards. No-one can deny that. Kakadu is an enormous area. It is about one-third the size of Tasmania. That should also be taken into consideration. It is a beautiful area. It should be made available to all Australians as a tourist attraction; and its wealth should also be made available to all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleagues on the minority report on the potential of Kakadu National Park region. At this stage most of what I have to say has already been said. Before I commence, I commend the chairmanship of Senator Black. In the time that I have been on the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, I have found him to be a very fair chairman.

SPEECH.PARA: To give honourable senators an idea of the size of Coronation Hill in relation to Kakadu National Park, which has been spoken about so much today, I will relate a story of my earlier years at school.

TALK.START.PARA: —About eight years ago.
—I will ignore that, Senator Crichton-Browne. I asked a teacher- -
—What did he say?

—I will come to that. The honourable senator should listen instead of talking to his friend behind him. I asked him what `delta' meant. He said. `It is simply an increment of the whole'. He said that if a truck was parked outside loaded with 20 tonnes of biscuits and he went and threw on another biscuit, that would be delta biscuit, or delta load. That is about how we can describe Coronation Hill and Kakadu National Park. Incidentally, there are a lot of moths flying around the chamber. Everyone is up in arms about them. In my home State of Western Australia, it is a triennial event, so I take no notice of them. I wish all honourable senators would stop flicking their heads around to get rid of them; they will soon go away by themselves. If one moth landed on this Parliament House building-not just in the chamber-that would be about the proportion of Coronation Hill mine compared to the whole of Kakadu National Park.

SPEECH.PARA: According to Senator Crichton-Browne, the size of Kakadu National Park varies. It is about 17,552 square kilometres, which is, roughly, 20 million hectares, according to Senator Crichton-Browne.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe you, Senator.

—I thank the Minister. It has a population of 250 Aborigines and 56 park staff, which means that there is 70.2 square kilometres for each Aboriginal, or 57.4 square kilometres per person, including the park staff. That just shows us how sparsely occupied it is.

SPEECH.PARA: On my visit to the park with members of the Committee, we were well shown around by various people of the Australian Parks and Wildlife Service and the Office of the Supervising Scientist. The Office of the Supervising Scientist is financed somewhat totally by the mines.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot have `somewhat totally'; it is like `slightly pregnant'.

—All right. It seems to me that they are doing a top job of supervising what is going on in regard to mining, but they seem to be very much bent contrary to the mining. As soon as we got there, these people were quick to tell us that one of the retort tanks overran the night before. I think they were hoping that it would get out, but it had cement blocks around it to stop that. Their main aim seems to be criticising the mines. I believe that that Office should be removed to, say, Darwin. We should have only a few of the staff in the park on a continuous and rotating basis. This would enable them to see a bit of the outside world as well.

SPEECH.PARA: I saw no great damage being done to the environment while I was there. I speak as one who is experienced in the bush and outback and in mining. When I was in local government, there was a lot of mining in our area. Compared to what I have seen elsewhere, I consider that minimal damage has been done to the environment. If honourable senators do not already know, I am committed to the cause of multiuse of land in Australia. I believe that Kakadu National Park, just like the rest of the public ground in Australia, should be available to all, whether it is for tourism, mining or whatever other industries suit various areas. I am a great believer in that and I have always worked that way.

Tourism is flourishing in that area. From what I have read, there are about 200,000 visitors to that area, which surprisingly matches up with Ayers Rock and the Olgas, and various other places. As I have said, I believe that land should not be locked up. Senator Coulter has said that the areas we are discussing should be locked up for the occasional visit that he and others may make.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody has ever said that.

—I thought I heard it being said. I believe that all bush is beautiful. I believe that Kakadu is beautiful; but I believe that all bush is beautiful. Senator Coulter referred to the land at the top of South Australia. I have travelled right through there, coming right across the desert from Western Australia. One cannot find there any plants or animal life, except for the cattle in the pastoral areas. I consider that that land is all beautiful. But that does not mean that it has to be locked up from everyone. Just for the occasional visit Senator Coulter might make there to be with the stars. I would go so far as to say that if the honourable senator and others bent that way think it is that great, it should be compulsory for everyone to go out there for 12 months and stay in primitive situations. We would then see if the people back in the cushy, easy life cities, such as Senator Zakharov, want to go back there. I have had the experience of living in harsh outback areas. I think many others would think differently about mining, agriculture and whatever in those areas if they spent a little more time there. Of course, mining and tourism in those areas provide opportunities for the employment of Aborigines. In Darwin, before we went to Coronation Hill-which incidentally was run into the ground by what Broken Hill Proprietary Co Ltd (BHP) did to it-a radical group who followed the mining group in told us that BHP was not doing the right thing and was stripping the benches. The next day we found out that these benches, which are on the side of the hill where the rigs stand, were made around 1948, when Coronation Hill was being explored for uranium. It is only in the last six or seven years that they have been exploring for gold. The benches had been re-cleared because they had grown up since that time. We were met by the management at Coronation Hill, who laid out the exploration results on the plans, although they were not too forward about giving us values. Over the years I have read a few of those results-and fortunately I am able to read upside down-and I ascertained that in some places there were up to 400 ounces of gold in a tonne of ore. It would be a crying shame, considering the foreign income we need to keep this country afloat and the social security bills we get from this Government, to think of locking up that area.

SPEECH.PARA: While we were there we had a discussion with the Jawoyn people. They presented us with a petition about doing our utmost to see that this area is opened up for gold mining so that they can get jobs. About 25 people were employed on the exploration site. I spoke to many of them who were driving trucks and working on drilling rigs, as general hands, trades assistants, et cetera. They were very interested in their jobs. In fact they said that it was a pity that there were not more of these positions around so that their mates, who could not get jobs, could get out of the pubs in Katherine, where they were drinking themselves to death. I thought that was a good point. A lot more could be done for those people if jobs were made available. If Coronation Hill were to get off the ground, there are already agreements in place by which royalties would go to the Aborigines.

The Ranger uranium mine is very successful and hopefully in time we will see another two mines start up-Jabiluka and Koongarra. On the experience of Ranger alone, the Aborigines are getting roughly $15,200 per person a year. I know that that amount does not always go directly into their hands; a certain amount goes into a trust account or something similar, where it accrues interest over time. Of course, that has taken the load off the social security bill, which is getting very heavy, and is also keeping the people occupied.

Coronation Hill could do a lot with its natural resources. In our minority report we said that, subject to certain environmental studies being done-we already have the experience of what is happening at the Ranger mine-we do not see why Coronation Hill, as well as Jabiluka and Koongarra, should be prevented from going ahead, particularly as the risk of damage to the environment would be greater from a uranium mine than from a gold mine. In the majority report it was noted-and this was mentioned by Senator McGauran-that no recommendation was made one way or another as to whether mining should go ahead in those three places. Senator Collins from the Northern Territory has, like myself, spent a lot of time in those outback areas. He usually has a certain amount of commonsense, although when he gets to this place he probably has to put it aside. However, the Chairman admitted that the Committee was deadlocked. If I wanted to read his mind--

TALK.START.PARA: —What? This is sheer speculation.

—No, it is not. Like the honourable senator, I can judge what people are thinking by what they say. I cannot see why she is here. The honourable senator does not deny that the Committee was deadlocked, and for that reason it made no recommendation. I thought very hard, as Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator McGauran probably did, before we decided to bring down a minority report. Had the majority report come down with a recommendation to mine, I would not have brought down the minority report. People such as Senator Zakharov, who is laughing on the other side of the chamber, come from the city of Melbourne-the honourable senator had never been out of Melbourne before she came here-and want to tell us how to run the rest of Australia. The people who are prepared to go to the outback are the ones who should have a say in how the outback operates.
—Humbug!

—I am not humbug enough to tell the honourable senator what to do in Melbourne; she should not tell us what to do out in the open country, where she prefers not to be. I would not have been part of the minority report if the majority report had come down on the side of mining.

SPEECH.PARA: While we were there we were able to see Mudginberri, which was very interesting, as most honourable senators would remember, in that famous case the industrial relations of the animal slaughtering industry in Australia were rewritten. I noted that the Government, probably through the Northern Land Council, has finally taken over the station. A caretaker has been put in and the abattoir is now being used to slaughter the last of the buffalo. The buffalo have disappeared; the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) delights in showing people spare parts of buffaloes which have been shot from helicopters by aerial shooting parties and left to rot. It is a very cruel way of killing them. I was very sorry to see that demise because the buffalo, in its own right, is a very beautiful animal. I know that it is an introduced species, but I believe it added something to the place. It was meat for the Aborigines, and the ANPWS has now taken delight in removing it. Of course, with the buffalo gone, we had the famous quote from Senator Gareth Evans, before I came here, that that country was nothing but clapped out buffalo country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which he modified, and you know it.
—I do not know it.
—Perhaps you should.

—All right, but he did say that. I do not quite agree that that is how one would describe that country. I said earlier that I believe all of the outback countryside is beautiful. Some parts of the country are different.
—He did not modify it. He said it is clapped out.

—All right. I do not know what his modification was. He probably modified it when he had an argument with Senator Coates in the Caucus room. We are not responsible for what the Government modifies. If we say that we will modify something, the Government makes mileage out of it. So I am not saying that it is not a beautiful place, but I am saying it is no better than a lot of other places such as the Olgas, the Gibson Desert and the Simpson Desert. In other words, beauty is in the eye of the beholder. I like the place but I do not like it that much that I think it should be locked up from everyone except for a few fit hitchhikers that care to go through it every once in their lifetime.
—Thank you for the compliment.

—Yes, but all the same, I have described how much of the park Coronation Hill and the mines take up, Senator Coulter. For the next 1,000 years people could still be visiting it, as the honourable senator said, and the mining could still go on. The mining companies will not worry about the people walking through there, nor should the people worry about the mining companies being there. That is how we should look at it. I would also like to know what percentage of Australians will go there. Let the Northern Territory Government carry on with taking care of what is happening up there. We should not be telling it how to run the place. Let it run its own affairs without interference from the wise men from the south or from the east, or even from the west for that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not have much else to say on the matter, but I conclude by saying that I did enjoy being on the Committee, irrespective of the very one-sided and opposing views we got from some members of the Committee who are on the other side of the House, as well as those on my left. I would like to commend Senator Crichton-Browne for the work he did on this minority report, because he did the bulk of it. Having been on the Committee for much longer than I have, he was able to contribute much more to the writing of the minority report than I could. When I went through it I found very little to disagree with. But, of course, Senator Crichton-Browne, like me-I do not know whether honourable senators know it-has spent a lot of time in these outback areas of Western Australia. He was not the city boy that he looks like now. He has seen a lot of Australian country and he has had experience of the gold mining areas that probably members on the other side have not had. I commend him for that and I certainly commend the minority report. I found probably no more than 40 per cent of the majority report that I objected to. But my main objection was that those who wrote the majority report did not have the courage to come up with a recommendation on mining one way or the other. At least if they had come down with a recommendation that there be no mining, they would have made a decision and they could have been judged on it. But we cannot judge them because they did not make a decision at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand another report is to be presented tonight, so I will not be using my full time at this stage. I would like to raise a matter which is not related to the substance of the report or the dissenting report but to some of the material published in the dissenting report. This inquiry began as a result of a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, of which I was the Chair. Towards the end of the inquiry we were asked to hear the views of the Jawoyn people, the traditional owners of the Coronation Hill area. It was the wish of the Jawoyn community, and of the Committee, that the evidence be given in camera. As Chair, I inquired as to the security of in camera evidence and was advised then that it could be released only by resolution of the Committee or of the Senate itself. This was explained to those giving evidence, as was the belief of the then Committee that the evidence remained confidential.

SPEECH.PARA: I was therefore deeply shocked, on reading the dissenting report last week, to find that quite large sections of the evidence at that hearing were quoted verbatim in the dissenting report, and quoted selectively to support the minority's argument. I have since been advised by the Clerk that there is precedent for this action, for an independent member-in this case three senators but only one had been at that hearing-preparing a dissenting report to disclose, without reference to the Committee or to the witness, in camera evidence which the member claims in relevant to the dissent and which forms a necessary part of the reasoning of the dissent. I seek leave to incorporate that advice in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE USE OF IN CAMERA EVIDENCE IN DISSENTING REPORTS

The question has been raised whether a Senator, in a dissent attached to the report of a committee, may refer to or quote evidence taken by the committee in camera and not otherwise published by the committee or the Senate.

Standing order 311 provides, inter alia, that ``A protest or dissent may be added to the Report [of a committee].'' This provision applies to all committees, as standing order 37a makes clear. The standing orders contain no provisions, however, indicating the permissible content of a protest or dissent. A dissent is usually referred to as a dissenting report, and normally sets out the reasons for disagreement with the conclusions or recommendations of a committee's report.
The question of the use of in camera evidence in a dissenting report is a difficult one, and there are strong arguments in favour of contrary conclusions.

The question was raised in relation to the report of the Select Committee on the Conduct of a Judge in 1984. All of the evidence of that committee was taken in camera and was not disclosed by the committee, and the signatories of a dissenting report wished to support their dissent with quotations from the in camera evidence other than that referred to in the committee's report. After consideration of the question, the advice then given orally to the committee was that it was permissible for a Senator to quote in camera evidence to support the Senator's dissent. This advice was accepted and followed, and a dissenting report quoted parts of otherwise undisclosed in camera evidence. It is believed that there may have been other instances of this, but specific examples have not been located.

In camera evidence may be published by the committee which has taken it, in its report or otherwise, and may also be published by order of the Senate. A committee, therefore, cannot give to witnesses providing evidence in camera a binding assurance that that evidence will not be disclosed. For this reason, paragraph (8) of the resolution of the Senate of 25 February 1988 relating to the protection of witnesses provides that witnesses about to give evidence in private session are to be informed whether it is the intention of the committee to disclose the evidence and that the evidence may be disclosed by the committee or the Senate.

The disclosure of evidence taken in camera without the permission of the committee concerned or of the Senate is normally an offence, the word ``offence'' here meaning both a contempt of the Senate and a criminal offence. First, as to contempt, the unauthorised disclosure of in camera evidence is by precedent one of the established categories of contempt, and Senate standing order 308 explicitly prohibits it. The resolution of the Senate of 25 February 1988 setting out matters which may be treated as contempts, in paragraph (16), refers to the unauthorised disclosure of unpublished evidence. Second, as to criminal offences, the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 in section 13 creates a statutory offence of unauthorised disclosure of in camera evidence, and in sub-section 16 (4) prohibits the production in court of undisclosed in camera evidence. These statutory provisions, of course, have no application to the disclosure of evidence in the course of proceedings in Parliament, as section 16 elsewhere makes clear, and the inclusion of a dissent in a report, as section 16 also makes clear, is a proceeding in Parliament.

It might be deduced from this that the answer to the question is in the negative, that in camera evidence may be disclosed by the committee concerned or by the Senate and not otherwise, and that the disclosure of such evidence in a dissenting report is prohibited and is a contempt. There is also a strong argument of principle in favour of a negative answer. Allowing the quotation of in camera evidence in a dissenting report has the effect of giving to one Senator a power to publish such evidence, and a decision by one Senator does not have the safeguard of a deliberate decision by a committee or the Senate.
There are, however, strong considerations in favour of an affirmative answer, and these considerations decisively influenced the advice given in 1984.

The explicit provision for a dissent to be added to a report makes a dissenting report a part of the reporting process, and in itself confers a powerful right on individual Senators. In effect, it may be seen as providing another method whereby the authorised disclosure of evidence may take place. It may be essential for a dissenting Senator to refer to undisclosed evidence in order to make out the dissent, and it would be objectionable in principle to allow the majority of a committee to withhold the evidence which may be vital for the exercise of the right of dissent. That right may be effectively nullified by the suppression of some evidence by the majority.

Many Houses of Parliament, including the British and Canadian Houses of Commons, the New Zealand House of Representatives and the Australian House of Representatives before 1978, do or did not allow committee members to make dissenting reports, for the reason that this gives too great a power to an individual member. In those Houses, the prohibition on dissenting reports is often circumvented by the submission of alternative draft reports or amendments to the chairman's draft, which are included in the minutes attached to the report, and the same device might perhaps be used to disclose in camera evidence. It may well be argued that, in giving the right of dissent to its members, the Senate has conferred a right for individual members to make use of a committee's evidence for that purpose.

An insistence on a dissenting Senator obtaining the permission of the committee or the Senate before quoting or describing in camera evidence in a dissent, unless permission were routinely granted, could well give rise to artificial situations which could not long persist. A statement in a dissent that it was supported by undisclosed evidence would inevitably give rise to a demand for the production of the evidence. Subsequent debate would probably be such as to compel the committee or the Senate to disclose the evidence.

It must not be thought that this reasoning gives to each member of a committee a discretion to disclose in camera evidence. The disclosure must be only in the context of a dissenting report. A member could not add an attachment to a report which contains no dissent from the committee's recommendations or conclusions but which merely quotes in camera evidence. Moreover, the disclosure of evidence must be clearly relevant to the matters in respect of which the Senator dissents and must be a necessary part of the reasoning of the dissent. A Senator could not simply include in camera evidence in a dissenting report as an addition not strictly related to the dissent; to do so would be an unauthorised disclosure of the evidence.
On this basis, I consider that the balance of argument lies in favour of an affirmative answer. I would therefore confirm the advice previously given.

It must be said that the Senate has not explicitly determined the matter. By accepting the report of the 1984 select committee, and perhaps other reports, the Senate may be said to have tacitly accepted the view here expressed. A definite contrary decision would have the effect of overturning the precedent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Had the former Committee known at the time that this was possible, it is likely we may not have proceeded with the hearing. We are now faced with an untenable situation. The Committee had already decided earlier this year not to release the evidence and therefore did not quote it in the majority report. On the other hand, I cannot use other material from that transcript to refute the evidence already quoted selectively in the dissenting report in support of its case.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon Senator Crichton-Browne, in his interjection, said that this was not in camera evidence. If that were so, there would have been no need for the Committee to consider the matter of acceding to a request to release the evidence-incidentally, I think that request came from the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-earlier this year and for the Committee then to deny that request.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is because you had the numbers-the brutal numbers.

—It is not because I had the numbers. If the honourable senator looks at the transcript of that evidence he will see it is clearly marked `in camera'. Incidentally, this is not the only place in the dissenting report where in camera evidence is quoted. The transcript of a video presented by Mr Stephen Davis was incorporated at an in camera hearing in Darwin and it has also been quoted at length. In this case the minority would undoubtedly have had approval of the witness to release the evidence, but the Committee made no such decision.

SPEECH.PARA: But there is also a wider, very serious implication, and it was averted to earlier by Senator Coulter. If committees cannot guarantee that any one of their members will not break the trust of a witness that his or her evidence remain private, then such witness will be very unwilling to give evidence for fear of endangering his or her employment or even safety. I believe this matter to be extremely serious and to warrant the attention of the Committee of Privileges, to find some way to ensure that witnesses in the future are protected from action that, although extremely unethical in my view, apparently does not breach privilege.
As I said before, there is another report to be presented tonight, so I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Madam Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. In the course of my comments on the report it was suggested, I think by Senator Coulter, that I had been able to use evidence by trickery, and I think one of the honourable senators on the other side, Senator Zakharov I suspect, said that I required approval and the evidence was in camera. She also said, just a few moments ago, that I was unethical. I resent that imputation. I say first of all that anybody who knows the Standing Orders and who knows about precedent-and it arose particularly in the case of the investigation into a judge-knows that any evidence is available for use in a dissenting report in the event that it is relevant and goes to the substance of the minority report.

SPEECH.PARA: However, let me first refer the Senate to a letter written to Mr Raymond Fordimail by the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Crichton-Browne claims to have been misrepresented. He should stick to explaining why he has been misrepresented. He cannot debate the issue.
—Order! I do not believe Senator Crichton-Browne is debating the issue. No point of order is involved. I ask the honourable senator to keep his comments fairly short.

—I thank the Chair. The difficulty I have, as I am sure Senator Tate will understand, is that I cannot go to the heart of the claim of unethical conduct without demonstrating why it was ethical. If the Senate will bear with me, that is what I am trying to demonstrate. This matter is relevant. I quote from the relevant part of the letter to the Jawoyn people:

SPEECH.PARA: As requested, this will be a private meeting with the Jawoyn, not a public hearing (although I understand from our discussions that the Jawoyn would see no problem if the transcript were made publicly available at a later stage).
In that letter it was not suggested that the evidence was in camera. I refer the Senate to the evidence that was taken on that day. The Chairman started to say:
The evidence being taken this morning is in camera evidence.
Senator Townley then interrupted and said that it was a private meeting, not in camera. The Chairman said:
There may be parts that will be in camera.
Senator Townley then said:

But this is not in camera as I understand it. I said that I would not agree to it being in camera. This is a private meeting with the transcipt to be released following this meeting, as I understand it.
The Chairman said:

Will you let me finish and explain what we have been advised. This means that none of us here are permitted to tell other people what was said in this meeting. If the Committee wants to release any of the evidence at a later stage, it would consult you first.

Senator Townley said that he was not happy with that and that it was not an in camera meeting. The Chairman said that the evidence was to be released. If I may paraphrase, Senator Townley went on to give his understanding of the position, which was that the meeting was private to the extent that it allowed the Aboriginal community to give evidence without fear of intimidation by the presence of other people. It was not that the evidence was to be in camera. Debate went on with Senator Townley saying that it was not to be an in camera meeting. Without going through all the evidence, I concluded by saying, referring to the Jawoyn people:
They are not asking that the evidence, once given, be in camera, but rather that its presentation be in camera.

End of discussion-and there was no doubt in my mind, nor was there any doubt in Senator Townley's mind or anybody else's, that when that evidence was taken it was not in camera. I would not have agreed, Senator Townley would not have agreed, and there would have been no quorum, and there would have been no evidence.

I wish to make it quite clear that there is nothing unethical about that, there is no trickery about it-the evidence was not in camera. There was a meeting subsequently where it was asked for the evidence to be released. I said at that time, and it is on the record, that the evidence was not in camera and that I would never agree to its being in camera, and so far as I was concerned it was available to the public. I will not impugn the integrity of others, but I am rapidly being drawn to the conclusion that there is another reason for this evidence not being made available.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present a report entitled Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force, together with the transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Government's 1987 policy information paper entitled `The Defence of Australia' identified the men and women of the Australian Defence Force as that force's `most valuable asset' and `a vital resource in the security of Australia'. It follows, therefore, that personnel wastage-that is, loss rates-which exceed certain numerical and qualitative levels will be harmful to the national defence effort. Given that wastage rates in the Australian Defence Force have for several years now significantly exceeded historical levels, this report by the Joint Committee is, I believe, topical and important.

The inquiry attracted a great deal of armed service, public, academic and media interest. Some 226 written submissions were received, compared with the 35 and 26 respectively for this Committee's preceding two inquiries into defence matters. Public hearings and meetings were held in many different localities across Australia. Overall, more than 4,000 pages of evidence were collected.

Committee members found that, throughout the Australian Defence Force, servicemen and women were keenly aware of the personnel wastage issue, usually held an opinion on the subject and were keen to discuss it. During the course of the inquiry Committee members concluded that personnel wastage is the most pressing matter facing the Defence Force. It is an issue which requires prompt but at the same time considered resolution. I seek leave to incorporate the balance of my remarks in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

In order to achieve that end many individuals have worked with considerable dedication over the past 12 months. We would like to acknowledge their contribution and express our thanks. On behalf of the Chairman of the Defence Subcommittee, Mr Cross, M.P., I should like to record his appreciation of the efforts of his Subcommittee colleagues, who between them spent hundreds of hours working on what has been a most demanding inquiry.

We would also like to thank those who presented evidence and submissions; in particular, the co-operation of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Chief of the Defence Force, was appreciated. The subcommittee wishes to acknowledge the contribution made by our staff, in particular our secretary Mr Alan Stephens and word processor operator Ms Kylie Freer. We are also indebted to the main Committee, its chairman Mr Gordon Bilney and secretary Mr Peter Gibson.

Before turning to the Committee's Main Findings, I believe it is important to comment, first, on the nature of this inquiry, and, second, on the higher management of the Defence Force. The subject matter has made this a difficult inquiry. Throughout its deliberations the Committee has been aware of the fact that there is a persistent negative overtone inherent in the topic. If people are asked what is wrong with their organisation and why they are leaving it, then that is precisely the kind of information they will provide; they are unlikely to say much about the positive aspects of their employment. Because of the terms of reference this report unavoidably is a critical examination of defence personnel management. We believe that is proper, as the question of wastage rates in the ADF has been of concern to this Committee for some years. The very fact that we accepted the subject for inquiry is indicative of widespread public concern. The Committee also believes that while at a superficial level the inquiry may appear to have been a somewhat negative process, it has been necessary and in the long-term will be of significant benefit to the ADF and the Government. Personnel wastage has been the subject of considerable media attention; indeed, the extent of that attention may even have contributed to wastage. This inquiry has opened up a vexed and contentious issue. In the long term that process will be in the best interests of the ADF.

Because of the critical nature of the reference, Committee members wish emphatically to place on record their respect for the ADF and its members. As an organisation the ADF has attractions which few others can match. It offers comradeship, a sense of adventure, and opportunities to develop both leadership and specialist skills. Above all, it has a compelling ethos of service. During our visits to many ADF establishments and in our discussions with thousands of service men and women, we were continually aware of the high quality and commitment of those people. The Committee's report should be read with those admirable features of the ADF and its members clearly in mind. As far as the higher management and direction of the Defence Force is concerned, several important points must be made. In the form of the 1987 White Paper, the ADF has for the first time in decades a logical and coherent policy guidance document against which force development can be directed and assessed. That document has been widely endorsed within the defence community. The central role played by the present Minister for Defence in the development and implementation of that policy deserves the high praise which it has in fact attracted. The Joint Committee supports the re-equipment of the ADF as detailed in the White Paper. Since mid-1987, the Minister and the ADF have been supported by an energetic and committed Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Again, it is widely accepted that without her untiring efforts, many of the conditions of service improvements which have been effected in the past 12 months simply would not have happened.

Those are, very briefly, perhaps the major positive aspects of recent higher defence management. I believe it is most important to note that they have taken place not only against a background of years of benign neglect of our Defence Force by previous governments, but also during what currently is a period of extreme financial constraint.

I should now like to turn to the Committee's major findings. Like all other government activities, defence must compete for a finite pool of resources. Within the defence vote itself there is intense competition for a limited number of dollars. Personnel costs must be evaluated against bids for capital equipment, capital facilities, operating costs, defence co-operation programs, and so on. Senior management must decide whether, at a particular time, one or more functions can perhaps be reduced to a level which may be below their historical average. Such decisions should be taken only after a rigorous appraisal of Australia's strategic circumstances and should be consistent with the broader long-term interests of national security.

It might be argued that if Australia's defence managers consider that a particular wastage rate is acceptable within the context of our strategic circumstances and broader defence planning then, whatever that rate may be, there is no problem. Such an argument would be facile, for while statistics are an essential management tool, the examination of mere numbers is not in itself sufficient. Any worthwhile analysis of wastage must come to grips with the more subjective, but vital, factors of defence force quality and effectiveness. A central issue there is the pattern of wastage, that is, who is leaving and when. It is also important to remember that the lead time to replace a highly skilled and trained individual can be at least as long as that required to introduce into service an item of capital equipment. A controlled, manageable personnel separation rate is essential if the ADF's operational capability is to be maintained at the necessary standard. Against that background, and after careful consideration of a great deal of evidence, the Committee has concluded that the present level of wastage in the ADF is far too high and has been so for some time. Further, there has been a clear and consistent trend towards this situation for several years.

The Committee does not support the Department of Defence's conclusion that wastage is of concern only in some specific specialist areas. That kind of assessment pays insufficient attention to the qualitative aspects of wastage, as well as understating the overall effect and extent of numerical losses. Our assessment is that there is cause for concern across a wide range of ranks and skills. The extent and magnitude of wastage in some areas is such that it will adversely affect the ADF for at least the next decade. In sum, the effects of wastage identified by the Joint Committee amount to a loss of operational capability. It is manifestly obvious that the prevailing excessive level of personnel wastage is damaging the organisational health of the ADF. Wastage is undermining the experience and competence levels of personnel. It is impacting on the capacity of the training and personnel management systems to maintain the force's integrity. The financial cost arising from the abnormal loss of skilled staff and the increased training effort is enormous. At the psychological level, morale in some areas is lower than normal, and the potential has been created for institutional polarisation.

Having reached that conclusion, the Joint Committee would like to emphasise that, in its judgment, the ADF remains a capable organisation, staffed by many high quality and committed individuals. The force continues to attract praise for its performance in allied exercises. It operates high technology equipment with skill and, as demonstrated by the contingency preparations to evacuate Australians from Fiji in May 1987, can respond rapidly and effectively. Nevertheless, the nation's senior professional single service military leaders have all acknowledged that the current high wastage rates have reduced capabilities. Those judgments were confirmed by the Chief of the Defence Force when he appeared before the Joint Committee. It is clear that, under the existing organisational structure, capabilities will continue to diminish if wastage remains high. The greater part of the Joint Committee's examination of personnel wastage was spent assisting measures to resolve that unsatisfactory circumstance.

In its report the Committee has presented a range of recommendations which, if addressed vigorously and constructively, should enable the Government to reduce wastage to acceptable, more manageable levels. Those recommendations-of which there are 48 in all-are too detailed to discuss at length here. However, in broad terms, they encompass the following areas: policy, leadership and morale; career satisfaction and personnel management; the service family; and conditions of service.

A point of particular significance is that, in general, service men and women who leave the ADF before completing what might be considered a full military career tend to do so for the same reasons, regardless of rank or skill category. For example, while much media attention has focused on the salaries which airlines offer Air Force pilots-salaries which the ADF cannot hope to match-the reality is that pay is only one of a number of factors which influence a decision to separate, even for those who can command much larger wages outside the Defence Force. Changing community values mean that senior defence management must remain dynamic and responsive to change. If the expectations of service men and women are not met on such issues as, for example, job satisfaction, good housing, work opportunities for spouses and dependants, and child care, then retaining the right people in the force is likely to remain a problem. Across the ADF, the kinds of issues I have mentioned affect all service men and women. It is unlikely that one issue by itself will trigger a resignation; rather, it is probable that a combination of events will eventually generate the critical level of dissatisfaction. We believe, therefore, that it will be necessary for the ADF's senior management to adopt a wide-ranging and coordinated strategy to resolve this fundamental problem. Addressing issues in isolation is unlikely to produce a satisfactory long-term outcome.

It is also essential that the system by which the ADF's men and women are rewarded for their service recognises the unique nature of the ADF and the special circumstances under which Defence Force personnel and their families live and work. The recognition of those often onerous circumstances must include a substantial element of compensation through a wide range of conditions of service entitlements. The majority of the Committee's recommendations could be implemented at little or no extra cost to the defence budget. In many cases, determined and innovative management within the ADF and the Department of Defence could do the job. Nevertheless, it is clear that there will need to be either an extra allocation, or a reallocation, of resources to service personnel.

I should like to conclude by reiterating that this comprehensive and detailed report is the end result of a great deal of effort by a large number of individuals. That effort is indicative of the Committee's concern over the present level of personnel wastage in the ADF and our commitment both to national security and the men and women of the Defence Force. The Committee believes that continuing, vigorous action is necessary to control the present level of personnel wastage in the ADF which, under the existing organisation arrangements, is excessive and inimical to national defence. The recommendations presented in this report have been framed to achieve that positive objective. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade into personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force (ADF). This is one of the most important reports to come before the Parliament in recent years. The first duty of a government is the security of its people and the protection of their essential national interests. The Australian Defence Force is the custodian of that fundamental task for the Australian people. That force has been drastically reduced in its capabilities by the present crisis and resignation rates, thereby putting the security of Australia at risk, not only today but for years to come. The importance of this report is that it deals with this wastage-induced crisis.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I deal with the report in detail, I wish to express my thanks as Deputy Chairman of the Committee to my colleagues, those senators and members of the Committee who took an active part in the report. I must make individual reference to Manfred Cross, the Chairman, who conscientiously and resolutely, objectively and impartially kept faith with the Parliament by keeping the Committee moving. I also thank Alan Stephens who, as Secretary to the Committee, rendered the most outstanding service I have experienced in nearly 11 years of service on many Senate and joint parliamentary committees.

I also wish to thank the witnesses who wrote to or appeared before the Committee. The Committee received over 220 submissions, a record, which demonstrates the great concern of the armed services in this matter. The Parliament is indeed indebted to those men and women who were prepared to speak out in public, sometimes at possible risk to their careers. It is no secret that the Government was not in favour of this parliamentary inquiry. It did all it could in a covert way to delay or avoid the setting up of this inquiry. However, the wish of the Parliament prevailed, the inquiry was set up and the Government gave the Committee its fullest cooperation in the most honourable way through the course of the inquiry. The report before us today has the unanimous support of all the members of the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party who served on the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was the Chairman?
—Mr Manfred Cross.
—He must have done a wonderful job.

—He was an excellent chairman, as I said a few moments ago, as the Minister would realise had he been paying attention. There was no dissension when the evidence was analysed and the conclusions drawn. The Defence Committee is closely involved with the three Services. In its report the Committee draws attention to problems they are experiencing. Comment is made on actions by the Government and the Services which contribute to the present condition. I cannot emphasise strongly enough the need to maintain a balanced perspective with respect to the ADF. It has many problems. Those problems are mostly not of its making. With the right actions by the Government the ADF will get out of those problems in time. At present, even though the ADF's capabilities are reduced, the personnel concerned are as fine a body of men and women as ever wore the uniforms of the armed services. They are superb professionals, as good as any country's. We, the community, owe them a great debt for the way, with discipline and dedication, they have endured their troubles and continue to serve this country. They deserve not only our gratitude but our help and support. Let us not fail them again.

SPEECH.PARA: The report deals with the crisis in the Australian defence forces-a crisis the manifestation of which is record and unprecedented resignation rates.

Since the Australian Labor Party came to office a little over five years ago, over 45,000 men and women, out of a force of about 70,000, have voted with their feet and left the Services. In sheer numbers, in quantitative terms, we have never seen anything like this. Not only is it a quantitative problem but also it has profound qualitative connotations. The record resignations of the fully trained and experienced professionals, the key people-the people with 10 or 15 years service who are at the core of the operational capabilities of all three Services-are the ones who have gone as well. I refer to people such as company commanders, battalion commanders in the Army; pilots in strike and fighter squadrons; and captains in the Navy. It is the loss of these people in such numbers which is the really crippling effect of the present resignation crisis.

What are the consequences? The first and most obvious one is the lack of capability in an operational sense for our forces. Ships' captains, battalion commanders and pilots all require skill and judgment-the products of experience. This is experience which takes many years to acquire. No emergency training program can supply the experience that comes from eight or 18 years. That pool of experience has now gone. It is best illustrated by the pilots but in no sense are they an isolated example. Against an average loss for Australia and the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) of 47 pilots per year-42 before the present crisis-we had 70 pilots resign in 1985-86; 107 in 1986-87; 123 in 1987-88; and in the first six weeks of this financial year 42 pilots indicated their wish to terminate. We have lost 300 pilots in only three years. At best our training capacity will produce only between 55 to 65 pilots per year.

We have lost great capabilities in all three Services. More importantly, it will be the better part of a decade before we can re-establish that experience we have lost; that is presuming the Government takes effective action at this time. I was pleased to see in the tabling statement of the Committee Chairman in the other place that reference was made to the grievous loss of capacity and capability. He also said that we have lost that for at least a decade.

The second consequence of this high loss rate is a grossly inflated training cost. Since far more people than normal are leaving, not only does the average level of experience within the units fall but also unduly large resources, both in manpower and materiel, have to be devoted to training. That means transferring personnel from operational roles to training roles and transferring money which should be spent on exercises and operational training into basic training. Both of those moves are very expensive, particularly when defence budgets are falling. It is no exaggeration to say that the real cost to taxpayers over the last five years of record resignation rates is measured in terms of billions of dollars. Of the 300 pilots who left-160 more resigned than would have resigned in the average run of events-the total value of their training, conservatively estimated at about $5m each, represents a real loss to the taxpayer of over $800m. This unnecessary cost has to be borne at a time not only of reduced defence budgets but also of negative budget growth. It is not that the budgets have failed to keep pace with inflation; they are actually being reduced. All this is going on when the great predictability of the region has changed. We live in uncertain political times in the region, as the events in Fiji and Papua New Guinea testify.

How did we get into this position? Dozens, perhaps hundreds, of different reasons were advanced to the Committee. They are discussed in detail in the report. Nearly all of those reasons can be traced back to one central failing: the lack of leadership in the political area; primarily in the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the present Government, but secondly in the Parliament as a whole. In the bluntest of terms, too many of the men and women in the armed Services feel that no one in the Government appreciates what they are doing. If people are not valued for their sacrifices-life in the Services cannot be compared with civilian callings-they will find fault with the surroundings. It is so easy to transfer feelings of unease into complaints about poor housing, frequent transfers, interrupted schooling, long hours on duty and inadequate pay and allowances, particularly when the major shortcomings in many of the conditions of service can be so readily demonstrated today. Those are not the real reasons; those are the excuses that people who are leaving give.

The Services need strong leadership in the Parliament, just as they need it in their own ranks. It is a fundamental characteristic of Australia: there is a lack of leadership in the present Minister for Defence and in the Government. There is also confusion between management and leadership. The two are not the same, despite what the Minister thinks. Leadership involves many qualities. It involves an intimate knowledge of the task to be performed. It involves the ability to plan, to inform, and to inspire men and women to make the effort and the sacrifices to achieve the goal. Leadership generates the purpose that comes from the pursuit of a worthy ideal. The Australian Defence Force is foundering because of the lack of a coherent conceptual framework within which it can exist. The whole purpose of our Defence Force today is defined within the narrow confines set by what the Government is prepared to spend on it-not by what needs to be spent for national security.

Not one of the senior officers in any of the three Services believes in the infantile doctrine of credible contingencies and no threats for 10 years which now drives our defence planning. These people are professionals. They know that no one can foresee the future and the nature and timing of future events. They know that armed combat between nations is a very serious matter, not lightly undertaken by an attacking power. If Australia needs its armed forces it will need the highest level of capabilities, not a mere police force. This dishonesty and immorality in the present position comes from the fact that the Government will not put enough money into defence, so a low threat scenario is created.

Funding for defence has declined. The report shows how the percentage of the defence vote devoted to capital equipment and facilities has grown from 18.2 per cent to 29.6 per cent over the last 10 years, while personnel costs have fallen from 54.3 per cent to 42.8 per cent. At the same time, the total defence vote has actually declined. In the past three years the growth rate was positive only in 1985-86 when a growth of 2.9 per cent occurred. In 1986-87 there was a decrease of 0.4 per cent in real terms. In 1987-88 there was a decrease of 1 per cent. The balance between new equipment and personnel is wrong. That is the second great causative factor in resignations because there is just not enough money for the men and women in the Services to give them the conditions and the operational training they joined the Services for. I am the first to agree that it is necessary to spend money on new equipment but it is just as necessary to spend it on the welfare of service personnel. In an emergency, money is always available. The latest equipment can always be bought. However, without the personnel to use that equipment, we are lost. It is all in vain. That is where this Government is wrong.

Ten years ago it was foreseen that in this period, the middle of the 1980s through to the middle of the 1990s, very large amounts of money would be required for equipment. The Department of Defence made its plans to provide adequate funding for that circumstance. This Labor Government approved these plans, but it welshed on the deal, as it has on so many others. In 1984, two years after taking office, this Government approved the 1984-89 five-year defence plan, which provided for a 4.5 per cent real growth in defence outlays each year beyond 1984-85. That was the minimal figure required to run the program. But this growth of 4.5 per cent in real terms for the five years from 1984 to 1989 has never been obtained, even if we accept the dubious 1 per cent to 2 per cent savings which are claimed to have been made in outgoings. Because the Government is locked into inflexible contractual obligations for new equipment, it is the human factor which has had to be sacrificed.

One of the significant features of the present crisis is that the Government had plenty of warning of what was going to happen. The only thing that can be said in its defence is that it clearly received inadequate-perhaps even incompetent-advice from the senior civilian elements of the Department of Defence. Sadly, there are some senior officials still there who still have not realised the enormity of the problem that faces us today.

The Government's first reaction to the resignation crisis was to pretend that the problem did not exist. It embarked on a cover-up, but eventually the truth came out. The Government's early statements were that the original resignation rates were running marginally above average, conveniently overlooking the fact that each fraction of a percentage increase represented very big numbers. The Minister for Defence strenuously protested that there were no problems. On 3 March 1987 on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation 7.30 Report he replied to a question:
Sir, how serious would you regard this manpower drain?
Minister-I would regard it as unacceptable, not a crisis.

This view was repeated many times, particularly by his colleague the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly). On 25 August 1987, in a scintillating display of profound comprehension of the problem, this Minister even went so far as to say that high resignation rates were good for morale. No wonder Senator Tate is cradling his head in his hands, because the direct converse is true.

Forced to concede eventually that the problem existed, the next move of the Government was to shoot the bearers of bad news.
