Comments by informed observers, like myself, on continually rising resignation rates were attacked on the grounds that it was the commentators who were responsible for the problem because they were drawing attention to it. Current Government propaganda is that we have now turned the corner; the worst is over; and in a short while everything will be rosy again. That has been the gist of the press releases put out yesterday in an attempt to exercise some damage control over the release of this report. Sadly for Australia, the latest figures on resignation rates show no proof of this assertion whatsoever. The situation is just as bad as it was some months ago.

While I am on the subject of what the Government has done, I have taken a particular interest in the debates and the press conference held in this building today on this report, and I am more than a little amused at the way the standard defence of the Government to the situation of the mess we are in is that it is an inherited situation. That is false on two grounds. Sadly for Australia, we have had a Labor Government in the Federal arena for the last 5 1/2 years. On the basis that a week is a long time in politics, 5 1/2 years is long enough for the Government to have cleared up any problem that it inherited. The Government has had the initiative. It is the Government's policies that have led us into the mess we are in.

The basic assertion that the Government inherited troubles with respect to resignation rates is absolutely false. Having spent a lot of time looking at statistics for resignation rates in the armed services over the last two or three decades, I can say that when this Government came to power resignation rates for all three services were at the lowest level they had been for many a long day. This Government inherited a very stable and satisfied Defence Force manpower situation, and the figures today give the lie to the assertion that it inherited precisely the same or remotely comparable circumstances to those that exist at present.

Along the way the Government has made some efforts to get on top of the problem. Some measures have been successful and worthwhile, and I pay full tribute to those, like the implementation of the Hamilton report on the Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses, and the things that have been done on defence housing. Other schemes, like the pilot's retention bonus, which was conceived in blind panic, were not only disastrous failures but positively harmful to the defence forces. Overall, the lack of coherent approach has allowed the position to continue unabated. In many ways the haemorrhage is continuing, and the only thing that will stop the outflow of blood from the body corporate of the Australian defence forces is the fact that we have run out of blood.

Having dealt with the Government's action, or inactions, the report also looks at shortcomings within the defence forces themselves. We note that there is clearly a need for the development of a professional personnel division within the armed services. There are matters in relation to conditions of service which are under the control of the individual services which can be improved, and we have drawn notice to them. One of the central problems remains the Russell Hill complex, the civilian-military bureaucracy and its extremely wasteful diarchic structure with its duplication and confrontation.

The last report of my Committee, entitled The Management of Australia's Defence Forces, dealt with the great and serious problem this monster presents, Despite the compelling logic of our last report, the Minister for Defence treated it, and therefore, by inference, the Parliament, with contempt, and has done nothing to correct the situation. As well as all the problems in an organisational and managerial sense that the Russell Hill complex creates, directly and indirectly, it makes its own positive contribution to increasing resignation rates because senior service personnel do not want to be locked up there for years. It is not what they joined the services for. The joined to fight the enemies of Australia, not the Australian Public Service. But the problems of the Russell Hill complex are problems that only this Government can fix. No committee can do that.

I commend this report to the Senate-all 400-odd pages of it. It deals with matters of vital importance to Australia's security. Regrettably, because of what has been going on for years and the numbers of resignations being so large, we have become anaesthetised to both the magnitude and the importance of the huge resignation rates in the Australian Defence Force. The press is not interested; the Government is not interested. I believe it passes their comprehension. We have suffered grievously. At worst, the security of our country has been put at risk. At best, we have pointlessly lost billions of dollars at a time when we are deeply in debt. There is a great parallel between the way the Government has handled the economy and the way it has handled defence. In the economy, the Government came to office with a national debt of $32,000m. Today, over five years later, it is more than $125,000m-all to be repaid by future generations of Australians. This huge legacy has been hidden from the public by the subterfuge of focusing attention on an internal balanced budget achieved by excessive and rapacious taxation and hiding the true indebtedness of the country from the population at large.

The report clearly shows the magnitude of the resignation problem, the length of time over which it has been operating and the responses by the Government. But not only have the corrective responses by the Government been deficient. As great a deficiency has been the failure of the Government to take any remedial action to compensate for these huge losses in numbers. Not one cent has been added to the defence budget so that more training can take place to bridge the gap in experience that we are now suffering from-not one cent for the most elementary process. Australia's national security has been gravely compromised by the neglect this Government shows for defence. If nothing is done we will lose the vestigial capabilities that are in the Australian Defence Force.

It is one of the fundamental principles of a responsible government that someone takes responsibility for actions. In this case it is the Minister for Defence who has knowingly tolerated, or been unable to correct, the dangerous loss of capability that the Australian Defence Force has suffered. There is no point in blaming the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. She is only a decoy. Her position was created in a cynical act by this Government to draw responsibility for this debacle away from its rightful source-the Minister for Defence, Kim Beazley. Never in our history have we had as great and as sorry a record of failure from any Minister for Defence as the present one. He must accept full responsibility for this. He must tender his resignation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any Australian who is seriously concerned about the defence of our nation must be deeply and gravely disturbed by the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. The report identifies a distressing problem in personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force (ADF). It recommends a number of measures to deal with the problem. Many of these might be appropriate. However, the report, from an Australian Democrats perspective, fails to consider a fundamental question. It fails to address the question of how Australia and the Australian Defence Force can be a dynamic institution in an age when conflict concerning Australia directly will either be nuclear, and our Defence Force pointless, or at a very low conventional level in our northern shores and our immediate region. In other words, our Defence Force lacks a sense of purpose, a sense of usefulness, because the raison d'etre is that of a military force conceived in previous decades. Yet it will not be engaged in those sorts of actions that Australian forces have been involved in in the past. This sense of uselessness leads to low morale and wastage. To overcome this the Australian Democrats would urge a model for defence forces that gave them a greater range of ongoing non-military tasks and a greater sense of relevance. In that way defence personnel would feel that they could make an ongoing contribution to our community. They will have a sense of relevance and the devastating personnel wastage that it has cited, documented and measured page after page-in fact, for 400 pages-in this report will have some opportunity of coming to an end. This document cites some extraordinary contradictions of profound significance. I will quote and cite some of these contradictions briefly. The document says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee does not support the Department of Defence's conclusion that wastage is of concern only in some specific areas.

Its assessment is that there is cause for concern across a wide range of ranks and skills within the Services. In other words, the Committee sees the problem of wastage as having its base or its origin across the whole of the defence Services. One might consider here and cite by contrast the view of the 1988-87 Department of Defence report. In the foreword to that report the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) draws attention to the issue of separations from the Australian Defence Force. He says:
The Australian Defence Force personnel wastage issue have also been of high priority for the defence organisation and the nature and extent of separations has been given particular attention.
However in the report tabled here today the Committee shies away from trying to paint too black a picture of the problem. It says:
The current overall rate of separations has not affected the ADF's ability to meet its obligations although at present there are shortages in specific job categories, for instance, RAAF pilots.

I fail to see how this Committee can say that the wastage problem does not detract from the ADF's ability to meet its obligations. What does it see as the obligations of the Australian Defence Force if it is not the defence of this nation? On the other hand, it says that there are insufficient pilots to put our aircraft into the air. That is a blatant contradiction within a few short pages of the introductory sections of the report. It had to resort to the payment of a once-only offer of $70,000 to Royal Australian Air Force pilots to retain them in the defence forces. How short-sighted can it be in its approach to defence service personnel wastage if on the one hand people who are sitting in one machine are given a $70,000 payment while people sitting in other machines, such as tanks or personnel carriers-or it might be someone sitting in the office next to the pilots-are not offered an accommodating equivalent, or at least a partially equivalent, payment? It was a ludicrous, short-sighted, pathetic and morale destroying approach to offer those pilots that once only payment.

The source of low morale within the Services has been documented previously and cited by Senator MacGibbon. It has been documented in this report. It covers aspects of policy, leadership and morale. It covers aspects of civilianisation of manpower. The report cites limitations to career satisfaction and personnel management, limitations of training, poor quality of equipment and personal and camping equipment. It cites limitations of career management. It cites the unacceptable life circumstances of service personnel. In the final analysis the fault lies with the fundamental structure of the Australian Defence Force. It lies in the fact that there is a malignant sense of irrelevance that has been permeating the defence forces for several decades. It lies in the fact that this report does not address those problems. The Minister has not addressed the problems at any stage. The Minister does not even acknowledge the fact that if we are to turn around these problems of wastage and morale we must think laterally and make profound changes to the manner in which we organise our defence forces.

Two days ago I listened on New South Wales radio to appeals for personnel and funds to man our volunteer bush fire brigades which are defending the southern suburbs of Sydney against attack from bushfires. At the same time as we are spending $7.6 billion a year to fund a virtually impotent and demoralised defence force we are funding our volunteer coastal patrols, our coastal surveillance and our bushfire brigades by selling lamingtons on street corners. The Minister for Defence and the Department of Defence are moribund, incapable of thinking laterally, and incapable of thinking positively and constructively about how we can reorganise into the 1990s, and indeed into the next century, a defence force which will have some sense of relevance.

In 1974 I resigned from the Australian Army out of a sense of utter irrelevance. I asked myself, after having been in the Australian Army for a decade, what I was doing with my life and what was the relevance of what I did on a day to day basis. The answer was such that I had no alternative, even back in 1974, to be on the forward edge of the thousands-now tens of thousands-of service personnel who have resigned out of a sense of absolute irrelevance to community needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think that is a common problem with peacetime armies?

—Yes. I believe that it calls for a different type of thinking. In fact, it is a type of thinking that is quite widely spread across Western society. I have put together a document which cites alternative structures and approaches to defence forces in Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, France, Greece, West Germany, Norway, Sweden, Portugal and Spain, all of which are now thinking quite differently about how to put together peacetime defence forces. They are not locked into models which are based on First World War, Second World War, Korea and Vietnam mentalities. We have to think in terms of the next 50 years if we are to come up with the relevant structures. For instance, Austria's defence forces are used in a diversity, a multiplicity, of civil roles such as mountain and air-sea rescue, frontier police, disaster relief, police reinforcement and fire reinforcement. In Belgium they are used for disaster relief; in Denmark, mountain and air rescue, air-sea rescue, coastguards and disaster relief. We can go through Finland, France, Greece, et cetera with similar examples.

SPEECH.PARA: I have stood up in this place on at least five or six occasions and pleaded with the Government and the Minister for Defence to put in front of them a blank sheet of paper and say, `Let us start thinking constructively about how to put together a civil-military defence force which will give serving personnel a sense of relevance, which will give us value for the $7.6 billion a year that we spend on our utterly impotent and demoralised Defence Force and which will render unnecessary the radio pleas such as were heard last week for personnel to go into volunteer bushfire brigades to defend our major cities'. If there is any truth in the greenhouse effect and in the fact that we will be confronted, summer after summer, with much more challenging and profound bushfires-even more challenging than the devastating Ash Wednesday fire of several years ago-the Department of Defence simply has to address seriously these alternative models.

I will not take up any more of the Senate's time. I believe that the Senate would be doing the Australian people and indeed this Government a service if, in the very near future, it created an opportunity to debate-I undertake to create that opportunity by proposing a serious urgency debate-alternative defence models. We must do so very soon. The evidence of the need is this document and the previous document of similar magnitude which was tabled in this chamber three or four months ago, that is, the 1987-88 annual report of the Department of Defence. We simply cannot go on turning our back on this problem and say, as the report suggests:
The current overall rate of separations has not affected the ADF's ability to meet its obligations . . .
Of course it has seriously affected its ability to meet its obligations. If it has not, we do not see it as having any obligations. Otherwise it is just a blatant contradiction in logic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For servicemen, I believe that satisfaction comes from knowing that they are doing an important job and that the people of Australia and the Federal Government stand behind them. The fact that this report has had to be compiled, has had to take the time of parliamentarians and has had to be addressed in a very serious manner across the whole of the community highlights the fact that at the moment the wastage or resignations-the compounding factors of unnecessary resignations from the Australian Defence Force-comes essentially from the fact that servicemen do not feel that they can either get satisfaction or know with confidence that this Federal Government stands behind them. In that respect, the report is very timely.

SPEECH.PARA: It contains, necessarily, some 48 recommendations. What a damning condemnation that is of a government, which has been in office for five years, by a very significant proportion of the Public Service work force. Let us face it; there is a Public Service component for all servicemen in Australia with which they identify. The fact is that a parliamentary report has been under consideration for many months.

I am pleased to have been a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade which compiled this report and undertook the work right around Australia. It is important to note in the report that some 226 individual and specific submissions were received by the committee of inquiry. As I recall, just about every one of those was from a serving serviceman, past serviceman, service representative organisation or academic with a specific interest in military and defence matters. Sure, there were a few important contributions from the forces themselves and the Department of Defence; but it was interesting to note that on several occasions the Department of Defence had to come back before the Committee and revise the evidence that it had presented initially in light of the submissions that had been made by other people or groups as the matter emerged. The Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mrs Kelly, were tardy in their representations to the Committee.

The fact that so little has happened, despite the public debate on this major issue, over the 12 months or so that is has been actively considered by this Parliament is again a further damning condemnation of this Government. Mrs Kelly had the audacity today to stand up in the House of Representatives and say that the problems were being created by the Opposition in this Parliament or by the public debate. What utter hypocrisy! Each problem has been identified in the report because it has not been addressed by government attention and government action-action that has been required of this Labor Government for five years. The Government has been bankrupt in dealing with Australia's defence forces. It has concentrated far too much on looking at equipment and not at people. Probably it had a preconception when it came to office that service personnel did not like the Labor Government's policies and it was just another arena that it chose to get stuck into because it believed that it did not win votes from that area. I know, from the significant number of Defence Force personnel in my electorate, that that is not true. Servicemen vote in patterns similar to just about every other group in the community. Their social and political priorities are no different from those of the general Australian community. But what they do want is confidence in their employment, confidence in knowing that the jobs they do are worth while. They want to feel that their employer, the Government, is responsive to the particular needs of so many people who are making a great contribution to Australia's Public Service.

To look at the report and the way in which it has been put together, I believe that it is interesting to note the priorities that have been given. I will read some of the chapter headings because they stand out and invite further discussion and debate. An entire chapter has been devoted to `The Extent and Magnitude of Wastage'. Another chapter is headed `The Effects of Wastage'. This chapter covers such matters as training deficiencies, the diversion of manpower and the loss of operational capacity of Australia's Defence Force. Another chapter is headed `Policy, Leadership and Morale'. What could be more important to any very significant group of people in Australia than to know that they are receiving leadership and morale encouragement either from politicians like us or the leadership of their own particular force discipline and area? What are the public perceptions of either the political leadership or the military leadership and how does that impact on morale? This question is well covered in this report.

Another chapter is headed `Career Satisfaction and Personnel Management'. The Labor Government has said that it has made many innovative reforms in areas of the Public Service over the five years that it has been in office. Why has it neglected the defence forces area? Why is there a need for us to identify so many areas of personnel management that are either irrelevant in this day and age or do not apply to the job and the force to which they are directed? I am sure that my colleague Senator Newman will address a number of issues to do with what is generally called the service family. Unless a family can, firstly, survive and, secondly, know that it has worth and respect and a decent standard of living in the community, how can we expect servicemen to give in return the loyalty and commitment to their jobs that we would expect? That important area of service family has been continually neglected. I think `neglect' is probably the best word to describe how the Australian Labor Party has treated the service families of Australia.

Probably the most important chapter of the whole report is that headed `Conditions of Service'. Most attention needs to be given to conditions of service which include pay and allowances, the pay fixing system, housing, retirement benefits and all of the other things that impact on a serviceman and on the quality of a force. How can we expect to retain service personnel if a service man or woman does not get a rate of pay which is comparable with that received in the broader community or in the defence forces internationally? That is probably the key area. When that is lacking they can have no confidence in the conditions of service that are available. Many other issues have been identified elsewhere in this report that provide the social triggers that force servicemen to resign. The cost of resignation is probably far greater than anything we could quantify or identify. The cost of someone leaving the Services can be measured in the cost to that person, to his family, to this Government and to future generations.

I believe that this report is timely. Each of the 48 recommendations must be addressed within the next few months by Mr Beazley and Mrs Kelly or the issue will compound throughout next year. While the people who will be affected by this report will be the current servicemen of Australia, I think it also important to note that a generation of young Australians currently aged between 13 and 18 years in the secondary schools of Australia are looking at their careers and their futures. A significant proportion of them ought to be able to know that they can enter the defence forces of Australia, get job satisfaction and career training and settle down to a very satisfactory life in the Services. They need to know that if they choose a career in the Services, the Government and the people of Australia will stand behind them and that they will get personal satisfaction from their careers.

This report has identified the problem areas. Unless the Government addresses those areas, I would hate this report to end up in the high school libraries of Australia. This report would create a very damning impression on the career choices of high school students who are looking for disciplined areas of high academic study that can be complemented by service in the defence forces, for trade careers which provide adequate training or for a family life that could give them brilliant satisfaction.

I believe that the report is one of government. As I said, Minister Beazley and Minister Kelly have to look at sins of the past few years. They have to address these problems urgently. They have to make sure that every one of the issues in the 48 recommendations can be identified in the actions that they take and the ministerial responsibilities that they exercise in the next few months. We need to see in the Budget next year a real determination by the Government to correct this situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in the House of Representatives the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) told the Parliament that the problems which had been discussed in the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade that we are now discussing had bottomed out and that they had been all fixed largely as a result of the measures that she had taken. Last month in the House of Representatives the same Minister said that morale in the Navy, the Air Force and the Army was very high. Mrs Kelly has been trying to put across this line ever since she obtained the Defence Science and Personnel portfolio over a year ago. We all remember the clangers she made when she said that there really was not much of a problem, that there had been a small amount of distortion in terms of the number of women resigning, that there had been a problem with what she called the `Vietnam hump' and that we should really not worry about it.
—She suffers from grand delusions.

—She does suffer from grand delusions. That is also evidenced by the fact that when things were getting tough she put out an order requiring wives of defence personnel to submit their questions to her before she spoke to them. The orders went out that they were to mind their p's and q's and not embarrass the Minister. It is a sad day when civilians are treated like that in order to protect the Minister's sensitivities when quite clearly she either does not know her job or she is trying to con the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is more important to us to look at what the report said, not what the Minister says. It is the Minister who is in the hot seat, as is her colleague, the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). I will selectively quote some rather damning items from the report. It said:
. . . the lead time to replace a highly skilled and trained individual can be at least as long as that required to introduce into service an item of capital equipment.
We are not just giving people rifles and sending them off around the parade ground any more. They have to be trained for a highly technologically advanced force. The report also said:
. . . the present level of wastage is substantially too high and has been for some time.
For 5 1/2 years we have watched that wastage grow. The report went on to talk about the balance of funding between capital equipment and personnel and training votes. The report said:
It would be a most dangerous practice to allow one key element of those capabilities to degrade past a certain level.

My complaint about the Ministry is that it has allowed that to happen. The Minister Mr Beazley is adamant that he will not change the proportion of capital equipment vote in his budget, and that is the source of so many of the problems that the personnel are facing. The report also said:
. . . political and some military leadership is generally regarded as insensitive, disinterested and ineffectual . . .

The report documented cases where Mrs Kelly and Senator Walsh had made some of those insensitive statements. I could add many others to the list which has caused great burning resentment amongst members of the defence forces.
The Committee also recorded its dissatisfaction with the time taken to implement the recommendations of the Hamilton Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses. The report also said:

While we believe that the root cause of the high separation rate the Defence Force is experiencing essentially arises from disaffection with leadership and lack of career and/or job satisfaction, any coordinated strategy aimed at reducing separations is unlikely to succeed if it does not address the conditions of service anomalies.
One could go on and on. I must say, in passing, that `separations' is defence-speaking for quitting the service, usually in a huff.

The importance of this report is that it draws the attention of senators and the nation as a whole to a matter which is crucial to the defence of Australia. It is vital that the message does not slip into oblivion like its predecessor, the Cross report on the management of Australia's defence. This Government has a poor track record when it comes to reports on defence. Apart from its dismissal of the report on the Department of Defence, it was almost a year before any substantial implementation of the long awaited Hamilton recommendation occurred. The hopes and expectations which are riding on the immediate implementation of that report made that year weigh very heavily with service families. Today many of Mrs Hamilton's recommendations, particularly those involving government spending, are still awaiting implementation: the really meaningful ones such as meaningful child care assistance; dealing with the problems of separated spouses; providing a system to assist spouses with employment as they move around the country; and providing a meaningful disturbance allowance for all these many occasions when they move the whole house and the family from one side of Australia to another. They are always out of pocket, and the disturbance allowance has not kept up with the times. The education allowance also does not help. Only 77 children in the whole of the Defence Force get the benefit of it.

The Government also seems to be finding Mr Cooksey's report on the Review of Australia's Defence Cooperation Programs and Policy on Export of Defence Equipment a little difficult to handle. We just cannot allow history to be repeated with this report for it documents what I have been predicting and warning the Government about for many long months. Indeed, as you would recall, Madam Acting Deputy President, I talked about these matters when I first arrived in the Parliament 2 1/2 years ago.

The importance of this report is that it demonstrates that the Government has failed. The Government has failed because the numbers leaving the services are still rising. Each year for the last four years these numbers have inexorably risen. The Government has failed because it will not put enough money into the personnel share of the Budget. It is now 43 per cent and that is far too low. When the Government took office, it was 50 per cent, and year by year it has dropped. The Government has failed because it has not shown the leadership needed to deal with the morale problems caused by the bloated defence bureaucracy. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel too, has failed. She has no influence in Cabinet, no financial authority, and she has spent her days in a public relations exercise devoted to trivia and to a disastrous operation known as the pilot retention bonus, while the real issues of complete review of pay and allowances, career development and management are ignored.

We are witnessing the greatest exodus from the forces in the history of the Defence Force. Since 1983, over 44,000 men and women have fled from the forces. This cannot be passed off as part of a natural cycle or turnover. Last financial year the forces recruited 8,483 staff, but lost 9,327. This is no Vietnam hump, as suggested by the Minister; this is the deliberate resignation of many frustrated and disillusioned men and women, as is demonstrated by the fact that 41 per cent of those quitting the forces last year were not eligible for pensions. These people could not even wait long enough to claim any benefits accruing from their years of service.

Mrs Kelly made a submission to the Committee which has just reported, as I did myself. In her submission she stressed that the Defence Force has sustained its manpower in terms of its average strength due to successful recruiting. This simply reveals her ignorance or, alternatively, the bad advice she receives, since she fails to take into account the nature of the recruiting figures. All the recruiting in the world cannot replace the valuable knowledge, skill and experience, which comes from service of between six years and 16 years in most cases, that is being drained from the forces as those most experienced and valuable ranks leave. For example, the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) is 84 pilots short of its optimum operating level, 32.5 per cent short of airborne electrical analysts and 24 per cent of flight engineers have resigned, leaving the RAAF 12 short of the restricted manning level which has been forced upon them. The Navy is desperately short of electrical and communications engineers and radar plotters and the pension ineligible separation numbers-that is, the people leaving without a pension entitlement-as a whole fell by 282, but the officer component of this category registered an increase of 18.4 per cent.

Just why are these people leaving? They are leaving, as the report clearly demonstrates, because they are skilled professionals and this Government is treating them no better than navvies. The men and women of our Services and their families cannot, as this Government seems to believe, survive simply on patriotism and loyalty, although they have plenty of that. For the most part, they are not leaving because they do not like the job; they are leaving because the job simply is not viable in terms of pay, service conditions and career structure. It simply does not compare with what is available in other work sectors.

I would like to detail a number of specific problem areas and what I suggest we should do to correct them. When it comes to pay, the Government, having trained these men and women at an enormous cost these days, is foolishly only willing to pay them a fraction of what their skills are worth on the open market. This policy of penny wise and pound foolish means that the Government is providing the commercial sector with ready trained personnel at the expense of its own defence capability. British officers are earning an average of $10,500 more than their Australian counterparts, which must be the first time that that has occurred for at least 30 years; but worse, some of our lower ranks and trainees have to rely on welfare supplements to make ends meet.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is disgusting.

—It is disgusting. Despite the long hours being worked by service members-and that is at least 52 1/2 hours a week in many cases-this Government has established a track record of delay in reviewing allowances and pay. In other sectors workers would not put up with it, their unions would be screaming.

SPEECH.PARA: Fortunately, the Committee report has emphasised that there is an immediate need to implement a system of automatic pay review by the Remuneration Tribunal without the intervention of the Government or the Department of Defence. The Government needs to provide urgently meaningful resources so that its Tribunal can get on and do the job which has been promised to the defence forces-that is, a biennial review of their pay and allowances. The Defence Force Advocate needs to be free to appeal without the Secretary of the Department breathing down his neck and the Secretary should be removed from any involvement in the process. These are recommendations with which I heartily agree.

I refer now to the Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme. Servicemen are obliged to pay 5.5 per cent of their income every year into this scheme, but unless they stay for 20 years they simply receive their contributions back with not a penny of interest after all that time. That is a fund where the Government gets the benefit, but it is not the way unions would expect their superannuation funds to be worked these days, and nor should our defence forces expect to suffer that indignity either.

Apart from the pay, the problems associated with the unique lifestyle of the Defence Force-for example, things like frequent postings-are proving to be major contributing factors to the wastage in the forces, as many of the exit surveys the Government has received have revealed. I do not intend to spend time on housing today, except to say that 60 per cent of the housing is substandard by the Department's own assessment. The Government has moved-I give it credit for this-to establish the Defence Housing Authority. Unfortunately, the nature of the beast is such that it will require more than $750m over 10 years to replace or upgrade 60 per cent of substandard housing which the forces are currently being required to live in and pay rent for.

The Joint Committee on Public Works of the Parliament did a wide survey of single personnel in the forces. The survey revealed that their accommodation was inadequate and noisy, which made it difficult for people to study, and there was no privacy and practically no storage for individuals. From my own inspection of single accommodation, that is quite true. The Committee has recommended the upgrading of this accommodation be speeded up, that covered carports be provided for single personnel and that until such time as adequate accommodation is provided, the living out allowance should be made more flexible so that servicemen can go and get their own accommodation outside the forces if they choose.

That is a humane recommendation which I would have expected the Government to put into operation long before this. Professional people are living in welfare-standard housing or worse in some of the most undesirable areas in Australia. I get the most pathetic letters from servicemen saying, `I am not going to stay in this area any longer, with my family being stood over by drug pushers and standover people, with petty vandalism and minor theft'. Some suburban areas where defence people are now posted have some of the greatest social problems that we face in this country. That is not good enough for people who have pledged to defend the standards of this country. I would have expected that they would be entitled to the standards that they are pledged to defend.

We have heard a great deal from the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel about her efforts in the education area. I welcome the fact that she has recognised that it is a problem. Unfortunately, the publicity campaign does not quite match the reality. The reality is that the tuition allowance that she talks about has actually produced coaching for 27 children. We have 30,000 married servicemen in the forces: 27 children are in receipt of tuition allowance. An education allowance was already in existence, and Mrs Kelly tells us that she has seen to it that the criteria for that allowance have been freed up. They have certainly been freed up; they are almost incomprehensible. The number of children now benefiting from the education allowance, which enables them to stay in a State if there is disruption to their education, has risen from 55 to 77. I hardly think that that is a matter for a national publicity campaign. If Mrs Kelly was really serious about it she would see to it that that education allowance was available to any secondary school child of service personnel whose parents were facing a move. That would really be something to talk about.

This Government continually berates employers for the need to provide employer based child-care. I remember Senator Devereux in Tasmania not long ago representing the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and telling employers how much more productive their work force would be and how much higher the morale of their work force would be if child-care were provided by the employer. Charity begins at home. If Senator Devereux really believes what he says, he should be working very hard on his Ministry because it is certainly not prepared to do that with its own employees. I am talking about young men and women, young mothers who are thousands of miles away from their own mothers or sisters, with no back-up family support, being asked to live in all sorts of odd and difficult places. They are going into areas where their children are on the bottom of the queue for child-care and do not reach the top until they leave the area. The Minister has to do something urgently about this. Mrs Hamilton two years ago urged that that be done. The Minister is still conducting a study. It is just not good enough.

Another recommendation of the Hamilton report related to spouse employment. Typically in Australia today families are finding that with the reduced standards of living this Government has imposed upon them they need two incomes coming in. Members of the defence forces are no different. They desperately need that second income. It is much more difficult for them because they are constantly moving. It is very hard for wives to find employment, especially if they are known as service wives who will be here today and gone tomorrow. Mrs Hamilton recommended that an assistance scheme be set up to find employment for spouses of Defence Force personnel and to give priority to them in defence employment. The Committee has again recommended that but the Government has had two years since Mrs Hamilton made that recommendation to put it into operation and it still has not happened. Mrs Kelly has nothing to skite about.

Today's Defence Force members have had the benefit of extensive education and stringent selection procedures. They therefore possess specialist skills which should be valued and paid for. They are entitled to expect a sound career structure, presenting opportunities for responsibility, promotion and performance. They are also entitled to expect some consultation on issues and decisions which affect their lives and the lives of their families. But this is not what they get. As the report makes very clear, there is clearly a leadership problem within the Department. A lot of this is probably due to a lack of authority, in that many service issues lie outside the services' control or influence. The civilians in the departments of Defence, Industrial Relations and Finance rule the roost. It is therefore essential that the Government act on the recommendation to deal with the powerful position of some of the civilians in the conditions of service area.

I briefly draw attention to the service allowance fiasco, where the failure of the Chief of the Defence Force to appeal against a decision which was clearly not in the interests of servicemen had a disastrous effect upon morale and there has been some disillusionment with senior leadership. That is very sad to see and it has to be addressed. The report on the Defence Department, which I mentioned earlier in my speech, had major implications not only for the efficiency of the Department but also for the morale of those who are sent there to work and who see a large and frustrating road ahead. Other sectors of the work force would never stand for such conditions and would inevitably strike. But our Defence Force personnel cannot take that way out and instead they are leaving the forces en masse. Either way, it has the same effect-and so emasculates our defence capability.

What this Government, or at least this Defence Minister, does not seem to be able to grasp is that big guns, impressive planes and sophisticated ships cannot defend this country. It is the well trained and experienced people who operate them that we depend upon. It is they who defend this country. With the Government's present spending priorities-29.1 per cent on equipment, 27.9 per cent on operations, and 43 per cent on personnel-and the enormous $8,567m outstanding financial commitment it has ahead of it for equipment, we are rapidly approaching a situation where we will be left with extremely sophisticated and technologically advanced equipment suitable for medium to high level conflicts but without the trained personnel to use it. We have a number of examples where equipment is already undermanned or undermaintained, and in some cases mothballed. I shall not go into the details of that now for pressure of time.

We have an increasingly greater proportion of the forces in training-just over 11 per cent at 30 June 1988-and that leads to a dilution of experience and expertise. As the report so clearly states, it leads to enormous cost. Money that could be spent elsewhere keeping these people in is being used to train new people to replace them. This situation is even more alarming and the Government's priorities even more awry when one considers that our most likely threat is a low level one, and very labour intensive in terms of patrol surveillance and high mobility. What if the Indonesian fishing boats had been full of armed men? We would have had real problems in this country. As Brigadier Alan Hodges, Western Australia's most senior soldier, said in the West Australian on 8 March this year:
Small forces of men could come ashore undetected, well kitted and well armed. They could do a lot of damage.

If one visits, as I have, the Northern bases of Australia, such as Darwin or Tindal, it is clear what a mess we would be in if groups of commandos set out to damage several of our northern bases at once.

Professor Des Ball, the defence analyst at the Australian National University Centre for Strategic and Defence Studies, has said that the effective defence of Australia's northern bases would require nine battalions. At the present time Australia has only six battalions. Yet despite such opinions, the Minister continues to accumulate capital equipment while our personnel suffer. Given the vulnerability of Australia's terrain, the location of its strategic bases and vital national areas, and the number of people required to defend it, this is a dangerous path. Emphasis in government spending must shift away from total attention on equipment to a balanced attention on personnel and operations. A shift of only one to two per cent from capital equipment would deal with the problems of manning levels and the personnel wastage that we are now facing. Mrs Kelly, in her submission to the inquiry, stressed the importance of the Committee's findings. I think this is a very relevant point and we should think about it very seriously. She said:

The sifting of fact and fiction that your committee is engaged in in this inquiry should go a long way towards making this debate more rational. In that way it will be an invaluable contribution to the defence of Australia.

Mrs Kelly's submission was dated August this year. She seems to have suddenly changed her mind when she found that she, her fellow Minister and her Government had been put in the hot seat by a bipartisan parliamentary committee. She set the parameters within which these matters should be considered, and she has in fact accepted in advance her own shortcomings and those of the Defence Minister and the Government as a whole. But, to give her her due, I think she has been trying, although with very little success. It is time for the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, to take off his blinkers and face up to the reality. What is needed is an honest appraisal, a commitment and the courage to change direction. Words will not upgrade living standards or allowances, and promises will not improve management techniques. They need to be accompanied by financial commitment.

This report of the Committee gives the Government a blueprint on which to base its future conduct. But it has no time to spare. It has been warned now for several years that its neglect would prove disastrous. It is now five minutes to midnight for the defence forces. Nothing less than an immediate and total commitment will reverse the process of deterioration and emasculation within the forces, and nothing less will preserve the capable and credible defence of this country.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Assent to the following Bills reported:
Industrial Relations Bill 1988
Industrial Relations (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1988

DEBATE.TITLE: CENSUS AND STATISTICS AMENDMENT (VOLUNTARY PROVISION OF SURVEY INFORMATION) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 October, on motion by Senator Sheil:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the Senate this evening to speak strongly in favour of a Bill-the Census and Statistics Amendment (Voluntary Provision of Survey Information) Bill-introduced by Senator Glen Sheil, which relates to the Australian Bureau of Statistics and its most incredible household expenditure survey. The Implications of this Bill are not solely about the household expenditure survey, although that is the current issue; more importantly, the Bill which Senator Sheil has introduced seeks to protect the privacy of every individual Australian.

SPEECH.PARA: Now privacy can mean many things to many people. The Macquarie Dictionary defines privacy as `the state of being private; retirement or seclusion'. I believe that privacy means the right which every Australian has to live his or her life without being threatened, to be able to keep his or her intimate family and financial matters amongst themselves and to be undisturbed. Contrasting this, we have the household expenditure survey, a survey which has been the method by which the Australian Bureau of Statistics has sought to extract those intimate details from ordinary Australians. By its action, the Australian Bureau of Statistics is becoming the Big Brother of Australian Bureaucracy, and its officers may soon find themselves in a position where they are nothing more than peeping toms spying through household keyholes and through windows where curtains have not been drawn.

Some 7,500 households have been targeted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for this survey. It is not a minor survey; indeed, it contains a 22-page income and a 110-page expenditure questionnaire. It also contains a two-week spending diary plus a form authorising the Bureau to extract loan details from those unlucky persons' banks. Now, depending on the circumstances and the amount of financial transactions which the family may have, they may be required to answer anything from 300 to 1,100 questions. It is right and proper that the people of Australia should be outraged by this survey. It is also right and proper that we, as their elected representatives, should seek to do something about it. I am very pleased that Senator Sheil has brought this Bill forward to do something.

I do not wish to take up too much of the Senate's time on individual cases, but I would point out that my office has received numerous complaints about the survey, and that has been going on for quite some time. They are complaints which are coming from a broad spectrum of social groups all of whom are considerably outraged by its consequences. I have had people threatening violence over the survey. No doubt those people who have been distributing the questionnaires could attest to similar threats. But, more importantly, I have also had elderly pensioners with a few hundred dollars in the bank who have been reduced to tears over this matter.

What I question is this: is it the Australian Bureau of Statistics which is at fault, or is it the Government which has chosen to allow this matter to progress without following the proper procedures? I refer to the failure of the Australian Bureau of Statistics to table this document. Section 6 (3) of the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act states:

. . . each new proposal for the collection of information for statistical purposes by the Bureau shall be laid before both Houses of the Parliament before its implementation, unless the proposal is for the collection of information on a voluntary basis.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics contends that, because this household expenditure survey is a repeat of the 1984 household expenditure survey, it did not need to table the new details. But anyone who has had even the briefest look at the two surveys can tell quite clearly that they are very different. There was, therefore, a requirement that this new survey, which contains a number of new and more prying questions, should have been tabled to make it legal, and this is a view which has been supported by a number of very eminent individuals. I would like to quote some of them. The first most of us would be aware of is by Peter O'Keeffe, Clerk-Assistant (Procedure) from the Senate. He said:

It is, however, strongly arguable that, since the proposal for the 1984 HES was not a proposal for a regular, annual, survey, the 1988 Survey in fact and in law relates to a ``new proposal'' which should have been tabled in Parliament. If this argument is valid the failure of the ABS to table a new proposal has the effect, under subsection 6 (3) of the ABSA, of rendering the current survey a voluntary one only. No new proposal can be ``implemented'' by the Bureau until it has been tabled, unless participation in the survey is to be voluntary.

I am inclined to the view that the current survey is in fact and in law a new survey for which there has been no tabled proposal. There was no indication in the proposal tabled in 1988 that it related to any HES survey other than that to be conducted in 1984.
This was backed up by Robert K. O'Connor, a barrister from Cathedral Square in Perth, Western Australia, who said:
I agree with the Opinion expressed by Mr O'Keeffe on both questions.
He quoted six reasons and went on to say:
In my view, the inescapable conclusion is that the 1988-89 survey is a ``new proposal''. It is of a similar type or kind to the earlier proposal, but it itself is nevertheless a new proposal.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics' own advice to itself, if you like, was that the survey should have been tabled. I would like to quote from an Australian Bureau of Statistics' minute paper, which says in part:

The Household Expenditure Survey is the most burdensome household survey undertaken by the ABS and is also considered to be highly intrusive by some members of the community. As a consequence, the survey tends to generate Ministerials arising from complaints by constituents to their Local Members of Parliament. Being able to say that the survey had been tabled and subject to parliamentary scrutiny then becomes a very useful ABS tactic.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! At Question Time today, Senator Vanstone asked me a question relating to the printing of a press release. I undertook to advise honourable senators further when I had established the facts of the matter. I have been advised that yesterday Senator Vanstone sought to have a press release comprising one page of text and two pages of illustrations from a video cover printed by the Department of the Senate's printing unit.
