SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take up a short time in the Senate this evening to outline that earlier this year a constituent brought to my attention the fact that on the 1988 Form S Tax Guide toll free numbers were listed for Sydney, Melbourne, Perth, Adelaide and Hobart. Thus, residents outside those centres who wanted to make contact with the Australian Taxation Office in their capital city could telephone that office for the cost of a local call. No such toll free number was provided for Brisbane. My constituent, who lives on the Gold Coast, quite properly asked why he was obliged to use STD facilities while those in other States could use a toll free number. I could not answer this person's valid question, so I placed a question on notice to the Treasurer (Mr Keating). The question was in four parts. Part one read:

SPEECH.PARA: Did the 1988 Form S Tax Guide have Taxation Office telephone contacts on the rear page?
The answer to that question was yes. Part two of my question read:
If so, were toll free numbers provided for Sydney, Melbourne, Perth, Adelaide and Hobart?
The answer to that question was yes. Part three of my question read as follows:
Was a toll free number listed for Brisbane or were inquirers from outside the Brisbane area directed to telephone a Brisbane telephone number using STD.
The answer to that question was:
A toll free number was not listed for Brisbane. Enquiries from outside the Brisbane area were required to use an STD number.
However, I take issue with the answer to my question No. 4. Question No. 4 read:
If Brisbane was the only capital city for which non-metropolitan residents were not directed to use a toll free number, why was that so.
In part the answer read:

The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) recognises the value and importance of providing a toll-free inquiry service for non-metropolitan residents. A detailed study of toll-free telephone requirements was undertaken in late 1987 for the purpose of identifying deficiencies in the provision of the service and to provide a basis for allocating funds for remedial action. At that time a number of Branch Offices already had toll-free telephones in use but others, including the Brisbane Office, did not.

There is a little more to that answer, but it is not relevant to the question I asked. Indeed, what I have read out of the answer to question four was not relevant to the question I asked anyway. It is perhaps written in a bureaucratic language that someone understands, but certainly I do not. It did not answer the question that I asked. If five capital cities were able to have toll free numbers, why could not Brisbane? That was the question, but it was not answered. Whoever cleared the question was acting in a cavalier way to a perfectly reasonable question. There is no point in my pursuing the matter further, unless the Treasurer considers that it is worth asking his Department to respond properly. What I will say, however, is that residents near Brisbane expect the same facilities as taxpayers in other States. If they do not, in future I shall ask why. I shall not accept a non-answer again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time today Senator Vanstone referred a matter to the President, on which he has just made a statement, relating to the refusal of the Senate printing unit to publish attachments to a press release because those attachments contained depictions of explicit sex, which they do. I have the press release with the attachments in my possession, as I regret to say perhaps so do a lot of others. The Senate debated the subject of explicit sex material yesterday, and the senator who led the debate for the Opposition thundered about the Government's hypocrisy in wanting to delay the question of banning totally X-rated-that is non-violent explicit-erotica. In that debate the hypocrisy of Senator Hill was exposed very quickly indeed by Senator Crowley--
—Order! I think the honourable senator will have to use other words.

—Exposed very quickly by Senator Crowley when she read an extract from a speech that Senator Hill himself had delivered on 15 October this year. It was not dug out of the Hansard of four, five or 10 years ago. It was delivered here in Canberra at a public seminar on sexism in advertising. Senator Hill led a debate in this chamber yesterday condemning the Government for not agreeing at this time to ban non-violent, non-coercive explicit erotica. On 15 October at a public seminar Senator Hill said-and, I am told by many people who were there, said very vociferously indeed-that he would not agree to regulation of advertising on television-even if, presumably, it were sexist or offensive-because, to quote Senator Hill, he was totally opposed to censorship. However, we know that scarcely two or three weeks later Senator Hill led a debate in this chamber. If at any stage honourable senators in this chamber are a little concerned that they may be verging close to committing the crime of hypocrisy, then before they condemn themselves they should compare whatever they intend to do with the performance of Senator Hill-a performance that one would have to describe as a benchmark in that area, breathtaking indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: We had another performance today from Senator Vanstone, which I condemn utterly-and I shall be very surprised if Senator Harradine does not condemn it when he hears the facts, particularly if he looks at the extraordinary press release with its even more extraordinary attachment distributed by Senator Vanstone. Senator Vanstone has in fact broken the law in a serious fashion indeed. If the same breach of law had been committed by the retailers whom Senator Vanstone thunders against, they would be subjected to very serious penalties indeed, including heavy fines and imprisonment. Senator Vanstone herself as an individual is also liable for penalties, including heavy fines and/ or imprisonment-and so she should be.

First of all, I would like to refer to the guidelines for the elimination of sexual harassment in the workplace because, unfortunately, as well as committing a serious offence against the Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 of the Australian Capital Territory, Senator Vanstone has directly breached the guidelines for the elimination of sexual harassment in the workplace and has exposed herself, I think-I hope it is not unparliamentary to say so-as a fool. Before she raised the matter with the President today she should have read page 1 of the very guidelines she referred to. Of course, Senator Vanstone was trying to make a point, a very silly point, that because the woman who was in charge of the print office found the material offensive-as was her right to find it-she refused to publish it. Senator Vanstone obviously is trying to make the point that that constituted a proven case that this material of itself was offensive, and in fact, qualified to be classed as sexual harassment in the workplace. Of course, Senator Vanstone did not bother reading the guidelines. They are very sensible, sane and reasonable guidelines. Senator Vanstone simply breached them in an offensive way-in a way I would have been offended about if I had been in charge of the print shop. I will read the guidelines because they are very sensible indeed. They state:
Sexual harassment is a form of discrimination and as such should not be condoned or tolerated in the workplace--
hear, hear!-
It includes a wide range of behaviour of a sexual nature which causes another person distress-
this is the key point-
for such behaviour to constitute sexual harassment it must be unwanted, unsolicited and unreciprocated.

The woman in charge of the print shop did not want the explicit sexual material that Senator Vanstone seems to be so besotted with. She did not solicit it. The guidelines for sexual harassment were certainly breached, and breached by Senator Vanstone herself in the most outrageous and offensive way.

There is another far more serious problem in regard to what Senator Vanstone did. I am not making political points. This is not rhetoric. I am extremely angry indeed in regard to Senator Vanstone's impossible, disgraceful actions today in issuing this stuff. Unfortunately, press releases from politicians are not restricted publications; they are spread, as this one has been spread, widely everywhere. They are freely available to any- body. No retailer of explicit sex in Canberra is permitted--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not from me they were not.

—It is all over the place. Senator Vanstone issued the press release. She obviously photocopied the material and attached it. I have certainly seen that material all over the place today. I would strongly advise Senator Vanstone in her own interests to stop publishing it and to withdraw those copies of the press release which she can get her hands on. Senator Vanstone in fact has committed a serious offence-an offence I personally condemn-in attaching scenes of explicit sex to a press release. These are scenes which are not legally available to anyone under the age of 18 years in the Australian Capital Territory, or anywhere else. They have been attached to a press release which is freely available. That is contemptible behaviour. The best that could be said about it is that it is irresponsible. However, it is also criminal behaviour. I would like to refer to the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983. Section 47 of that Ordinance states:

SPEECH.PARA: 47 (1) A person who advertises, or sells or otherwise publishes-
Senator Vanstone published this material-
a publication, being
(a) a Category 1 or a Category 2 restricted publication; or
(b) a film classified as an `R' film or an `X' film,
otherwise than in accordance with the conditions applicable to that publication, is guilty of an offence.

The publication by Senator Vanstone of this explicit material which is not otherwise available in the ACT, unless it is on restricted premises that can be entered only by a person 18 years of age or over, involves, in the case of a body corporate:
. . . a fine not exceeding $2,500; and,
(d) in the case of an individual-by a fine not exceeding $500 or by imprisonment for a period not exceeding three months, or both.
Senator Vanstone also has breached the second sub-section in this section of the Ordinance. Section 47 (2) states:
A person who deposits, or causes to be deposited-
(a) a Category 1 or Category 2 restricted publication; or
as Senator Vanstone has-
(b) a film classified as an `R' film or an `X' film, in or on a public place-
which this Parliament House is-
except with the permission of the occupier-
I am an occupier and I did not give her my permission. I am sure the President did not. In fact, the President through his print office presumably refused permission. The Ordinance continued;
. . . ia guilty of an offence punishable, on conviction-
(c) in the cae of a body corporate-by a fine not exceeding $5,000; and
(d) in the case of an individual-
the individual being Senator Vanstone-
by a fine not exceeding $1,000 or by imprisonment for a period not exceeding 6 months, or both.

It appears that Senator Vanstone has breached two sections of the Publications Ordinance which would give her a maximum cumulative sentence of $5,500 and/or nine months in prison. It might be a great relief to all of us in here if the second part of the penalty were applied to Senator Vanstone. I do not think she should be prosecuted. The reason I do not think she should be prosecuted is that I think it would give her more publicity, frankly, than she is worth. I might say, having gone through this publication, that she has probably breached-I have had only 10 minutes in which to look at it-a number of other sections of this Ordinance as well. In fact, she has in my view, certainly on the face of it, been guilty of a serious offence. She has certainly been guilty of committing an offence which, if it were committed by a retailer of explicit sex material-the sort of person she rails against-would be punishable indeed by very serious penalties of both imprisonment and fines.

As I say again, I am not in here to prosecute Senator Vanstone, although I think she probably deserves it. I am here to condemn her as an individual and as a senator for attaching explicit sexual material to a public press release, which is not restricted, containing material which, in the ACT where she published it, would be behind locked doors with big signs saying that one has to be 18 years or over to go in and look at it. I might add that the retailers of explicit sexual material are not permitted to advertise that material by publishing any of the depictions that the press release contains-as Senator Vanstone is well aware. She should be ashamed of herself at the very least. Politicians' press releases, certainly my press releases, have found their way into school libraries. I know of a number of schools in the Northern Territory which regularly collect public statements by political figures in the Northern Territory. I am referring to high schools that are full of children under the age of 18 years. Frankly, I think this is contemptible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have sat here and listened to comments that I thought were--
—What is your point of order?

—I have listened to comments that I thought were a reflection on Senator Vanstone. Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you to rule those comments out of order and ask Senator Collins to withdraw. I would have thought that to describe a senator as contemptible would be contrary to Standing Orders.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order, very simply I did not describe Senator Vanstone as contemptible. I described her act as contemptible. I do not resile from that.
—There is no point of order.
—Mr Acting Deputy President--
—I have ruled on the point of order, Senator Boswell.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I have another point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 418. I think that you should call Senator Collins to order because I believe he has transgressed standing order 418 a number of times in his speech. I would ask you to ask him to desist.
—There has been no breach of standing order 418 to this stage. I call Senator Collins.

—I believe that it is incumbent on any senator in this House, if such a senator is concerned about children seeing or reading this material, to raise it to the attention of the House. I said in the debate yesterday that my major concern-the concern that I expressed all through the hearings of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material-was the potential access of children to this material. I should have thought that that was a sentiment that would be shared by every senator in this chamber. For the sake of scoring a few rather cheap political points, for the sake of missing the mark completely, as she did in terms of the sexual harassment guidelines when in fact she is the one who committed the breach of them in forcing material which was entirely unwanted and unsolicited on a woman in the print room-that act in itself is contempt- ible-Senator Vanstone has taken actions today which no retailer, that I am aware of, of any explicit sexual material in the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory would have taken, in attaching to a public press release of hers photocopied pictures of explicit sex scenes from X-rated movies. I am prepared to give the honourable senator the benefit of the doubt in this matter. I think she has committed a gross error of judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: My position on explicit sexual material is very simple. There should be a category of non-violent erotica (NVE). That is hardly a secret. Anyone who has taken the trouble to read the Joint Select Committee's report-and I regret to say that many people who have been following this debate have not bothered to do that-will see my position stated there very clearly.

I was the first person to raise in the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory my concern that X-rated material was freely available; it was being retailed in supermarkets and service stations in the Northern Territory and was causing considerable concern and disquiet in the community. I raised the matter as the then Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory. I am pleased to say that, with the total cooperation of the then Chief Minister, Mr Ian Tuxworth, legislation-the first of its kind-was introduced into the Northern Territory Parliament which treated R-rated and X-rated category material in precisely the same way, and put it behind locked doors. The position was logical and reasonable. That is, if the law says that a person cannot have access to X-rated material if he or she is not 18 years of age or over, and if the law says that a person cannot have access to R-rated material unless he or she is 18 years of age or over, they both should be treated in the same way and at least we should do something positive instead of simply paying lip-service to the violent and sexually violent material available in the R-rated category. That is what we did in the Northern Territory. The system has been operating for 12 months, and I can say with absolute certainty that it has eased the disquiet that many people had because of their concern that this material would fall into the hands of minors-precisely, I might add, by her actions today, where Senator Vanstone has potentially placed it.

I have not seen too much redeeming material in the X-rated category. I have seen some of it which was satirical and which I thought was very clever and funny-satirising, I might add, the censors and censorship. I have seen some of it that could be described fairly as material of very high quality and constituting artistic merit of great degree. But the majority of the material is trash. The majority of it is boring, and I dislike most of it. The problem is that I dislike censorship, particularly the censors-the self-appointed ones-even more, and that is the balance one has to strike.

I thought that Senator Hill in the debate yesterday totally contradicted a thundering public statement that he had made in this city only three weeks before when he said he opposed censorship and would not even agree to regulating offensive advertising. Certainly Senator Vanstone's behaviour today has convinced me once again that if I had any lingering political doubts about the rightness of the position I am taking, I am certainly on the side of the angels in this debate.

I draw the attention of Senator Vanstone to the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 and to the fact that the retailers of the material which she continually brings into this House-she seems to have a fascination with Bill's Big Banana, because she has brought the actual video into the chamber at Question Time on a number of occasions and flashed it from the front--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I have listened with some patience to Senator Collins. He obviously feels very strongly about the point he wants to make. I have allowed a number of unparliamentary remarks and, I think, unfair or improper imputations against myself to go past in the interests of letting Senator Collins put his case, and it is the latter portion of his remarks that I take offence to and I ask that he withdraw them.
—Order! Any imputations of improper motives are contrary to standing order 418.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I withdraw any reflections that I made on the senator. I simply state as a matter of fact-I was interested to see it-that part of the explicit sexual material depicted in the attachments to Senator Vanstone's press release contained once again scenes from the movie that she has actually physically brought into this Chamber on previous occasions. I am simply saying that I did not solicit that material to be brought in here; I did not want it; and I would rather Senator Vanstone did not bring it in here again, because it offends me and I do not like it. If I want to watch it, I will go to the premises where it is legally available and watch it there, or I will hire it and take it to my own home and watch it, or I will watch it because Parliament tells me that I should watch it as a member of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, carrying out a function which I think probably has not corrupted me all that much, by viewing that material. But I do not particularly want it brought into this chamber, where there are public galleries full of school children at Question Time-when Senator Vanstone brought the video in here.

SPEECH.PARA: I call your attention, Mr Acting Deputy President, to what I did on both occasions that I have spoken on X-rated material. On both occasions I prefaced my remarks by warning people-and I was particularly cognisant of the children-both in this new Parliament House and the old Parliament House, that I was going to discuss, as I had to, this material. I gave them and the people who were looking after them the opportunity to take the children out of the Parliament. That was not any grandstanding move on my part. It was done because of a genuine belief I have that I do not particularly like discussing this material in front of young children. However, one would hardly suggest that matters as serious as this should not be discussed in a parliament of adults. Of course not; we all discuss them. But I gave fair warning that I was going to do so, and I just wish that Senator Vanstone would stop doing what she has done.

Senator Vanstone would probably accuse me of having standards that have slipped. Perhaps they have. Perhaps I have fallen a little from grace, and perhaps the reason that I have done so is that I was a regular watcher-in fact I tuned in again-and perhaps even dependent on the moral advice and strictures of the Reverend Jimmy Swaggart. We get Jim in the Northern Territory at 7 o'clock every Sunday morning. When Jim was not available I used to listen to Jimmy Bakker for my moral guidance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you being sarcastic?

—No, I tuned in. I do not know why my motives are being impugned. I regularly watch Jimmy Swaggart, in simple fascination, often with tears streaming down his face, his Bible clutched to his breast, storming up and down in front of thousands of people, heaving $50 bills into plastic buckets, and I never cease to be amazed at what fools people can be. I tuned in to Jimmy Swaggart's program last Sunday at 7 a.m., because it is still being broadcast in the Northern Territory. I watched that good ol' boy storming up and down the platform with his Bible, thundering at the congregation, as so many self-appointed moralists and guardians of the public morals do, about the sins of the flesh. He was telling me-because I felt it was directed at me-that if I did not pull my socks up and become as morally astringent as Jimmy Swaggart, a big lightning bolt with my name on it would come down out of the skies and zap me clean off the earth. The trouble is, though, that I had to turn if off after five minutes-I usually manage to watch him for about 15 minutes-because I saw Jimmy, and I could not get it out of my head after the TV show was over, the lights were turned off, the plug was pulled out of the organ, the congregation gone and the choir sent home, having a quick dab around his eyes with a kleenex, sprinting up the aisle, grabbing a handful of $100 bills out of the nearest plastic bucket and off to the nearest motel with a prostitute and a Polaroid camera.
—You don't think he won't pay a price for that?
—He does not seem to have paid a price. I am confident he will probably pay a price for it after he leaves.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I just want to say this to Senator Vanstone again. Please read carefully the ordinance I have referred to. Please consider carefully the serious penalties attached to what you did today-a $5,000 fine and/or six months in prison-and desist from doing it again. If Senator Vanstone wants to make political points she should confine that activity to the Chamber without the explicit material being brought in here. I would ask Senator Vanstone whether she could give this House an assurance that she will make sure after she leaves this chamber that any of that material that she has published has not left this Parliament and that all copies of it, unsolicited and unwanted as they are, that were distributed around this Parliament, are withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard 95 per cent humbug and 5 per cent--
—Have you a copy of this document?

—Yes, I have and I will be dealing with it. That is why I asked how Senator Vanstone had committed a crime. We have heard 95 per cent humbug and 5 per cent on a matter of some concern. I will deal with the 5 per cent matter of some concern. Had I been in this position I would not have sent the material, as Senator Vanstone did, to the Senate Printing Unit for reproduction. She can speak for herself on the matter. Senators have printing services available to them. I suppose that if there were a problem that was it. Quite rightly, the Senate Printing Unit took offence at this material and refused to print it. That is a reflection on the material itself as much as on the perhaps not so wise decision to send it to the Printing Unit. I will leave it at that.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the other 95 per cent which was utter humbug. Is Senator Collins threatening Senator Vanstone? Is he trying to shut up Senator Vanstone or other people from revealing to responsible people the nature, intent and content of this material? That is what we are talking about. Or is he reflecting upon the whole of the Press Gallery, suggesting that it in some way is not responsible and should not know what is in this material? That is what Senator Collins has been about all the time. That is what Senator Zakharov has been about all the time. That is what Dr Dick Klugman has been about. Let me prove it.

I ask honourable senators to look at the majority report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. I ask them to look at the chapter dealing with the current Commonwealth laws on video material. I ask them to look at chapter 5 of the majority report. The majority report-that is, the Klugman, Zakharov, Collins, Jenkins and Jakobsen report-is chapter 5 as well. I ask honourable senator to look at section 5.32, which is the same in both reports. It deals with what it contained in the X classification. In our chapter 5 of the majority report it says what Dick Klugman has been going around saying and what the Film Censorship Board says. It is a bland statement as to what is concerned in X-rated material. It states:
Material which includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, but does not include any depiction suggestion coercion or non-consent of any kind.
That is what it says in the majority report. Chapter 5.33 says:

Thus the subject matter drawing an X classification in December 1984 can include what was spelled out in the May 1984 guidelines-i.e. explicit penetration, masturbation, ejaculation, fellatio, cunnilingus, insertion of objects into orifices, miscellaneous other sexual activities and fetishes.
Is chapter 5.33 in the minority report? Of course it is not in the minority report because members of the Committee wanted to censor the facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, that's not true and you know it. It's not there because we want to relish the facts.

—I will deal with relish in a moment. I thank the honourable senator for reminding me. That is precisely what those members of the Committee did in its minority report. They attempted to censor what this material contained. They attempted to hide from the Parliament what this material actually contains. So we have in the public debate precisely that sort of censorship being conducted. Senator Collins was also a signatory to the minority report which misstated the legal position prior to 1984. We discussed this at length in the Committee proceedings. I do not think I am out of order by suggesting that we discussed this at length. Senator Collins included a statement in the report with which he was associated. It talked about the law prior to 1984 not covering videos. In fact, the law prior to 1984 did cover videos. This shows his ignorance and the ignorance of the other members of the minority of the actual law. Today we have had another example of the ignorance of Senator Collins of the actual law. Senator Collins referred to the possibility of Senator Vanstone breaching section 47 (2) (b) of the Classification of Publications Ordinance. I would hope that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) might listen to this because section 47 (2) (b) says:

SPEECH.PARA: A person who deposits, or causes to be deposited-
(a) a Category 1 or a Category 2 restricted publication-
which this is not-
or
(b) a film classified as a ``R'' film or an ``X'' film.
She did not deposit an R or an X film. Therefore, I cannot see how she would be liable under that provision. He said that she would be liable under 47 (1). Section 47 (1) says:
A person who advertises, or sells or otherwise publishes a publication . . .
What we have to do is look at the definition of the word `publication'. Publication is very broad and would normally include this material. However, the section goes on to say:
being-
a Category 1 or a Category 2 . . . or
a film classified as an `R' film or an `X' film,

Senator Vanstone did neither, unless her proposed action could be regarded as advertising. I am not too certain of that. Another section which I thought Senator Collins would have mentioned but did not was 48 (3) which states:
A person shall not publish any approved advertising matter in relation to a film except in accordance with the conditions (if any) to which the approval is subject.

That may apply: I do not know, because I am not sure of the conditions upon which this X-rated video received its X classification. I guarantee that nobody in this chamber would be sure of that either. The supporters of the Government's decision, which in effect rejected the unanimous request of the States to ban X-rated videos, are trying to censor information about what is contained in X-rated videos. Presumably, what Senator Vanstone was seeking to do-this is an argument that no doubt would be advanced by her-was to illuminate persons in a responsible position as to the nature of this material.

I now show the statements relating to this video to the Minister because I intend to seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard. I do so because I think it is important for members of the Parliament at least to know the nature of these videos. As Senator Collins said, it is important that we in this chamber know what we are talking about. If I am to be accused of doing something that is inappropriate, I do not think that it is inappropriate for members of this chamber to know the nature and content of X-rated videos. I believe that it is important for them to see whether they agree that this material falls within a category of erotica. However, I do not expect the Government to agree to my incorporating the statements until it has seen them. We have been faced with an attempt by Senator Collins and others associated with the minority of the Video Material Committee to censor information which ought to be known by responsible decision makers about the nature, content and intent of X-rated videos.

Senator Collins went on to say what he has been saying all along about violence-that is, people are being soft on violence. I again refer the Senate to the fact that the Joint Select Committee on Video Material recommended that films of relished violence be refused classification and banned. He said that people pay lip service to the problem of violence. What did he, Senator Jenkins, Senator Zakharov, Dr Klugman and Ms Jakobsen do about that? They did not place it in their recommendations. Yet we, the majority, were saying that films of relished violence should be banned. We are certainly not soft on violence.

The Government decided on Tuesday to establish a committee. The committee that is to be established will do two things: it will, firstly, note the public confusion about what is contained in X and R and, secondly, seek to institute a public education campaign to show the difference between X and R. I am trying to visualise Senator Tate running around the countryside with an R in one hand and an X in the other. But I cannot really imagine him running around the countryside with an R film in one hand and an X film in the other and showing people the difference, saying, `This one does not contain violence but it contains anal sex, group sex and the like, and this one contains violence'. What a lot of hooey. What will the committee do? What powers will it have?

Indeed, the Government is seven months too late because the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material recommended that the Film Censorship Board tighten up guidelines in the M and R classifications to the extent, as was said yesterday, that the top half of R ought to be banned and the top half of M ought to go into R. All the State Ministers, meeting on 30 June this year, instructed the Film Censorship Board and the Films Board of Review to undertake that task. What is the Caucus committee going to do? It has no power. The Film Censorship Board and the Films Board of Review do. The States knew that and they told them to get on with the job.

Tuesday's decision was a sham. It was an attempt to camouflage the fact that the Federal Government is continuing its legislative support for the hard core pornographic industry, against the express wishes of all the States and the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. The Commonwealth Government cannot say that the State Ministers did not know or were confused about what was in X-rated videos. They knew what was in this material, they knew the harm it could cause and they asked the Federal Government to ban it.

All members of the Committee saw the evidence. The majority of the Committee was persuaded by the evidence which was submitted to us by behavioural scientists and others that this material engenders in the mind of the habitual viewer a sexually calloused and manipulative attitude towards women. Anyone who studies X-rated videos will appreciate and understand that. This evidence was given to us by experts and others. We were also told that it engenders in the minds of regular viewers a perception of women in general as being highly promiscuous and available. Four of the behavioural science research papers that were presented to us-namely those of Professor Bryant, Professor Jennings, Professor Check and Professor Weaver-said that the type of material contained in Australian X-rated video material is more harmful in this regard than even violent pornography which is already banned in Australia. That is something which the Government must have regard to. Obviously the States have because they have made the request.

Senator Collins seems to be taking the running on this matter. He is going around the countryside saying that he went onto the Committee with a view that this material ought to be banned and that he came out of it saying that it ought not to be banned. As I said yesterday, the same Bob Collins, as a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, spoke in favour of and voted for the sale and hire of X-rated videos in the Northern Territory.

It has been suggested that some impropriety has taken place. As I say, I would not have sent the material down to the Senate Printing Unit. I do not blame the persons down there for taking the attitude that they did. I think that they are quite courageous. Nevertheless, we should not obscure the fact that the video industry and those who support it are trying to censor information about the nature, intent and content of the material in an effort to ensure that responsible decision makers do not know what is happening. That is a disgrace. Obviously the Caucus decision was based on false and censored information. The consequences of that deplorable decision will be visited upon individual members of Caucus in the electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Harradine sought to incorporate certain material. Is the honourable senator seeking leave to incorporate the printed material marked in pencil alongside certain illustrations?
—Yes, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—The Chair has examined the material and taken advice. In accordance with Senate precedent, the material is not appropriate for incorporation, neither can it be read into the Hansard.
—I suppose if I table it, it has to be reproduced.
—You can seek leave to table it, but it is not appropriate to table it either. The material is offensive and not suitable.
—Well, how do we make the laws, Mr Acting Deputy President?
—I am sorry. You may move a motion of dissent from the Chair's ruling if you wish. I call Senator Vanstone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last couple of days the Parliament has been discussing a very important issue, namely the availability of X-rated videos in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) and, through mail order, to the rest of Australia. Some honourable senators will know that I did not speak in the debate yesterday. My view on this material is perfectly clear. I made it clear some six months ago when I asked the Minister for Local Government, Senator Reynolds, a question pertaining to the Government's desire to advance and protect the status of women. The import of my question was that if the Government had a very strong desire, or even a mild desire, to protect the status of women, these sorts of trashy, offensive videos would be banned.

SPEECH.PARA: Not a lot has happened since then. The Minister's reply indicated that the State Attorneys-General were meeting some four of six weeks from the time that I asked the question, that they would express their view then as to what they wanted done and then the Commonwealth would decide. This brings us up to yesterday when the Commonwealth did decide that it is not going to take any notice of what the State Attorneys-General had decided; that X-rated videos, this trashy, offensive material, will continue to be available in the ACT. I accept that these videos are not freely available; I understand the limitations put on the availability of this material.

I think the material is offensive. I agree with the line of argument put forward by Senator Harradine. I do not know about other senators, but I do not make a habit of watching X-rated videos. I actually sought some X-rated videos to get some understanding of what everyone was complaining about. I found the cover of the two videos that my staff hired for a day or so so offensive that I decided not to bother looking at the contents. That satisfied me that the people making assessments about what goes into X-rated videos are not doing so in accordance with the views of the public. Many members of the public will say `yes' when asked if they think someone should be able to look at non-violent erotica. If one then describes to them some of the material that is depicted on the cover of a video provided by Senator Harradine, they would say no, they do not think that sort of material should be available. There is an ambiguity in the term `non-violent erotica'. It is a broad and general term. The availability of video 355 indicates the sort of trashy and offensive material that is available under the X classification.

I have sought on a number of occasions to raise this matter and to acquaint honourable senators who do not make a habit of looking at X-rated videos and seeing what is available, with just exactly what is available. Mr Acting Deputy President, it is no surprise to me that that material is unsuitable to be written or read into Hansard. I would be horrified to think that someone would object to your ruling in that respect.

Let me turn to Senator Collins. Senator Collins perhaps-I do not know-likes the sound of his own voice. When I asked him for the courtesy of giving me some indication of for how long he wished to speak, he indicated about 10 minutes. I note that he took the full 30 minutes. So perhaps he became engrossed with what he was saying and he enjoys the sound of his voice. He accuses me of perhaps accusing him of falling from grace, having some sort of lack of standards. It is extraordinary, a twist of logic, that someone who has not heard what someone else has got to say can feel comfortable to get up and say, `What she is probably going to do is tell me that my standards have fallen'. It is quite the opposite. I accept that Senator Collins has a different view about what we ought to make available to people who want it. We share the view, I am pleased to hear, that the said material is offensive. We obviously have simply a different view about whether it ought to be available. That is where we differ. I am absolutely lost at the relevance of Jimmy Swaggart, and there is no point in me wasting any time on the seven to 10 minutes that Senator Collins donated to this chamber describing what he does on Sunday mornings. I would not degrade the chamber by attempting to verbalise the scenes in the said material to which Senator Collins referred.

Let me refer to some of the bush lawyer skills that Senator Collins has displayed. He says that this is a public press release. He indicated to the chamber that it is freely available just about anywhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was given to me by a member of the public, Senator.
—Senator Collins can say where he got a copy from and he can imagine in his mind where anyone else got a copy from, but he cannot deduce from that that those copies were provided by me.
—I did not say they were, Senator. I said you published them, and you deposited them in the boxes in the Press Gallery-all of them.

—As I understood the run of Senator Collins's argument, it is that if one publishes some material, for example, to one person and that person publishes it to every Tom, Dick and Harry, the first publisher is responsible for the second publisher's actions. I need not say any more than that. Anybody who has the faintest twinkling with respect to legal matters will understand what I am saying. He further says that I have put children at risk by making this material available. That is his allegation. I am surprised that he does not concern himself with whether or not there are children under 18 years of age opening the mail that arrives, that Australia Post makes money out of delivering, that the taxpayers make money out of delivering this sort of trashy material, and there is no-one at the other end to inquire whether there is an 18-year-old or over going to open it. I am surprised that Senator Collins did not take the opportunity to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that this Government participates in making money out of this sort of trashy material by allowing Australia Post to convey it all around Australia from the Australian Capital Territory. If that is not the case and if the Government does not want that to be the case, then let it legislate accordingly. But we have heard in the last couple of days what the Government thinks. It is not going to legislate to stop it. We all know what inquisitive children are like. They say, `Oh, there is a letter for mum, a package for dad; let's have a look'.
—But also it could be a child who is requesting it.

—As Senator Harradine has said, perhaps a child could acquire this material through mail order. But I am simply making the point that one cannot infer that because something is available all over the place and has been available in one place, that the person who first distributed the material has distributed it to the full distribution, nor can we apportion blame so narrowly in that respect. If Senator Collins is friends with members of the Press Gallery who choose to then reproduce and republish material unwisely, then that is his choice and their choice, and I am sorry that that is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins then made the allegation that I had improperly behaved in some way-and I think I quote correctly-by forcing this material on some unfortunate woman in the Senate Printing Unit. We do not like to call it the reproduction unit any more. I beg to differ with Senator Collins's version of those events. I did send the material down, but plenty of senators have sent material down and had it sent back. I understand that Labor senators are frequently having it sent back with the Printing Unit saying that it is not there for party purposes. So what we do is make a request for something to be done and the Printing Unit will decide whether it is suitable or not, under a whole range of guidelines, and in this instance the Printing Unit said that it was not. I am not offended by that-not at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then why did you raise it?

—I was advised that the material, if it were printed, would have breached the relevant guidelines and that it could not so be printed. I said that that was a perfectly satisfactory decision as far as I was concerned and raised the question that this material had been printed by the same unit before. I was then very graciously made the offer that if that were the case and as it had been done before, the Department of the Senate would not want to cause a senator any embarrassment and it would be done again-to which request I responded, `No'. If someone is offended by this material to such an extent that the Printing Unit does not want to print it, then I do not want to ask for that Printing Unit to continue to print it. Those are the facts of the matter, Senator. Had Senator Collins chosen to speak to me prior to raising this matter, I would have given him the benefit of those facts prior to him embarrassing himself by coming here and making allegations that are, in fact, quite untrue.

SPEECH.PARA: To summarise that point, I do not regard myself as having forced that material on the Printing Unit at all. I made a request for it to be printed; the request was denied. It is as simple as that. But the denial was followed with an offer to print, which was declined. I do not want to force material on someone who finds it so offensive that as a part of his or her work he does not want to print it-not at all.

In conclusion, I want to make one other point-that is really to back up a point that I have already made-namely, that if this Parliament is to make sensible laws about what should or should not be available, then it ought to understand what sort of material it is talking about when it uses these catchy little titles like X-rated, R-rated or non-violent erotica. I am quite happy-it is a good thing-that senators will disagree about what material ought to be available and what ought not. I am simply not happy if they engage in that discussion in some form of ignorance as to what the nature of the material is.

With respect to the other legal aspects raised by Senator Collins, I am grateful for the contribution of Senator Harradine. I have not yet had an opportunity to fully peruse the particular ordinance to which he refers, but on the basis of the earlier portion of Senator Collins's contribution, I do not have high expectations that the full content of what he said will turn out to be my interpretation of that particular ordinance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek your indulgence under standing order 408 to make a personal explanation because I have been misrepresented during this debate.
—Standing order 408 or standing order 410?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Does the honourable senator claim to have been misrepresented or has he a personal explanation?
—I have a personal explanation to make.
—Well, are you seeking leave in that case? You need leave.
—I am sorry; I was advised otherwise.
—Senator Collins, are you seeking to use standing order 408?
—Yes, I wish to explain matters of a personal nature, although there is no--
—Is leave granted? There being no objection--
—Just a moment. Perhaps the honourable senator could take 60 seconds to explain what the matters are before leave is granted.
—Mr Acting Deputy President--
—Order! Senator Collins, might I suggest that you indicate that you claim to have been misunderstood under standing order 410, in which case you do not need leave.

—I do, Mr Acting Deputy President. I might add that this is the first time I have ever heard, in the 12 months I have been in this Parliament, a senator's attempt to give a personal explanation questioned.
—No, that is not right.
—That is the first time I have heard it. Standing order 410, Mr President.
—You do not need leave.

—During the debate Senator Harradine-in fact, it is the second time he has done this-referred to the Hansard records of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. He stated that I had spoken in favour of and voted for-I might add, in support of the Government of the Northern Territory-legislation which restricted the access of people to both R- and X-rated videos. He made the point for the purpose of inferring that that indicated my prior public support for the retention of access to such material. If Senator Harradine had done himself the favour of reading the entire debate, he would have realised that the Legislative Assembly enacted that legislation after I initiated the debate to restrict a completely out of hand situation that existed in the Northern Territory at that time. The reason, if Senator Harradine would like to read the whole debate, that the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly did not proceed past that point was that the Northern Territory Government stated quite clearly, and I supported it, that before moving further it would await the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, pursuant to standing order 410, I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Collins. I have read the whole debate. I have made it my business so to do. Senator Collins, by his intervention, suggested that I had not. Indeed, in fairness to him, I read his comments of 6 March 1985. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are members on this side of the Assembly-and they will be free to say so-who want to see X-rated videos banned completely in the Northern Territory. I am sure there are many members on the opposite side of the Assembly who have also that view. That does not happen to be my personal view.
The only thing that one can deduce from Senator Collins's remarks is that his view is that X-rated videos should not be banned completely from the Northern Territory.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following paper was tabled:
Social Security Act-Determination 1988-No. 1-Fees and allowances payable to witnesses appearing before the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, dated 3 November 1988.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the article `A new star in sky wars espionage' in The Australian of 22 June 1988.

(2) Was the Minister accurately quoted in stating that Defence Signals Directorate (DSD) facilities were for `external surveillance purposes', and therefore would not infringe the civil liberties of Australians.

(3) Does this mean that no communications between Australia and another country are intercepted by the DSD, or does it mean that such interceptions are discarded, or does it mean that such interceptions require prior authorisation.

(4) Does this mean that no communications within Australia are intercepted by the DSD, or does it mean that such interceptions are discarded, or does it mean that such interceptions require prior authorisation.

(5) Given that communications intercepted by DSD can be passed on to intelligence services and Governments of allied countries, are the civil liberties of residents of countries monitored by DSD at risk as a result of DSD activities.

(6) Does international or Australian law protect the civil liberties of foreign citizens from the monitoring activities of the DSD; if so, what are the details of that protection, and how does the Government ensure that it is provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (6) The Government, in response to a recommendation of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies, has approved and issued to DSD a set of rules governing the interception of foreign communications originated by, or directed to, Australian persons.
Under those rules, DSD is permitted to intercept such communications only under special circumstances and with the approval of the Attorney-General.
DSD has no domestic intelligence role and as a consequence, is not permitted to intercept any internal Australian communications.

The rules have been modelled on relevant legislation protecting civil liberties in telecommunications interception such as the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. Endorsement of the Rules in no way diminishes the Government's regard for individual rights.

Arrangements are in place for the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security to regularly monitor compliance by the Defence Signals Directorate with those rules, the purpose of which is to protect the privacy of Australian citizens and permanent residents from intrusion, be it deliberate or incidental, by activities of the Defence Signals Directorate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: For the financial years 1986/87 and 1987/88, what were the total monies paid out by your department and authorities within your portfolio in the form of grants or ex gratia payments to consultants, corporations, or other non-employees of the commonwealth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The total amount paid in grants by the Department of Defence was $16,000 in 1986/87 and $21,000 in 1987/88.

(2) In respect to act of grace payments, the Department paid $1,405 during the 1986/87 period to the ex-wife of a Commonwealth employee. During the period 1987/88, the Department made act of grace payments which amounted to a total of $55,106.77 to ex-Commonwealth employees.
